questions.text: A physician is assessing the body composition of patients using various anthropometric indices. Which of the following indices is defined as height in centimetres divided by the cube root of body weight?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ponderal’s index

 

  • The Ponderal's index is calculated as height in centimetres divided by the cube root of body weight (in kilograms).
  • It is used as an alternative to the Body Mass Index (BMI) to assess body composition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quetelet index: The Quetelet index is another name for the Body Mass Index (BMI), which is calculated as weight in kilograms divided by the square of height in meters.

 

Option B. Broca index: The Broca index is a formula used to estimate ideal body weight, calculated as height in centimetres minus 100 for men and minus 105 for women.

 

Option D. Corpulence index (CI): This is an indicator of Obesity. Calculated as -

CI = Actual weight/Desirable weight; Normal CI is up to 1.2

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Ponderal's index is an anthropometric measure calculated as height in centimetres divided by the cube root of body weight.
  • It provides an alternative method to assess body composition, particularly useful in differentiating individuals of similar height but varying body builds.
  • Understanding different indices helps in accurately evaluating and managing patient health.

choices.text: Serum antibodies against Class I HLA antigens
Low levels of serum IgA

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with sickle cell disease develops flank pain and fever, an hour after a blood transfusion. Her urine appearance is shown. What is most likely to be found?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Positive direct Coombs test

 

  • Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction is indicated by a positive direct Coombs test, showing RBCs bound by antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum antibodies against Class I HLA antigens: HLA antibodies cause febrile nonhemolytic reactions.

 

Option B. Low levels of serum IgA: Low IgA is linked to anaphylactic reactions.

 

Option C. Positive blood cultures: Positive cultures suggest sepsis, not transfusion reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction is indicated by a positive direct Coombs test.

choices.text: Only observation of the cat is sufficient

questions.text: A 45-year-old man, who underwent splenectomy 5 years ago, presents to the clinic after being bitten by a previously vaccinated cat. What is the appropriate antibiotic for preventing infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amoxicillin + Clavulanic acid

 

  • Amoxicillin-clavulanate is the first-line therapy for prophylactic treatment of animal bites, particularly in asplenic individuals who are at higher risk for severe infections.
  • This combination antibiotic is effective against a broad spectrum of bacteria commonly found in animal bites, such as Pasteurella species.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metronidazole: Metronidazole is not the recommended first-line treatment for animal bites as it does not cover many of the common bacteria involved.

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin, although effective against some bacteria, is not the first-line therapy for animal bites.

 

Option D. Only observation of the cat is sufficient: Simply observing the cat is not adequate in managing an animal bite, especially in an asplenic individual. Prophylactic antibiotics are essential to prevent potential infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For individuals, particularly those who are asplenic, who have been bitten by an animal, amoxicillin-clavulanate is the recommended antibiotic for infection prophylaxis. Proper wound care, including cleaning and debridement, and ensuring appropriate tetanus and rabies prophylaxis, are also critical components of managing animal bites. Understanding the appropriate use of prophylactic antibiotics can prevent serious complications

choices.text: Blood products should be used to correct coagulopathy.
Crystalloids and colloids should be used judiciously.
Systolic blood pressure should be maintained above 100 mm Hg.
Damage control surgery is employed to control hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency room following a road traffic accident with severe pelvic injuries and signs of ongoing hemorrhage. He is hemodynamically unstable and the surgical team is preparing for immediate intervention. Regarding damage control resuscitation in this context, which of the following statements is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Systolic blood pressure should be maintained above 100 mm Hg.

 

  • In damage control resuscitation, particularly for patients with severe trauma and hemorrhage, the concept of permissive hypotension is applied where the systolic blood pressure is maintained at a lower threshold (70-90 mm Hg) rather than normal or elevated levels.
  • This strategy minimizes bleeding while maintaining enough perfusion to sustain vital organ functions.
  • The goal is to avoid over-resuscitation with fluids, which can dilute coagulation factors and exacerbate bleeding.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Blood products should be used to correct coagulopathy: Correct. Administering blood products like packed red cells, fresh frozen plasma, and platelets is crucial to manage coagulopathy in trauma patients undergoing resuscitation.

 

Option B. Crystalloids and colloids should be used judiciously: Correct. Excessive use of crystalloids and colloids can lead to dilutional coagulopathy and worsen tissue edema, thus they should be used judiciously in the setting of hemorrhagic shock.

 

Option D. Damage control surgery is employed to control hemorrhage: Correct. Damage control surgery aims to quickly control bleeding and contamination in trauma patients, stabilizing them enough for definitive surgery after initial resuscitation.

 

Educational Objective

 

In damage control resuscitation, maintaining a lower threshold of systolic blood pressure (70-90 mm Hg) through permissive hypotension is crucial to minimize ongoing hemorrhage while ensuring adequate organ perfusion.

choices.text: Discontinue anti-leprosy medication and initiate steroids and antibiotics
Continue anti-leprosy medication and add steroids

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman undergoing treatment for leprosy presents with symptoms of Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL), a severe inflammatory reaction. What is the appropriate management strategy in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continue anti-leprosy medication and add steroids

 

  • In the management of Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL), it is crucial to continue anti-leprosy medication to prevent the disease from progressing.
  • Steroids are added to control the inflammatory reaction, as they help reduce inflammation and the immune response associated with ENL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discontinue anti-leprosy medication and initiate steroids and antibiotics: Discontinuing anti-leprosy medication is not recommended, as it can lead to disease progression and resistance.

 

Option B. Prescribe thalidomide: Thalidomide is effective in managing ENL but is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects.

 

Option C. Prescribe thalidomide and steroids: Using thalidomide in combination with steroids is also contraindicated in pregnancy because of the teratogenic risks associated with thalidomide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For managing Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL) in pregnant women, it is essential to continue anti-leprosy medications and add steroids to control the inflammatory response.
  • Thalidomide is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects. Ensuring appropriate treatment helps manage the condition effectively while safeguarding maternal and fetal health.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a history of chronic diarrhea, a symmetric dermatitis in sun-exposed areas, and cognitive disturbances suggestive of dementia. Laboratory tests confirm a vitamin deficiency. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this triad of symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Niacin

 

  • Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency leads to pellagra, which is characterized by the classic triad of diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. If left untreated, pellagra can be fatal. The dermatitis in pellagra is typically photosensitive, presenting as symmetric hyperpigmented rashes in sun-exposed areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency can lead to beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, but not the triad of diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency causes ariboflavinosis, which includes symptoms like sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, cracks or sores on the outsides of the lips (cheilosis) and at the corners of the mouth (angular stomatitis), and a moist, scaly skin inflammation (seborrheic dermatitis), but not the triad mentioned.

 

Option D. Folic acid: Folic acid (vitamin B9) deficiency primarily causes megaloblastic anemia and can lead to neural tube defects in a developing fetus, but not the triad of symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pellagra occurs due to Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency
  • Pellagra is characterized by 4 D’s: Diarrhoea, Dermatitis, Dementia, Death

choices.text: Maternal surface presents at vulva
Most common method of separation

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is in the third stage of labor, and the placenta is about to be delivered. Which statement is incorrect regarding Duncan's placental separation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Most common method of separation

 

  • Duncan's placental separation, often referred to as the "dirty Duncan" method, occurs when the placenta separates from the uterus peripherally.
  • This method is characterized by:
  • Peripheral separation: The placenta detaches from the edges first.
  • Maternal surface presents at vulva: The maternal side of the placenta appears at the vulva during delivery.
  • More blood loss: This method tends to cause more bleeding compared to other methods due to the less controlled manner of separation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maternal surface presents at vulva: This is true for Duncan's separation, where the maternal surface of the placenta is the first to appear at the vulva.

 

Option B. Peripheral separation: This is true, as the placenta separates from the edges first in Duncan's method.

 

Option D. More blood loss: This is true, as Duncan's method is associated with more bleeding compared to the Schultze method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Duncan's placental separation involves peripheral separation, the maternal surface presenting at the vulva, and more blood loss.
  • It is not the most common method of placental separation; the Schultze method is more common.

choices.text: Cefotaxime has higher oral bioavailability
Cefotaxime is more effective against H. influenzae with altered penicillin-binding proteins
Cefotaxime is a bactericidal drug whereas ampicillin is bacteriostatic
Cefotaxime is more effective against beta-lactamase producing strains

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the hospital with symptoms of bacterial meningitis. Cultures reveal infection with beta-lactamase producing Haemophilus influenzae. Why is cefotaxime preferred over ampicillin in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cefotaxime is more effective against beta-lactamase producing strains

 

  • Cefotaxime is a third-generation cephalosporin that is resistant to beta-lactamase enzymes produced by certain strains of H. influenzae.
  • This resistance makes cefotaxime a more effective treatment option in cases of beta-lactamase producing bacterial infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cefotaxime has higher oral bioavailability: This is incorrect as cefotaxime is administered intravenously, not orally, and ampicillin also has poor oral bioavailability for treating meningitis.

 

Option B. Cefotaxime is more effective against H. influenzae with altered penicillin-binding proteins: While cefotaxime is effective against H. influenzae, its primary advantage is its stability against beta-lactamase, rather than altered penicillin-binding proteins.

 

Option C. Cefotaxime is a bactericidal drug whereas ampicillin is bacteriostatic: This is incorrect because both cefotaxime and ampicillin are bactericidal antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cefotaxime is preferred for treating bacterial meningitis caused by beta-lactamase producing Haemophilus influenzae due to its resistance to beta-lactamase enzymes, ensuring greater efficacy in these cases.

choices.text: Rifampicin reduces the effectiveness of OCPs by inducing their metabolism
Rifampicin increases the effectiveness of OCPs
OCPs enhance the effectiveness of rifampicin
OCPs reduce the effectiveness of rifampicin

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is prescribed a regimen that includes rifampicin as part of her treatment for tuberculosis. She is currently using combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for contraception. The healthcare provider recommends adding a barrier method of contraception. What is the primary reason for this recommendation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rifampicin reduces the effectiveness of OCPs by inducing their metabolism

 

  • Rifampicin is a potent inducer of the cytochrome P450 enzyme system, particularly CYP3A4.
  • This induction accelerates the metabolism of oral contraceptive pills, thereby reducing their contraceptive effectiveness and increasing the risk of unintended pregnancy.
  • As a result, an additional barrier method is recommended to ensure effective contraception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rifampicin increases the effectiveness of OCPs: This is incorrect as rifampicin actually decreases the effectiveness of OCPs.

 

Option C. OCPs enhance the effectiveness of rifampicin: OCPs do not have any effect on the effectiveness of rifampicin.

 

Option D. OCPs reduce the effectiveness of rifampicin: OCPs do not interfere with the effectiveness of rifampicin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rifampicin, used in the treatment of tuberculosis, induces the metabolism of combined oral contraceptive pills, leading to decreased contraceptive effectiveness.
  • To prevent unintended pregnancies, it is recommended to use an additional barrier method of contraception while taking rifampicin.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, and fatigue after returning from a camping trip in a wooded area. The physician suspects babesiosis. Babesiosis is most commonly transmitted by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ticks

 

  • ​​Babesiosis is a malaria like illness seen in cattle and sheep.
  • B. microti is the most common species, others being B. bovis and B. divergens.
  •  It is similar to malaria parasite in its life cycle and pathogenesis except for the following differences:
    •  Hard tick (Ixodes scapularis) is the primary vector (definitive host) of the parasite
    • There is no liver-stage, sporozoites enter directly into RBCs
    • Clinical feature: It differs from falciparum malaria being less severe, low parasitemia, no cerebral involvement, less severe anemia and no periodicity seen in fever cycle.
  • More severe in splenectomized and immunocompromised patients

 

Other Options:

 

Options A, B, C:  Pigs, rats, and sand flies are not common vectors for the transmission of Babesia parasites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Babesiosis is most commonly transmitted by deer tick (hard tick) Ixodes scapularis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with diabetes insipidus is prescribed a diuretic that paradoxically reduces urine output. Which of the following diuretics shows paradoxical antidiuretic activity in diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thiazide

 

  • Thiazide diuretics paradoxically reduce urine output in patients with diabetes insipidus.
  • They do this by decreasing distal tubular sodium reabsorption, leading to increased proximal tubular reabsorption of sodium and water.
  • This reduces the volume of urine produced and helps to concentrate the urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Triamterene: This is a potassium-sparing diuretic and does not show paradoxical antidiuretic activity in diabetes insipidus.

 

Option C. Spironolactone: This is also a potassium-sparing diuretic and acts as an aldosterone antagonist, but it does not have paradoxical antidiuretic effects in diabetes insipidus.

 

Option D. Furosemide: This is a loop diuretic that increases urine output and does not have the paradoxical antidiuretic effect seen with thiazides.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Thiazide diuretics exhibit paradoxical antidiuretic activity in diabetes insipidus by promoting sodium and water reabsorption in the proximal tubule, thereby reducing urine output and helping to concentrate the urine.

questions.text: During a ward round, a 42-year-old patient is being discussed due to concerns about dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. The professor explains the role of the countercurrent system in the kidneys in maintaining water and solute balance to the medical interns. Which of the following will function as the countercurrent exchanger in the countercurrent system of the kidneys?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vasa Recta

 

  • The vasa recta are a series of straight capillaries in the medulla of the kidney that lie parallel to the loop of Henle.
  • They function as the counter current exchangers in the kidney's counter current system.
  • The vasa recta play a crucial role in maintaining the osmotic gradient in the renal medulla, which is essential for the concentration of urine.
  • They achieve this by allowing blood to flow slowly and in a counter current direction relative to the flow of filtrate in the loop of Henle, thus facilitating the exchange of solutes and water without dissipating the osmotic gradient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peritubular Capillaries: Peritubular capillaries surround the proximal and distal tubules and are involved in the reabsorption of solutes and water, but they do not function as the counter current exchangers.

 

Option B. Loop of Henle: The loop of Henle functions as the counter current multiplier, which helps establish the osmotic gradient in the renal medulla. However, it is not the exchanger; it multiplies the concentration gradient.

 

Option D. Juxtaglomerular Apparatus: The juxtaglomerular apparatus is involved in regulating blood pressure and the filtration rate of the glomerulus through the release of renin, but it is not involved in the counter current exchange process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vasa recta function as the counter current exchangers in the kidneys, maintaining the osmotic gradient necessary for the concentration of urine and the regulation of water and solute balance.

questions.text: A forensic expert examines an individual found deceased under suspicious circumstances with a notable skin injury on the forearm as shown in the image. which type of abrasion is most likely observed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pressure abrasion

 

  • Pressure abrasion is typically caused by the sustained application of a rough object against the skin, leading to crushing or friction-related skin damage.
  • This type of abrasion is often seen in cases involving nooses, ligatures in hanging and strangulation, or teeth bite marks, which can either produce contusions or lacerations depending on the force applied.
  • The characteristics of the injury described suggest a localized, intense application of pressure consistent with pressure abrasion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scratch/linear abrasion - Caused by contact with sharp or pointed objects such as fingernails, thorns, or pins. This type of abrasion produces a more linear, defined mark, which does not align with the described injury.

 

Option B. Graze abrasion - Results from horizontal or tangential friction between the skin and a hard rough surface, typical of road traffic accidents (RTA). It covers a broader area and is more superficial than what is indicated in the scenario.

 

Option C. Imprint abrasion - Occurs when an object impacts the skin perpendicularly, leaving a patterned imprint, such as tire marks in RTAs or shoe sole marks from a kick. The injury described lacks the patterned aspect typical of imprint abrasions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pressure abrasion results from the direct, intense pressure of a rough object against the skin, often seen in forensic cases involving strangulation or other forms of physical restraint.
  • Recognizing this type of abrasion is crucial for understanding the mechanism of injury and potential circumstances surrounding the individual's death.

choices.text: Increased serum amyloid A production

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with Rheumatoid arthritis presents with fatigue, puffy face, frothy urine, and swelling of legs and feet. He takes amlodipine, methotrexate, and ibuprofen. Physical exam shows pallor, periorbital edema, and 2+ pedal edema. Labs reveal Hb 8.2 g/dL, albumin 2.8 g/dL, and urine protein 3+. What is the cause of his findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased serum amyloid A production

 

  • Chronic inflammatory processes like rheumatoid arthritis increase serum amyloid A (SAA) production, leading to AA amyloidosis and nephrotic syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased hepatic albumin production: Decreased hepatic albumin production suggests liver failure, which is not supported by normal LFTs and ultrasound.

 

Option B. Adverse effect of amlodipine: Amlodipine causes pedal edema but not periorbital edema, ascites, or proteinuria.

 

Option C. Renal AL amyloid deposition: Renal AL amyloid deposition is associated with plasma cell dyscrasias like multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic inflammatory processes like rheumatoid arthritis increase serum amyloid A (SAA) production.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic seeking advice on contraceptive options following unprotected intercourse. She is looking to understand which methods are available and effective. Which of the following is NOT considered a post-coital contraceptive?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Diaphragm
 

  • The diaphragm is a barrier method of contraception that is placed inside the vagina to cover the cervix to prevent sperm from entering the uterus.
  • It must be used with spermicide and placed before intercourse, and thus, it is not effective as a post-coital contraceptive because it cannot prevent pregnancy after intercourse has already occurred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. OCPs: Combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) can be used in higher doses as emergency contraception (often referred to as the Yuzpe regimen).

 

Option C. RU-486: RU-486 (mifepristone) is used as an emergency contraceptive to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse.

 

Option D. Copper-T: The Copper-T intrauterine device (IUD) can be inserted up to five days after unprotected intercourse as a highly effective form of emergency contraception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Emergency contraception (EC) methods are crucial after unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy.
  • Key options include the Yuzpe method using combined oral contraceptive pills within 72 hours, and Progesterone Only Pills (POP) which are more effective and have fewer side effects.
  • IUDs can be inserted within 5 days, offering higher efficacy than OCPs. Mifepristone (RU-486) and high-dose estrogens are also available, each with specific usage timelines. Common side effects include nausea, and EC does not protect against STDs.

questions.text: A 58-year-old fair skinned male presents to the clinic with a slowly enlarging lesion on his face. Biopsy of the lesion reveals a picture as given below. Given these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Basal cell carcinoma

 

  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is characterized histologically by basaloid cells forming nests or islands, which typically show peripheral palisading and central necrosis.
  • This description matches the biopsy findings in the presented patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Incorrect - Squamous cell carcinoma would show keratin pearls and intercellular bridges, not the basaloid cells with peripheral palisading seen in BCC.

 

Option B. Melanoma: Incorrect - Melanoma typically exhibits atypical melanocytes with varying degrees of pigmentation, and the architecture is different from the nests seen in BCC.

 

Option D. Actinic keratosis: Incorrect - Actinic keratosis presents with atypical keratinocytes throughout the epidermis and often parakeratosis, which does not include basaloid cell characteristics or the specific palisading pattern of BCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer, often appearing as a pearly lesion with telangiectasia.
  • It grows slowly and is generally considered locally invasive without substantial risk of metastasis. Key histopathological features include basaloid cells with peripheral palisading and occasional central necrosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are incorrect about the pathology shown in image? 

 

 

  1. Tumour has distinct margins
  2. Is eccentric
  3. Arises from the epiphysis
  4. Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3, 4 

 

  • The image shows a a bone lesion in the proximal tibia, characterized by a "soap bubble" lytic appearance, with eccentric location, and extending close to the joint line. 
  • This appearance is highly suggestive of a Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of bone.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

Statement 3. Arises from the epiphysis: Incorrect. GCTs arise from the metaphysis and extend into the epiphysis, often reaching the subchondral bone but do not cross the joint. 

 

Statement 4. Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice: Chemotherapy is not the primary treatment of choice for typical GCTs. The mainstay of treatment is surgical, involving extended curettage with or without adjuvant therapy (like liquid nitrogen, phenol, or bone cement) to destroy remaining tumor cells, or en bloc resection in more aggressive or recurrent cases. Denosumab, a monoclonal antibody, is also used, especially for unresectable tumors or as neoadjuvant therapy. Chemotherapy is generally reserved for rare cases of malignant GCTs or metastatic disease, which is not the typical presentation or initial treatment. 

 

Correct statements: 

 

Statement 1. Tumour has distinct margins: This statement is correct. GCTs typically have well-defined but non-sclerotic margins. They are lytic lesions but do not usually show a reactive sclerotic rim. The margins are distinct but often "geographic" rather than truly sharply demarcated. They are not infiltrative. Therefore, compared to malignant tumors, they are more distinct.

 

Statement 2. Is eccentric: This statement is correct. GCTs are classically described as eccentric in location, i.e., they are off-center within the bone, typically arising from one side of the metaphysis and expanding towards the cortex. The given image supports this, as the lesion appears to be predominantly on one side of the tibial shaft. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the GCT of the proximal tibia. 
  • GCT arises from the metaphysis of the long bones and extends into the epiphysis. 
  • The treatment of choice in such tumors is the surgical excision with extended curettage and not chemotherapy.

choices.text: Hogarth- Pringle

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a major road accident. He is stabilized but exhibits abdominal bruising. A contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) of the abdomen reveals a zone 1 retroperitoneal hematoma, suspected to involve the abdominal aorta. Which surgical maneuver is primarily used to expose the abdominal aorta in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mattox

 

  • The Mattox maneuver is a surgical technique used to mobilize the left colon and spleen medially to expose the abdominal aorta and the left infra-renal vascular structures.
  • This is particularly useful in cases of trauma where a retroperitoneal hematoma suggests aortic or major vessel injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cattle-Braasch: Incorrect. This maneuver is described for vascular exposure in IVC injury.

 

Option C. Kocherization: Incorrect. Kocherization is a maneuver used to mobilize the duodenum and head of the pancreas, typically for better visualization and access to the pancreas or duodenum, not the aorta.

 

Option D. Hogarth- Pringle: Incorrect. The Pringle maneuver is employed to occlude inflow to the liver via the hepatoduodenal ligament to control bleeding, not for exposure of the aorta.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • The Mattox maneuver is crucial for exposing the abdominal aorta in trauma cases, involving medial mobilization of the left colon and spleen.
  • It is a fundamental technique in the management of abdominal vascular injuries, especially in settings of trauma with suspected aortic involvement.

questions.text: A public health official is reviewing the components of disaster management to ensure comprehensive preparation and response plans are in place. Which of the following is not typically practiced in disaster management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mass vaccination

 

  • While vaccination campaigns may be part of public health strategies, they are not typically a standard component of disaster management.
  • Mass vaccination is more associated with controlling outbreaks of infectious diseases rather than responding to disasters.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triage: Triage is a crucial component of disaster management. It involves the process of sorting and prioritizing patients based on the severity of their injuries to ensure that those who need immediate medical attention receive it promptly.

 

Option B. Rehabilitation: Rehabilitation is an important part of the recovery phase in disaster management, focusing on restoring normalcy and providing ongoing care to those affected.

 

Option D. Disaster response: Disaster response includes all immediate actions taken during and after a disaster to ensure the safety, health, and well-being of affected populations.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Disaster management typically includes triage, rehabilitation, and disaster response. Mass vaccination, while important for controlling infectious diseases, is not a standard component of disaster management. Understanding the various elements of disaster management helps in preparing and implementing effective response plans to minimize the impact of disasters on affected populations.
  • WHO does not recommend routine vaccines viz. Typhoid, Cholera and Tetanus Toxoid vaccinations in routine use in endemic areas post-disaster.

choices.text: No impulse on coughing
Presence of rugosities of overlying vaginal mucosa
None of the above

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics does not differentiate a Gartner’s cyst from a cystocele?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presence of rugosities of overlying vaginal mucosa

 

  • Gartner's cyst, a benign cystic lesion arising from remnants of the mesonephric duct, typically presents as a non-reducible mass without an impulse on coughing.
  • The overlying vaginal mucosa in the case of a Gartner's cyst usually has normal rugosities, which is not a differentiating factor from a cystocele.
  • A cystocele, on the other hand, is characterized by the descent of the bladder into the vaginal canal, often reducible, and shows an impulse on coughing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Not reducible: Gartner's cysts are typically not reducible, whereas cystoceles can often be reduced.

 

Option B. No impulse on coughing: Gartner's cysts do not exhibit an impulse on coughing, unlike cystoceles which do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gartner's cyst can be differentiated from a cystocele by its non-reducible nature and lack of impulse on coughing.
  • The presence of rugosities of the overlying vaginal mucosa is not a differentiating feature.

choices.text: Administration of toxoids to stimulate antibody production.
Exposure to a subclinical infection leading to immune response without symptoms.
Administration of antitoxin to neutralize toxins.
Administration of immunoglobulins for immediate protection.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is an example of inducing active immunity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Administration of toxoids to stimulate antibody production.

 

  • Administration of toxoids to stimulate antibody production is an example of active immunity.
  • Toxoids are inactivated toxins that stimulate the body's immune system to produce antibodies, leading to long-term immunity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Exposure to a subclinical infection leading to immune response without symptoms: This is also an example of active immunity because the body mounts an immune response and develops immunity through natural exposure to the pathogen.

 

Option C. Administration of antitoxin to neutralize toxins: This is an example of passive immunity, as it involves the administration of preformed antibodies that provide immediate protection but do not stimulate the body's own immune response.

 

Option D. Administration of immunoglobulins for immediate protection: This is another example of passive immunity, as it provides immediate protection through preformed antibodies without stimulating the recipient's own immune system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Active immunity is induced by methods that stimulate the body's immune system to produce its own antibodies, such as the administration of toxoids or exposure to an infection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman with type 2 diabetes and primary hypertension presents with severe abdominal pain and scleral icterus. Blood pressure is 126/82 mm/Hg, and blood glucose is 98 mg/dL. Ultrasound reveals decreased hepatic vein flow. What most likely predisposes her to this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pregnancy

 

  • Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is characterized by reduced hepatic outflow, with risk factors including pregnancy, oral contraceptives, and hypercoagulable states.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetes mellitus: Diabetes mellitus is a risk for other complications but not directly BCS.

 

Option B. Insulin: Insulin causes hypoglycemia, not BCS.

 

Option C. Labetalol: Labetalol can cause hypotension, not BCS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is characterized by reduced hepatic outflow, with risk factors including pregnancy, oral contraceptives, and hypercoagulable states.

choices.text: Diffuse thickening of the GBM with a spike and dome pattern
Tram-track appearance of the GBM

questions.text: A 41-year-old man, who was recently found to have renal vein thrombosis, is under medical review. His medical history includes significant weight gain, generalized edema, and hypertension. His urine analysis reveals significant proteinuria and the presence of numerous normal-looking red blood cells without any casts. Tests also show positive anti-PLA2R antibodies. Based on these findings, what would you expect to see on his renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diffuse thickening of the GBM with spike and dome pattern

 

  • The presence of anti-PLA2R antibodies is highly suggestive of primary membranous nephropathy. This autoimmune disorder is characterized histologically by diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) due to subepithelial immune deposits.
  • These deposits can lead to the formation of a "spike and dome" pattern on silver staining of the renal biopsy, which is a classic finding in this condition.
  • The combination of gross proteinuria and the specific antibody presence further supports this diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tram-track appearance of the GBM: This finding is typical of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), which is associated with immune complex deposition and complement activation within the GBM and mesangium. It is not indicative of membranous nephropathy.

 

Option C. Mesangial deposition of IgA: The presence of IgA in the mesangium is characteristic of IgA nephropathy (Berger’s disease), which does not correlate with the presence of anti-PLA2R antibodies and is differentiated by its immunofluorescence staining patterns.

 

Option D. Large and hypercellular glomeruli: This description fits with proliferative forms of glomerulonephritis, such as lupus nephritis or acute post-infectious glomerulonephritis, rather than membranous nephropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with symptoms of nephrotic syndrome and testing positive for anti-PLA2R antibodies, the expected finding on renal biopsy is a diffuse thickening of the GBM with a spike and dome pattern, indicative of primary membranous nephropathy.

choices.text: They cause bronchodilation when given with xanthines
They increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol
They increase the action of aminophylline on adenosine receptors
They increase the mucociliary clearance

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic asthma presents to the emergency department with severe shortness of breath and wheezing unresponsive to his usual inhaled salbutamol. The patient is given intravenous corticosteroids and aminophylline, which lead to significant improvement. What is the primary mechanism by which corticosteroids help in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) They increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol

 

  • Corticosteroids enhance the sensitivity of the bronchial smooth muscle to beta-agonists like salbutamol.
  • By reducing inflammation and edema in the airways, corticosteroids improve the effectiveness of beta-agonists, leading to better bronchodilation and relief of asthma symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They cause bronchodilation when given with xanthines: Corticosteroids do not directly cause bronchodilation; they primarily reduce inflammation.

 

Option C. They increase the action of aminophylline on adenosine receptors: Corticosteroids do not increase the action of aminophylline on adenosine receptors; aminophylline itself inhibits phosphodiesterase and blocks adenosine receptors.

 

Option D. They increase the mucociliary clearance: While corticosteroids can have some effect on mucociliary clearance, this is not their primary mechanism of action in improving acute asthma exacerbations.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Corticosteroids enhance the responsiveness of bronchial smooth muscle to beta-agonists like salbutamol by reducing airway inflammation and edema.
  • This leads to improved bronchodilation and symptom relief in acute asthma exacerbations.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with dark urine, a history of bacterial infections, and venous thromboses, including portal vein thrombosis. Examination shows a swollen, tender right leg. Labs: Hb 9.8 g/dL, Hct 29.9%, MCV 92 µm³, platelets 150,000/mm³, WBC 3800/mm³. He has reticulocytosis and very low serum haptoglobin. Which gene mutation is likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphatidylinositol glycan A (PIGA)

 

  • The clinical presentation suggests paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), which is caused by a mutation in the PIGA gene.
  • This gene is essential for the synthesis of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors, which attach protective proteins to the cell surface.
  • The absence of these proteins on red blood cells leads to increased susceptibility to complement-mediated lysis, resulting in hemolysis, dark urine (due to hemoglobinuria), low haptoglobin levels, and increased risk of thrombosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase: Deficiency in this enzyme causes G6PD deficiency, leading to episodic hemolysis triggered by oxidative stress, but it does not explain the chronic symptoms and thrombosis seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Spectrin: Mutations in spectrin are associated with hereditary spherocytosis, which causes hemolytic anemia but not the specific combination of symptoms, including thrombosis, seen in PNH.

 

Option C. β-Globin chain: Mutations in the β-globin chain are responsible for conditions like sickle cell disease and β-thalassemia, which do not align with this patient's presentation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is associated with mutations in the PIGA gene, leading to defective GPI anchors and resulting in hemolysis, hemoglobinuria, and an increased risk of thrombosis.

choices.text: Mycobacterium can always be grown in menstrual blood
Associated with infertility
Ectopic pregnancy is common
Dysmenorrhea is a common presentation

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with chronic pelvic pain, irregular menstrual cycles, and a history of tuberculosis. Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is suspected, and further investigations confirm tuberculous etiology. Which of the following statements is true regarding pelvic inflammatory disease due to tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Associated with infertility

 

  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) caused by tuberculosis often leads to infertility.
  • Tuberculous infection can cause extensive scarring and damage to the reproductive organs, including the fallopian tubes, which can result in blocked tubes and subsequent infertility.
  • This condition is a significant cause of infertility in regions where tuberculosis is prevalent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium can always be grown in menstrual blood: This is incorrect. While Mycobacterium tuberculosis can sometimes be detected in menstrual blood, it is not always present, and culture methods may not consistently yield positive results due to the paucibacillary nature of the infection.

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy is common: Although tuberculous PID can increase the risk of tubal damage, leading to ectopic pregnancies, it is not the most common complication. Infertility is more frequently associated with tuberculous PID.

 

Option D. Dysmenorrhea is a common presentation: Dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) can occur in PID, but it is not the most common or specific presentation of tuberculous PID. Chronic pelvic pain and infertility are more characteristic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pelvic inflammatory disease due to tuberculosis is commonly associated with infertility due to the extensive scarring and damage to the reproductive organs caused by the infection.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man presents with increasing dyspnea for the past week. Physical examination reveals a temperature of 37.3°C, pulse 85/min, and blood pressure 150/95 mm Hg. There is dullness to percussion over the lung bases. Laboratory findings include serum creatinine 3.1 mg/dL, urea nitrogen 29 mg/dL, troponin I 0.1 ng/mL, hemoglobin 11.7 g/dL, and positive ANA and anti-double-stranded DNA antibody test results. Which of the following cardiac lesions is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Libman-Sacks endocarditis

 

  • Libman-Sacks endocarditis is a form of nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • The patient's positive ANA and anti-double-stranded DNA antibody test results indicate an autoimmune process consistent with SLE.
  • The presence of bilateral pleural effusions, elevated serum creatinine, and urea nitrogen levels further supports the diagnosis of SLE, which can involve multiple organs, including the kidneys and serosal surfaces. Libman-Sacks endocarditis involves vegetations on the heart valves, which are typically sterile but can cause valvular dysfunction.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Calcific aortic stenosis: This condition is characterized by calcification and narrowing of the aortic valve, leading to symptoms like angina, syncope, and heart failure, but it is not associated with positive ANA and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies.

 

Option B. Constrictive pericarditis: This results from the thickening and calcification of the pericardium, restricting heart movement, but it is not typically associated with SLE or the serological findings presented.

 

Option C. Ischemic cardiomyopathy: This condition results from chronic ischemic heart disease leading to heart failure but is not associated with positive autoimmune markers or the described clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Libman-Sacks endocarditis is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and presents with nonbacterial vegetations on heart valves.
  • Positive ANA and anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are indicative of SLE, making Libman-Sacks endocarditis the most likely cardiac lesion in this patient.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a high fever, severe sore throat, and difficulty breathing. On examination, the child has a thick gray membrane covering the throat and swollen neck glands. Suspecting a potentially serious bacterial infection, the doctor orders a throat swab. The result of the microscopic examination is shown in the image. Identify the organism and pick its other name from the options:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kleb-Loeffler bacillus

 

  • The organism shown in the microscopic image is Corynebacterium diphtheriae, which is responsible for diphtheria.
  • It appears as club-shaped rods with a characteristic beaded appearance.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae is also known as the Kleb-Loeffler bacillus, named after the scientists who first identified it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Koch’s bacillus: This refers to Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of tuberculosis, not diphtheria.

 

Option C. Roux bacillus: This is not a recognized term for any common pathogenic bacteria.

 

Option D. Yersin bacillus: This refers to Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, not diphtheria.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae is known as the Kleb-Loeffler bacillus and is the causative agent of diphtheria. It appears as club-shaped rods on microscopic examination.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male chronic alcoholic is admitted to the general medicine ward with symptoms of abdominal distention, yellowish discoloration of the eyes, and abdominal pain. He is diagnosed with decompensated liver disease. All of the following clotting factors will be affected in this patient except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Factor VIII

 

  • In decompensated liver disease, the synthesis of most clotting factors is impaired due to the liver's compromised function. The liver produces several clotting factors, including Factors II, VII, and IX, which are vitamin K-dependent.
  • However, Factor VIII is synthesized by endothelial cells, primarily in the liver but also in other tissues, and its levels can actually be normal or elevated in liver disease due to decreased clearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor II: Factor II (prothrombin) is produced in the liver and is dependent on vitamin K for its synthesis. It is typically reduced in liver disease.

 

Option B. Factor VII: Factor VII is another vitamin K-dependent clotting factor synthesized by the liver and is commonly reduced in liver disease.

 

Option D. Factor IX: Factor IX is also synthesized in the liver and is dependent on vitamin K. It is typically reduced in liver disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In decompensated liver disease, the synthesis of most clotting factors, including Factors II, VII, and IX, is impaired due to the liver's compromised function.
  • Factor VIII, however, is less affected because it is primarily produced by endothelial cells, not hepatocytes, and may remain normal or even elevated.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman, has a plasma glucose level of 160 mg/dl. What dietary management advice should be provided for managing her condition? 

 

  1. Not more than 30% of calories should come from fat
  2. Sodium intake should be less than 5000 mg/day
  3. Diet with total cholesterol less than 100 mg per day
  4. Diet including 80g dietary fiber daily
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

  • 1) Not more than 30% of calories should come from fat: This recommendation aligns with general dietary guidelines for managing blood glucose levels and promoting cardiovascular health. A balanced diet with controlled fat intake helps manage blood sugar and reduce the risk of cardiovascular complications.
  • 2) Sodium intake should be less than 5000 mg/day: While this recommendation is quite high and not typically advised (the usual recommendation is less than 2300 mg/day), reducing sodium intake is crucial for managing blood pressure and overall cardiovascular health. It is important to keep sodium intake within recommended limits to prevent hypertension and associated complications.

 

Other options:

 

  • 3) Diet with total cholesterol less than 100 mg per day: This is an impractically low target for total cholesterol intake. General guidelines suggest limiting cholesterol intake to less than 200 mg per day.
  • 4) Diet including 80g dietary fiber daily: This is an excessively high amount of dietary fiber, as the typical recommendation is about 25-30g per day for adults. Excessive fiber intake can cause gastrointestinal issues and may not be practical for most individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prudent Diet (Dietary Goals)

 

  • A prudent diet may be associated with enhanced insulin sensitivity and a lower risk of type 2 diabetes—It is a dietary modification is the principal preventive strategy for prevention of CHD and other chronic diseases
  • GOAL of Prudent Diet: Cholesterol/HDL Ratio <3.5
  • WHO recommended changes:
    • Reduction of fat intake to <30% of total energy intake
    • Consumption of saturated fats <7% of total energy
    • intake
    • Reduction in dietary cholesterol to <200 mg per day
    • Increase in complex carbohydrate consumption
    • Reduction of salt intake to <5 gms per day
    • Avoidance of alcohol consumption

choices.text: It involves the action potential "jumping" from one node of Ranvier to the next
It is characterized by the repolarization phase "jumping" across myelin sheaths
It enhances the speed of nerve impulse transmission
It is a feature of myelinated axons, contributing to efficient neural communication

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic with progressive weakness and sensory disturbances. His MRI shows demyelination of the central nervous system. The neurologist explains the concept of saltatory conduction to the residents using this case. Which of the following statements about saltatory conduction is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is characterized by the repolarization phase "jumping" across myelin sheaths.

 

  • Saltatory conduction refers to the process by which action potentials "jump" from one node of Ranvier to the next along a myelinated axon.
  • This mechanism significantly increases the speed of nerve impulse transmission compared to unmyelinated fibers. The nodes of Ranvier are gaps in the myelin sheath where ion channels are densely packed, allowing for rapid depolarization and propagation of the action potential.
  • The repolarization phase, however, does not "jump" across the myelin sheaths; it occurs at each node.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It involves the action potential "jumping" from one node of Ranvier to the next: This is correct. The action potential appears to jump from node to node, which is a defining characteristic of saltatory conduction.

 

Option C. It enhances the speed of nerve impulse transmission: This is correct. Saltatory conduction allows for much faster transmission of nerve impulses compared to continuous conduction in unmyelinated fibers.

 

Option D.  It is a feature of myelinated axons, contributing to efficient neural communication: This is correct. Myelinated axons use saltatory conduction to transmit neural signals quickly and efficiently over longer distances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Saltatory conduction increases the speed and efficiency of nerve impulse transmission by allowing action potentials to jump from one node of Ranvier to the next in myelinated axons.
  • The repolarization phase does not "jump" across myelin sheaths, making that statement incorrect.

choices.text: Can be caused by both staphylococcus and streptococcus
It extends deep into subcutaneous tissues
It feels hard on palpation

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with well demarcated redness over leg as shown in the image below. It was extremely painful. Which of the following statement is true regarding it?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It feels hard on palpation

 

  • Clinical image shows well defined erythematous plaques over leg.
  • Erysipelas is characterized by well-demarcated redness and warmth, and it often feels firm or raised on palpation due to the inflammatory response.
  • Therefore, this statement is true.
  • Differential diagnosis of tender erythematous plaques over leg are erysipelas and cellulitis.
  • Erysipelas is a skin infection that typically presents with well-demarcated redness, warmth, and pain, most commonly affecting the lower extremities.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Can be caused by both Staphylococcus and Streptococcus

 

  • Erysipelas is caused by Streptococcus, especially Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes).
  • Staphylococcus is not a causative agent for erysipelas.
  • Therefore, this statement is not true.

 

Option B. It extends deep into subcutaneous tissues:

 

  • Erysipelas typically involves the upper layers of the skin and the superficial dermis but does not extend deep into subcutaneous tissues.
  • It is more superficial compared to cellulitis.

 

Option D. It never involves the ear:

 

  • Erysipelas can affect various parts of the body, including the ear (Milian's Ear Sign).
  • Ear involvement is called Milian's ear sign, and it is a feature distinguishing erysipelas from cellulitis, because the pinna has no deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissue 

 

Educational Objective:

  • Erysipelas is characterized by well-demarcated redness and warmth and often feels firm or raised on palpation due to the inflammatory response.

choices.text: Antibodies to presynaptic calcium channels
Demyelination of the central nervous system
Demyelination of the peripheral nervous system

questions.text: A 42-year-old man complains of double vision and difficulty speaking and breathing daily in the evening. Examination shows the following appearance. His peripheral muscle tone and deep tendon reflexes were normal. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antibodies to acetylcholine receptors

 

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease caused by antibodies against acetylcholine receptors.
  • Ptosis is very common and patients can have diplopia due to ophthalmoplegia.
  • The ice pack test is a simple bed side test that helps confirm the diagnosis by improving muscle strength temporarily.
  • Weakness in myasthenia is usually diurnal with worsening during the evenings and improvement after rest (typically gets better in the mornings)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antibodies to presynaptic calcium channels: Presynaptic calcium channel antibodies are seen in Lambert-Eaton syndrome.

 

Option C. Demyelination of the central nervous system: CNS demyelination is seen in multiple sclerosis.

 

Option D. Demyelination of the peripheral nervous system: PNS demyelination occurs in Guillain-Barre syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease caused by antibodies against acetylcholine receptors.

questions.text:
Match List A with List B correctly and select your answer using the codes given below:

 

List A

 

  1. Papaya fruit
  2. Soya beans
  3. Ragi
  4. Amla fruit

 

List B

 

  1. Calcium
  2. Vitamin C
  3. Protein
  4. Vitamin A
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a-IV, b-III, c-I, d-II

 

  • a. Papaya fruit - IV. Vitamin A: Papaya is rich in Vitamin A.
  • b. Soya beans - III. Protein: Soya beans are a significant source of protein.
  • c. Ragi - I. Calcium: Ragi (finger millet) is known for its high calcium content.
  • d. Amla fruit - II. Vitamin C: Amla (Indian gooseberry) is exceptionally high in Vitamin C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Matching food items with their primary nutrients helps in understanding the nutritional benefits of different foods, which is essential for dietary planning and ensuring a balanced diet.

choices.text: I – a, II – c, III – e, IV – f
I – g, II – d, III – f, IV – e
I – g, II – d, III – b, IV – e
I – g, II – c, III – d, IV – f

questions.text:
Match the type of glaucoma with its associated condition:

 

Column A

 

  1. Phacolytic glaucoma
  2. Neovascular glaucoma
  3. Inverse glaucoma
  4. Angle recession glaucoma

 

Column B

 

  1. Intumescent cataract
  2. Anterior uveitis
  3. Penetrating trauma
  4. Diabetic retinopathy
  5. Blunt trauma
  6. Glaucoma surgery
  7. Morgagnian cataract
questions.solution:
Ans. B) I – g, II – d, III – f, IV – e

 

  • I – g (Phacolytic glaucoma – Morgagnian cataract): Phacolytic glaucoma occurs when proteins leak from a hypermature (Morgagnian) cataract, leading to inflammation and elevated intraocular pressure.
  • II – d (Neovascular glaucoma – Diabetic retinopathy): Neovascular glaucoma is often associated with proliferative diabetic retinopathy, where new, abnormal blood vessels grow on the iris and in the angle, obstructing aqueous outflow.
  • III – f (Inverse glaucoma – Glaucoma Surgery): Inverse glaucoma can occur due to changes in the eye's internal structures following any intraocular surgery.
  • IV – e (Angle recession glaucoma – Blunt trauma): Angle recession glaucoma results from blunt trauma to the eye, causing tearing of the anterior chamber angle structures and leading to increased intraocular pressure.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Different types of glaucoma can be associated with various ocular and systemic conditions, such as Morgagnian cataract, diabetic retinopathy, penetrating trauma, and blunt trauma.
  • Proper identification and association are crucial for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 35-year-old Pregnant woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with peptic ulcer disease. She is currently taking NSAIDs for her arthritis. Which of the following ulcer medications is most likely contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Misoprostol

 

  • Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E1 analog used to prevent NSAID-induced gastric ulcers.
  • However, it is contraindicated in pregnant women due to its abortifacient effects, which can cause uterine contractions and lead to miscarriage.
  • Since women with rheumatoid arthritis may be of childbearing age and taking NSAIDs, misoprostol should be used with caution or avoided unless effective contraception is assured.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Famotidine: Famotidine is an H2 receptor antagonist and is generally safe for use in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option B. Omeprazole: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor and is safe for use in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option D. Ranitidine: Ranitidine is another H2 receptor antagonist and is safe for use in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Misoprostol, used to prevent NSAID-induced gastric ulcers, is contraindicated in pregnant women and should be used with caution in women of childbearing age due to its abortifacient properties.
  • This makes it a less suitable choice for female patients with rheumatoid arthritis who are on NSAID therapy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with multiple lesions on the penile shaft, as shown in the image. He reports that the lesions have gradually increased in number over the past few months. He is sexually active with multiple partners and does not consistently use protection. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Human papillomavirus (HPV)

 

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) is the most likely causative agent for the lesions shown in the image.
  • HPV is known to cause genital warts, which are typically raised, rough-textured lesions on the genitalia. These warts can increase in number and size over time and are commonly transmitted through sexual contact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex virus: Typically causes painful vesicles or ulcers, not rough-textured warts.

 

Option C. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Does not typically present with genital warts; it usually causes systemic symptoms or mononucleosis-like syndrome.

 

Option D. Varicella-zoster virus (VZV): Causes chickenpox and shingles, presenting with vesicular rashes rather than genital warts.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) is the most common cause of genital warts, which are characterized by raised, rough-textured lesions on the genitalia.
  • It is a sexually transmitted infection that can increase in number and size over time.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man has experienced increasing respiratory difficulty for the past 18 months, preventing him from passing his yearly physical examination as an airline pilot. Physical examination is unremarkable. Pulmonary function tests show normal FEV1 but diminished FVC. A chest radiograph reveals diffuse interstitial disease without masses or hilar adenopathy. ANA and anti-DNA topoisomerase I antibody tests are negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

 

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is characterized by progressive interstitial lung disease leading to restrictive lung disease, evidenced by normal FEV₁ and reduced FVC.
  • Chest radiographs typically show diffuse interstitial changes.
  • The absence of autoimmune markers such as ANA and anti-DNA topoisomerase I supports the diagnosis of IPF over other conditions.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Goodpasture syndrome: Typically involves hemoptysis and renal involvement, with anti-GBM antibodies.

 

Option B. Scleroderma: Often associated with positive ANA or anti-DNA topoisomerase I antibodies.

 

Option C. Diffuse alveolar damage: More typical of acute conditions like ARDS, not a chronic, progressive disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a chronic, progressive interstitial lung disease characterized by restrictive lung patterns on PFTs and diffuse interstitial changes on radiographs, without autoimmune marker positivity.

choices.text: Croup
Asthma
Failure to intubate
Acute epiglottitis

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with high fever, severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and drooling. The image of his airway is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute epiglottitis

 

  • This condition is characterized by the sudden onset of high fever, sore throat, dysphagia, drooling, and a characteristic inflamed, cherry-red epiglottis seen on examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Croup: Typically presents with a barking cough and inspiratory stridor, not with an inflamed epiglottis.

 

Option B. Asthma: Manifests with wheezing and respiratory distress but does not involve epiglottal inflammation.

 

Option C. Failure to intubate: Is a procedural complication rather than a diagnosis and does not explain the patient's symptoms or findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute epiglottitis is an emergency condition often caused by Hemophilus influenzae type B. It presents with fever, sore throat, drooling, and a characteristic inflamed epiglottis. Prompt recognition and airway management are crucial.

questions.text: A patient with a suspected metabolic disorder is being evaluated for abnormalities in nucleotide synthesis. Laboratory tests are being conducted to identify any deficiencies in the purine biosynthesis pathway. Which of the following compounds is a required substrate for purine biosynthesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5-Phosphoribosylpyrophosphate (PRPP)

 

  • 5-Phosphoribosylpyrophosphate (PRPP) is essential for the synthesis of purines.
  • It provides the ribose-phosphate backbone that is necessary for the formation of purine nucleotides, such as adenine and guanine.
  • PRPP is a key molecule in the initial steps of the purine biosynthetic pathway, facilitating the attachment of purine bases to the ribose-phosphate structure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ara C: Also known as cytarabine, Ara C is a chemotherapeutic agent used to treat certain cancers. It is an analog of cytidine and does not play a role in purine biosynthesis.

 

Option B. 5-Methyl thymidine: This is a modified nucleoside related to thymine and is involved in DNA synthesis, but it is not a substrate for purine biosynthesis.

 

Option C. Ribose phosphate: While ribose phosphate is involved in metabolic pathways leading to nucleotide synthesis, PRPP is the active substrate directly involved in purine biosynthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 5-Phosphoribosylpyrophosphate (PRPP) is a crucial substrate required for the biosynthesis of purines, providing the ribose-phosphate backbone necessary for the formation of purine nucleotides.

choices.text: Adequacy of cytotoxic drug therapy
Gender of an anatomically abnormal child
Malignant change at the squamocolumnar junction of the cervix
Estrogen level in the woman

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with irregular menstrual cycles. Her physician performs a vaginal cytology test to evaluate her endocrine status. The maturation index is determined from the vaginal smear. What does the maturation index on vaginal cytology evaluate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Estrogen level in the woman.

 

  • The maturation index in vaginal cytology is an essential tool used to evaluate the estrogen levels in a woman.
  • This index assesses the ratio of parabasal, intermediate, and superficial cells present in a vaginal smear. The prevalence of each cell type is influenced by estrogen levels, with an increase in superficial cells indicative of higher estrogen activity.
  • This assessment is crucial for diagnosing and managing hormonal imbalances that may lead to irregular menstrual cycles, as in the case of the woman presented.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Adequacy of cytotoxic drug therapy is incorrect. The maturation index is not used to monitor the effectiveness of cytotoxic drug therapies, which are primarily concerned with treating cancers and are monitored by different types of cell counts and imaging studies.
  • Option B. Gender of an anatomically abnormal child is incorrect. The maturation index does not provide information regarding the gender or anatomical abnormalities of children; it solely assesses the estrogenic effect on the vaginal epithelium of the woman being tested.
  • Option C. Malignant change at the squamocolumnar junction of the cervix is incorrect. While cytology tests such as the Pap smear are used to detect potential malignant changes in the cervix, the maturation index specifically measures estrogen effect and does not diagnose cervical malignancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The maturation index in vaginal cytology primarily evaluates the estrogen levels in a woman, crucial for diagnosing conditions associated with hormonal imbalances such as irregular menstrual cycles.

choices.text: Basal Cell Carcinoma

questions.text: A young boy is brought to the clinic with a large, dark pigmented lesion covering a significant portion of his face and scalp, as seen in the image. This congenital lesion has a slightly irregular surface and has been present since birth. His parents are concerned about potential complications associated with this finding. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with this type of lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malignant Melanoma

 

  • Malignant Melanoma can arise within large or giant congenital melanocytic nevi. Patients with this type of nevi have a higher risk of developing malignant melanoma within the lesion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cataract: It is not typically associated with congenital melanocytic nevi. While cataracts can be congenital, they are usually related to intrauterine infections, metabolic disorders, or genetic abnormalities.

 

Option B. Glaucoma: It can be congenital but is not related to the presence of melanocytic nevi. Glaucoma involves increased intraocular pressure and damage to the optic nerve.

 

Option D. Basal Cell Carcinoma: It is the most common form of skin cancer but is not typically associated with congenital melanocytic nevi and is exceedingly rare in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Giant congenital melanocytic nevi, such as the one depicted in the image, carry an increased risk for the development of malignant melanoma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with blurry vision and is diagnosed with against-the-rule astigmatism. Which of the following prescriptions is most appropriate for correcting against-the-rule astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) -1.25 at 90 degrees

 

  • Against-the-rule astigmatism occurs when the steepest curvature of the cornea is in the horizontal meridian (around 180 degrees).
  • To correct this, a cylindrical lens with its axis at 90 degrees (vertical) is used.
  • The prescription -1.25 at 90 degrees indicates a cylindrical correction needed to neutralize the steeper horizontal curvature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. -2.00: This indicates a spherical correction and does not address the cylindrical nature of astigmatism.

 

Option C. t2.51 +1.25 at 90 degrees: This is an incorrect notation and does not conform to standard ophthalmic prescription format.

 

Option D. +0.25 at 45 degrees: This indicates a very minor cylindrical correction in the oblique meridian, which is not typically used to correct significant astigmatism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Against-the-rule astigmatism is corrected by using a cylindrical lens with the axis at 90 degrees.
  • The prescription -1.25 at 90 degrees is appropriate for correcting this type of astigmatism.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is admitted to the hospital for an acute episode. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Barbiturates

 

  • Barbiturates are contraindicated in patients with acute intermittent porphyria because they can induce the activity of ALA synthase, leading to an accumulation of porphyrin precursors and exacerbation of porphyric symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Lithium: Lithium is not contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria and does not exacerbate the condition.

 

Option B. Ampicillin: Ampicillin is generally considered safe and does not typically provoke porphyric crises.

 

Option C. Propofol: Propofol is considered safe for use in patients with acute intermittent porphyria.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Barbiturates are contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria because they can induce the activity of ALA synthase, exacerbating porphyric symptoms.

questions.text: A pediatric patient in the ICU requires dextrose infusion for hypoglycemia management. Through a peripheral line, what is the maximum concentration of dextrose that can be safely administered?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 12.5%

 

  • This is the maximum concentration of dextrose that can be administered through a peripheral line to avoid complications such as phlebitis or thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum concentration of dextrose that can be safely administered through a peripheral line is 12.5% to avoid complications such as phlebitis or thrombosis.

questions.text: A forensic expert is analyzing a gunshot wound found on a deceased individual during an autopsy. The wound shows extensive tissue damage around the entry point, suggesting a specific range of fire. Based on the wound characteristics presented in the image, what is the most likely distance between the victim and the firearm?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2 m - 4 m

 

  • The image shows a central rat hole wound (wound with irregular margins resembling as bitten by a rat) with a few satellite wounds.
  • Rat hole wound occurs in gunshot wound after 30 cm
  • Satellite wounds occur after 2m.
  • After 4 m there is only individual pellet wounds and no central wound.

 

 

Since the image shows central rat hole wound as well as satellite wounds, the distance is 2m-4m. 

 

Educational Objective

 

Shotgun wound at varying distances

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, who recently underwent a laparotomy, presents with abdominal distention and absent bowel sounds without any accompanying colicky pain. Laboratory tests reveal an electrolyte imbalance. Which electrolyte abnormality is commonly associated with the development of this condition in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypokalemia

 

  • Paralytic ileus, characterized by decreased or absent intestinal motility without mechanical obstruction, can be caused by various factors including postoperative states, intra-abdominal infections, and certain electrolyte imbalances.
  • Hypokalemia, is a well-known risk factor for paralytic ileus.
  • Potassium plays a crucial role in muscle contractions and nerve impulse transmission; its deficiency can impair the motility of the gastrointestinal tract, leading to ileus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypernatremia: Incorrect - Hypernatremia primarily affects water balance and is less commonly associated with paralytic ileus.

 

Option B. Hypercalcemia: Incorrect - Hypercalcemia may cause constipation but is not typically linked with paralytic ileus.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: Incorrect - Hyperkalemia affects cardiac and neuromuscular functions but is not a common cause of paralytic ileus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypokalemia is a significant electrolyte disturbance that can lead to paralytic ileus by reducing the motility of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Monitoring and correction of electrolyte imbalances are essential in the postoperative management to prevent complications like ileus.

choices.text: Tibio-Calcaneal part of Deltoid Ligament
Tibio Talar part of Deltoid Ligament

questions.text: A 19-year-old basketball player sprained his right ankle after landing on an opponent's foot following a jump shot. His ankle inverted, causing severe pain and rapid swelling. He could not bear weight on the injured ankle. An X-ray showed no evidence of fractures in the lower limb bones. This is his first ankle injury. Which structure related to the ankle joint is most likely injured in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior Talo-Fibular Ligament

 

  • The most common ligament injured in an ankle sprain, particularly with an inversion mechanism (where the ankle rolls outward), is the Anterior Talo-Fibular Ligament (ATFL).
  • The ATFL is part of the lateral ligament complex of the ankle and is the weakest and most frequently injured ligament during such events.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tibio-Calcaneal part of Deltoid Ligament: This ligament is part of the medial ligament complex (deltoid ligament) and is less commonly injured in inversion sprains.

 

Option C. Capsular Ligament: This term is less specific and does not typically refer to a primary structure injured in an ankle sprain.

 

Option D. Tibio Talar part of Deltoid Ligament: This is another part of the deltoid ligament on the medial side of the ankle, which is not typically involved in inversion injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Anterior Talo-Fibular Ligament (ATFL) is the most commonly injured ligament in ankle sprains, especially when the injury mechanism involves inversion of the foot.

questions.text: A public health educator is developing a program aimed at fostering lasting behavior change in a community. The program emphasizes personal engagement and internalization of healthy behaviors. In which model of health education does this process of 'internalization' occur?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Motivation model

 

  • The motivation model of health education focuses on internalization, where individuals adopt health behaviors because they have personal motivation and have internalized the importance of these behaviors.
  • This model emphasizes personal engagement and the development of intrinsic motivation to sustain behavior change.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medical model: This model focuses on diagnosis and treatment of diseases, typically involving healthcare professionals providing interventions, with less emphasis on personal internalization of health behaviors.

 

Option B. Socio-environmental model: This model considers the broader social and environmental factors that influence health behaviors, focusing on external factors rather than internal personal motivation.

 

Option C. Service model: This model involves providing services to meet health needs, often through healthcare systems and community services, without necessarily focusing on personal internalization of health behaviors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The motivation model of health education emphasizes internalization, where individuals adopt and sustain health behaviors through personal motivation and engagement.
  • This model is essential for fostering lasting behavior change by developing intrinsic motivation. Understanding different health education models helps in designing effective public health programs.

choices.text: 34 cm
35 cm
36 cm
39 cm

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents for a routine check-up. At birth, the head circumference was 33 cm. What is the expected head circumference (HC) of this infant now?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 39 cm

 

  • The head circumference of an infant typically increases by approximately 2 cm per month during the first three months of life.
  • Thus, from an initial 33 cm, the expected HC at three months would be 39 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Head circumference increases by about 2 cm per month in the first three months of life. Monitoring HC is crucial for early detection of growth abnormalities.

choices.text: They provide better glycemic control
They induce insulin release at low glucose concentrations
These have lesser risk of precipitating hypoglycemia in normoglycemic patients

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is being considered for a change in therapy due to recurrent hypoglycemic episodes on his current sulfonylurea medication. The endocrinologist is considering switching him to a GLP-1 analogue. Which of the following is an advantage of GLP-1 analogues over sulfonylureas?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) These have lesser risk of precipitating hypoglycemia in normoglycemic patients
