  • GLP-1 analogues stimulate insulin secretion in a glucose-dependent manner, which means they enhance insulin release primarily when blood glucose levels are elevated.
  • This greatly reduces the risk of hypoglycemia compared to sulfonylureas, which can stimulate insulin release regardless of glucose levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They provide better glycemic control: Both GLP-1 analogues and sulfonylureas can achieve good glycemic control, but this benefit is not exclusive to GLP-1 analogues.

 

Option B. They induce insulin release at low glucose concentrations: GLP-1 analogues induce insulin release primarily at high glucose concentrations, not low, reducing the risk of hypoglycemia.

 

Option C. These are effective orally: GLP-1 analogues are typically administered via subcutaneous injection and are not effective orally. Oral formulations are under development but are not widely available.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • GLP-1 analogues offer the advantage of a lower risk of hypoglycemia compared to sulfonylureas due to their glucose-dependent mechanism of stimulating insulin release, making them a safer option for patients prone to hypoglycemic episodes.

choices.text: Normal external auditory canal with sensorineural hearing loss
Canal atresia with functional cochlea
Acute otitis media with effusion
Unilateral tinnitus without hearing loss

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents at a tertiary care center with complaints of hearing loss. Upon examination, the ENT specialist suggests considering a specific auditory device as shown in the image below. Given the patient's condition, which of the following indications is most likely for recommending this device?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Canal atresia with functional cochlea

 

  • For patients with canal atresia, where the external auditory canal is congenitally or acquiredly closed and not amenable to treatment, devices that bypass the external auditory canal and middle ear to stimulate the cochlea directly are indicated.
  • This device is suitable when the cochlea and auditory nerve are functional, making it ideal for the given patient's scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal external auditory canal with sensorineural hearing loss: Patients with a normal external auditory canal and sensorineural hearing loss typically benefit from conventional air-conduction hearing aids, not devices that bypass these structures.

 

Option C. Acute otitis media with effusion: In cases of acute otitis media with effusion, management usually involves medical treatment or conventional air-conduction aids post-resolution of the effusion, not bypass devices.

 

Option D. Unilateral tinnitus without hearing loss: Tinnitus without hearing loss does not typically require the use of hearing devices that bypass the middle and external ear, as their primary function is to aid in hearing, not to resolve tinnitus symptoms alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Devices that directly stimulate the cochlea are particularly beneficial in cases where the external auditory canal is obstructed or absent, and the middle ear cannot effectively conduct sound, such as in canal atresia with a functional cochlea.
  • These devices are contraindicated in normal auditory structures where traditional air-conduction devices can be effectively used.

choices.text: Middle Trunk of Brachial Plexus

questions.text: A 68-year-old male, chronic smoker, visited his physician with complaints of persistent cough, weight loss, and for the past few days, there was blood in his sputum. He also noticed an absence of sweating on the right side of his face. On examination, partial ptosis and constriction of the pupil were noted in the right eye. A PA view of a chest X-ray showed a lesion in the apex of the right lung. Which of the following structures does not form a posterior relation to the apex of the lung?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Middle Trunk of Brachial Plexus

 

  • The Middle Trunk of the Brachial Plexus originates from the C7 nerve root and lies more laterally and anteriorly, not forming a posterior relation to the apex of the lung.

 

Posterior relations of apex of the lung

 

• Neck of the 1st rib.

• Structures between apex & neck of 1st rib.

• From medial to lateral

1. Sympathetic chain (cervicothoracic ganglion)

2. Supreme intercostal vein

3. Superior intercostal artery

4. Ventral ramus of 1st thoracic nerve

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Highest Intercostal Vein: This structure is a posterior relation to the apex of the lung and drains into the brachiocephalic vein and is located posteriorly.

 

Option C. Sympathetic Chain:  This structure is a posterior relation to the apex of the lung and runs alongside of the vertebral column

 

Option D. Ventral Ramus of T1:  This structure is a posterior relation to the apex of the lung and exits the spinal cord thus contributing to the brachial plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The middle trunk of the brachial plexus does not form a posterior relation to the apex of the lung, whereas the highest intercostal vein, sympathetic chain, and ventral ramus of T1 do.

questions.text: Which of the following models explains that the active site is flexible and that the shape of the active site can be modified by the binding of the substrate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Induced fit model

 

  • The induced fit model describes how the active site of an enzyme is flexible and can change shape to better fit the substrate upon binding.
  • This model suggests that the enzyme and substrate undergo conformational changes to achieve an optimal fit, enhancing the catalytic efficiency of the enzyme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lock and key model: This model suggests that the enzyme's active site is rigid and has a specific shape that only fits a particular substrate, similar to a key fitting into a lock. It does not account for the flexibility of the active site.

 

Option C. Fisher’s Template theory: Fisher's Template theory is another name for the lock and key model, which does not include the concept of active site flexibility and induced fit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The induced fit model explains that the enzyme's active site is flexible and can change shape to accommodate the substrate, optimizing enzyme-substrate interactions.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought to the hospital with symptoms of fever, irritability, and a bulging fontanelle. The doctor suspects bacterial meningitis and orders a lumbar puncture. Which of the following is least likely to be a causative agent of bacterial meningitis in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Listeria

 

  • Listeria (Listeria monocytogenes) is less likely to cause bacterial meningitis in a 1-year-old child. It is more commonly associated with neonatal meningitis and infections in immunocompromised individuals or the elderly.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pneumococcus (Streptococcus pneumoniae): This is a leading cause of bacterial meningitis in infants and young children.

 

Option B. H. influenzae (Haemophilus influenzae type b): This used to be a common cause of bacterial meningitis in children under 5 years old, but its incidence has significantly decreased due to vaccination.

 

Option C. Neisseria meningitidis: This is also a frequent cause of bacterial meningitis in young children and infants.

 

Educational Objective

 

Age Wise cause of Meningitis

choices.text: Vitamin B12

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with severe muscle and joint pain, morning stiffness, and tingling in her lower limbs has normal ESR and TSH. Physical exam reveals muscular tenderness. What is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amitriptyline

 

  • Amitriptyline is used for fibromyalgia, characterized by widespread muscular pain and tenderness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 treats pernicious anemia.

 

Option B. Prednisone: Prednisone is for autoimmune diseases like SLE or PR.

 

Option D. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is for rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amitriptyline is used for fibromyalgia

questions.text: A public health engineer is designing a sanitary well for a rural community to ensure safe drinking water. What is the minimum depth required for the lining of a sanitary well?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20 feet

 

  • The minimum depth for the lining of a sanitary well is typically 20 feet.
  • This depth helps to ensure that the well is protected from surface contamination and provides a sufficient barrier to protect the water quality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sanitary Well Guidelines:

 

  • Location: <100 m radial distance; >15 m (50 feet) from source of contamination
  • Lining: >6 m (20 feet) depth; >60-90 cm (2-3 feet) above ground level
  • Parapet wall: >70-75 cms above ground
  • Platform: >1 m (3 feet) in all directions
  • Other guidelines: Pucca drain to a soakage pit/public drain beyond cone of filtration; cement concrete cover; robust hand pump to withdraw water

choices.text: Failure to produce hydrogen peroxide
Failure to produce hydroxy-halide radicals (HOCl⁻)

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a history of recurrent bacterial infections, including pneumonia and otitis media. Laboratory analysis of leukocytes reveals a deficiency in myeloperoxidase. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this child's increased susceptibility to infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Failure to produce hydroxy-halide radicals (HOCl⁻)

 

  • Myeloperoxidase (MPO) is an enzyme present in neutrophils that converts hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) and chloride ions (Cl⁻) into hypochlorous acid (HOCl) during the respiratory burst.
  • Hypochlorous acid is a potent antimicrobial agent that plays a critical role in killing bacteria and other pathogens.
  • A deficiency in MPO leads to the failure to produce HOCl, significantly impairing the neutrophils' ability to destroy ingested microbes, thus resulting in increased susceptibility to infections.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Defective neutrophil degranulation: While defective degranulation affects the release of antimicrobial substances from neutrophil granules, the specific deficiency in MPO is more directly related to the failure to produce HOCl.

 

Option B. Failure to produce hydrogen peroxide: Hydrogen peroxide is produced by the NADPH oxidase complex. A failure to produce hydrogen peroxide is associated with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), not MPO deficiency.

 

Option D. Decreased oxygen consumption after phagocytosis: This is indicative of chronic granulomatous disease, where the defect is in the NADPH oxidase complex leading to an inability to produce reactive oxygen species, which is distinct from MPO deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Myeloperoxidase deficiency leads to the failure to produce hypochlorous acid (HOCl), a crucial antimicrobial agent, resulting in increased susceptibility to infections.

questions.text: A newborn present with large areas of denuded skin, particularly in the diaper region, as shown in the image. What is the most likely genetic mutation associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) SLC39A4

 

  • This gene mutation is associated with Acrodermatitis Enteropathica, a condition characterized by zinc deficiency leading to dermatitis, alopecia, and diarrhea.
  • The clinical presentation of skin lesions, particularly in areas of friction, is typical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATP7A: Associated with Menkes disease, characterized by kinky hair, growth failure, and nervous system deterioration.

 

Option B. ATP7B: Linked to Wilson's disease, which involves copper accumulation, liver disease, and neurological symptoms.

 

Option D. ATP7C: Not commonly associated with the described clinical presentation or similar dermatological findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acrodermatitis Enteropathica is caused by mutations in the SLC39A4 gene, leading to zinc deficiency.
  • Symptoms include dermatitis, alopecia, and diarrhea.
  • Early diagnosis and zinc supplementation are crucial for management.

questions.text:
Which of the following staffing levels are correct standard indicators for evaluating health manpower?

 

  1. Doctor 1 per 3500 population
  2. ANM 1 per >1000 population
  3. Lab technician 1 per 10000 population
  4. Pharmacist 1 per 100000 population
  5. MPW 1 per 5000 population
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 5

 

Explanation:

 

  • 3) Lab technician 1 per 10000 populations: This ratio is a standard indicator for assessing the adequacy of laboratory technician staffing levels in a population. It ensures that there are enough lab technicians to support diagnostic services.
  • 5) MPW 1 per 5000 populations: This ratio is a standard indicator for Multi-Purpose Workers (MPW) staffing levels, ensuring sufficient public health workforce to meet the needs of the community. 1 per 5000 in plains and 1 per 3000 in hilly areas

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suggested norm for health personnel:

questions.text: An oral lesion biopsy sample from a 50-year-old female patient who had a recent history of use of broad-spectrum antibiotic, is taken for microscopic examination. The image from the biopsy specimen is shown below. Based on the findings, which of the following is the most likely etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Candida

 

  • Candida is the most likely etiological agent, as evidenced by the presence of budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae in the microscopic image.
  • Candida is commonly associated with oral thrush, particularly in immunocompromised patients or those on prolonged antibiotic therapy, which can disrupt normal flora and allow for Candida overgrowth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus: Typically presents as septate hyphae with acute angle branching, which is not seen in the image.

 

Option B. Rhizopus: Characterized by broad, non-septate hyphae with right angle branching, not consistent with the image.

 

Option D. Fusarium: Displays septate hyphae and conidia, which are not evident in the image provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Candida is a common cause of oral thrush, especially in immunocompromised patients or those on long-term antibiotics, and can be identified microscopically by the presence of budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with 4 months of fatigue, dry mouth, blurry vision, and a persistent non-productive cough. She has injected conjunctivae and swollen parotid glands. Oral examination shows dry mucous membranes and prominent tongue fissures. ANA and anti-Ro antibodies were positive. What is she at greatest risk for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

 

  • Patients with Sjogren's syndrome have an increased risk of developing non-Hodgkin lymphoma due to chronic inflammation and B-cell activation, especially in the parotid gland.
  • Most common histological subtype is Marginal zone lymphoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Sjogren's syndrome most commonly causes dRTA (FSGS is unlikely)

 

Option B. Lofgren syndrome: Lofgren syndrome is a subset of sarcoidosis, not typically seen with Sjogren's syndrome.

 

Option D. Retroperitoneal fibrosis: Retroperitoneal fibrosis is associated with IgG4-related disease, not primary Sjogren's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with Sjogren's syndrome have an increased risk of developing non-Hodgkin lymphoma

choices.text: It is a rare side effect of second-generation antipsychotics.
It typically resolves without intervention within a few days.
It is often effectively managed by a beta blocker.
It primarily affects the upper extremities.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man with a recent diagnosis of schizophrenia started treatment with haloperidol two weeks ago. He now reports a compelling need to move, particularly in his legs. He finds it difficult to sit still for even short periods and is constantly fidgeting and pacing. Which of the following statements about this condition is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is often effectively managed by a beta blocker

 

  • The symptoms described by the patient suggest he is experiencing akathisia, a common side effect of antipsychotic medications, particularly first-generation antipsychotics like haloperidol.
  • Akathisia is characterized by an inner restlessness along with objective, observable movements.
  • Beta blockers, such as propranolol, are frequently used and are effective in managing the symptoms of akathisia.
  • They help reduce the severity of the restlessness and the urge to move.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. It is a rare side effect of second-generation antipsychotics: Incorrect. Although akathisia is more commonly associated with first-generation antipsychotics but, it can also occur with second-generation antipsychotics, and it is not considered rare.

 

Option B. It typically resolves without intervention within a few days: Incorrect, akathisia often persists if the offending medication is continued without intervention.

 

Option D. It primarily affects the upper extremities: Incorrect, akathisia typically affects the whole body but is most notably problematic in the legs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute akathisia is the commonest side effect of antipsychotic medications.
  • It is characterized by an inner sense of restlessness along with objective, observable movements such as fidgeting of legs, pacing around, inability to sit or stand in one place for a long time.
  • Drug of choice is β-blockers such as propranolol.
  • Other treatment options include anticholinergics and benzodiazepines.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with a GABRA1 gene mutation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy

 

  • This condition is characterized by myoclonic jerks, often occurring in the morning, and generalized tonic-clonic seizures. It is associated with mutations in the GABRA1 gene, which affects the function of GABA receptors in the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Menke disease: A genetic disorder affecting copper levels in the body, leading to developmental delays and other systemic symptoms. It is not related to GABRA1 mutations.

 

Option B. Wilson disease: A disorder of copper metabolism due to mutations in the ATP7B gene, leading to copper accumulation in the liver and brain, not associated with GABRA1 mutations.

 

Option C. Achondroplasia: A genetic disorder affecting bone growth, caused by mutations in the FGFR3 gene, not linked to GABRA1 mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, associated with GABRA1 gene mutations, presents with myoclonic jerks and generalized tonic-clonic seizures, typically beginning in adolescence.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of fever, cough, blood-tinged sputum, dry skin, and fatigue. Examination reveals crackles in the left lung, and X-ray is shown. Which stain is used to identify the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ziehl-Neelsen stain

 

  • Chest X ray shows reticulonodular opacities in the left upper and middle lung zones with a cavity in the left upper lobe. The clinical picture and X-ray is suggestive of TB.
  • Ziehl-Neelsen stain is used to visualize Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the likely cause given the patient's symptoms and lung cavitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromogranin stain: Chromogranin stain is for neuroendocrine tumors.

 

Option B. Giemsa stain: Giemsa stain visualizes certain bacteria and parasites.

 

Option C. India ink stain: India ink stain identifies Cryptococcus species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ziehl-Neelsen stain is used to visualize Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child presents with repeated episodes of gastrointestinal problems and listlessness over the past few weeks. He is brought to the pediatric OPD for further evaluation. Laboratory tests reveal microcytic, hypochromic anemia and elevated blood lead levels. Which of the following enzymes will have higher-than-normal activity in the liver in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) δ-Aminolevulinic acid synthase

 

  • Lead poisoning inhibits key enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway, specifically δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase and ferrochelatase.
  • This inhibition leads to the accumulation of δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA), which in turn stimulates the activity of δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase (ALAS), the first enzyme in the heme synthesis pathway.
  • Increased ALAS activity results from feedback regulation as the body attempts to compensate for the blockade in heme production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bilirubin UDP-glucuronosyltransferase: This enzyme is involved in bilirubin metabolism, converting unconjugated bilirubin to conjugated bilirubin. Its activity is not directly affected by lead poisoning.

 

Option C. Ferrochelatase: Lead poisoning inhibits ferrochelatase, leading to decreased enzyme activity, not increased.

 

Option D. Heme oxygenase: This enzyme breaks down heme into biliverdin, iron, and carbon monoxide. Its activity is not increased as a direct consequence of lead poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lead poisoning inhibits enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway, leading to increased activity of δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase due to feedback regulation.

questions.text: A 70 kg construction worker with a heavy workload needs to ensure his daily caloric intake meets his energy requirements. He consumes 56 grams of protein, 275 grams of carbohydrates, and 60 grams of fats daily. Based on this diet, assess and comment on his calories consumption.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Less calories

 

To determine if the construction worker is consuming adequate calories, we need to compare his actual caloric intake to his total energy requirements based on his activity level.

 

Energy requirements in kcal/kg/day for a heavy worker: 58 kcal/kg/day

 

Total energy requirement for the worker: 70 kg×58 kcal/kg/day=4060 kcal/day

 

Calculating actual caloric intake:

 

  • Protein: 56 grams×4.2 kcal/gram=235.2 kcal
  • Carbohydrates: 275 grams×4.1 kcal/gram=1127.5 kcal
  • Lipids: 60 grams×9 kcal/gram=540 kcal

 

Total caloric intake: 235.2 kcal (protein)+1127.5 kcal (carbohydrates)+540 kcal (lipids)=1902.7 kcal

 

The worker's actual caloric intake is approximately 1903 kcal/day, which is significantly less than his required intake of 3470 kcal/day (≈3500) for a heavy worker.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recommended daily energy and protein intake (New Guidelines 2021):

questions.text: A study was conducted with three different sample sizes, and the results are shown in the graph. Based on the given normal distributions, what is the order for the margin of error?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 > 2 > 1

 

  • The margin of error decreases as the sample size increases. In the graph, sample 3 (n=600) has the widest distribution, indicating the largest margin of error. Sample 2 (n=800) has a narrower distribution, and sample 1 (n=1000) has the narrowest distribution, indicating the smallest margin of error.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Margin of Error: Amount of random sampling error in a survey’s results
  • Margin of error is simply the “radius” (or half the width) of a confidence interval
  • Margin of error = Critical value × Standard error
  • Standard error is inversely related to sample size (SE mean = SD/√Sample size)
  • Margin of error is inversely related to the Sample size.

questions.text: In a forensic investigation at a rural health center, a medical officer is called to evaluate the scene where an elderly man was found deceased with no apparent injuries. During the examination, the officer discovers a vial near the body containing a gelatinous substance with a distinct 'chicken fat' appearance, which had been drawn from the patient's IV line after death was confirmed. What type of thrombus is indicated by this appearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postmortem thrombus

 

  • The 'chicken fat' appearance is characteristic of postmortem clots, which are gelatinous and loosely cohesive, typically forming after death.
  • This appearance contrasts sharply with antemortem thrombi, which are denser and adhere to the vessel walls, indicating they formed due to circulatory disturbances or injuries while the heart was still functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antemortem thrombus - These thrombi form before death and are usually more structured and solid, indicative of ongoing pathological processes.

 

Option C. Gunshot injury - Gunshot injuries may lead to hemorrhage and rapid clotting, but the specific 'chicken fat' appearance is indicative of the natural postmortem clotting process rather than trauma-related clot formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Two types of Postmortem thrombus:

 

  • Red currant jelly: Occurs if the blood clots rapidly. RBCs do not have time to settle down hence RBCs are distributed in whole clot and hence the clot is uniformly dark red
  • Chicken fat: Occurs if the clotting is gradual. RBCs settle down and two different layers are seen:
  • Upper layer: A pale layer of serum and fibrin
  • Lower layer: Red (like red current layer)

choices.text: Anterior dislocation of hip
Posterior dislocation of hip
Central dislocation of hip

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior dislocation of hip

 

  • Posterior dislocation of the hip occurs when the femoral head is pushed backward out of the acetabulum.
  • This can occur due to high-energy trauma, such as a car accident or a fall from a height.
  • The broken Shenton’s line is a characteristic finding in posterior dislocation of the hip.
  • In this type of dislocation, the femoral head is displaced posteriorly, disrupting the smooth curve formed by the Shenton’s line.
  • Therefore, the presence of a broken Shenton’s line supports the diagnosis of posterior dislocation of the hip, making this the likely answer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior Dislocation of Hip: Anterior dislocation of the hip occurs when the femoral head is forced out of the acetabulum in a forward direction. This can happen due to a traumatic event, such as a fall or motor vehicle accident. In anterior dislocation, the femoral head would appear displaced anteriorly from its normal position in the acetabulum. The broken Shenton’s line, which is typically seen as a smooth arc formed by the inferior border of the femoral neck and the superior border of the obturator foramen on radiographs, would not be disrupted in anterior dislocation. Therefore, anterior dislocation is not the likely diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Central Dislocation of Hip: Central dislocation of the hip is a term used to describe a dislocation where the femoral head is neither anteriorly nor posteriorly displaced but remains centred within the acetabulum. This term is less commonly used in clinical practice. The presence of a broken Shenton’s line would not be expected in a central dislocation, as the femoral head remains within the acetabulum and does not disrupt the normal contour of the hip joint on radiographs.

 

 

Option D. Intertrochanteric Fracture of Femur: Intertrochanteric fracture of the femur is a common type of hip fracture that occurs in the region between the greater and lesser trochanters of the femur. It is often associated with falls in elderly individuals or high-energy trauma in younger patients. While an intertrochanteric fracture can cause disruption of the Shenton’s line, it typically presents as a fracture line extending across the proximal femur rather than as displacement of the femoral head from the acetabulum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows posterior dislocation of the hip because the Shenton’s line is broken in this injury.
  • The line remains intact in other types of hip dislocation and intertrochanteric fractures.

choices.text: Opening of plaster is sufficient

questions.text: A young male patient sustained right tibial shaft fracture following RTA. The patient’s right leg was immobilized with a plaster cast. This patient now presents to the emergency with severe pain in the leg. On examination, the distal pulses are absent; on passive stretching, the pain increases; and on opening the plaster, the right leg appears edematous and numerous blisters are seen. Considering the suspected diagnosis, what would be the most appropriate management in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fasciotomy

 

  • Fasciotomy involves surgically releasing the fascial compartments surrounding the affected limb to relieve compartment syndrome.
  • It is the definitive treatment for acute compartment syndrome.
  • Given the patient's severe pain, absent distal pulses, passive stretch exacerbating pain, and the presence of edema and blisters, these are classic signs and symptoms of acute compartment syndrome.
  • Fasciotomy is the most appropriate management to prevent irreversible ischemic damage to the muscles and nerves of the leg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Elevation of Limb: Elevation of the limb above heart level can help reduce swelling and improve venous return. It is a supportive measure but not sufficient as definitive treatment for acute compartment syndrome. While limb elevation can be helpful in reducing edema, it does not address the underlying issue of increased pressure within the compartments causing compartment syndrome. In this case, more definitive management with fasciotomy is necessary.

 

Option C. Opening of plaster is sufficient: This option suggests that simply opening the plaster cast would be enough to relieve the symptoms. However, in cases of acute compartment syndrome, the underlying issue is increased pressure within the fascial compartments, which cannot be adequately relieved by only opening the plaster. Acute compartment syndrome requires urgent surgical intervention with fasciotomy to prevent irreversible tissue damage. Simply opening the plaster cast would not address the underlying pathophysiology and could lead to worsening of symptoms.

 

Option D. Closed Reduction: Closed reduction involves manipulating fractured bone fragments back into their normal alignment without surgery. While closed reduction may be indicated for some fractures, it is not the appropriate management for acute compartment syndrome. Acute compartment syndrome is a medical emergency that requires prompt recognition and treatment with fasciotomy to prevent tissue necrosis. Closed reduction alone would not address the underlying compartmental pressure causing the symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given description of the patient’s condition suggests compartment syndrome following traumatic tibial shaft fracture.
  • The most appropriate line of management of the compartment syndrome is the fasciotomy to release the compartment pressure.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents to your clinic with mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and a family history of medullary thyroid cancer. He is concerned about his risk of developing additional associated conditions. Which of the following is commonly associated with his likely diagnosis of MEN 2B syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pheochromocytoma

 

  • Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B) syndrome is characterized by medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuromas, and a marfanoid body habitus.
  • Pheochromocytomas are seen in this syndrome and can present with hypertension, palpitations, and episodic sweating.
  • The presence of mucosal neuromas and a family history of medullary thyroid cancer further supports the diagnosis of MEN 2B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parathyroid hyperplasia: Incorrect. Parathyroid involvement is not a feature of MEN 2B; it is more commonly seen in MEN 1 and MEN 2A.

 

Option C. Gastric carcinoid tumor: Incorrect. While patients with MEN 1 may develop carcinoid tumors, they are not a feature of MEN 2B.

 

Option D. Insulinoma: Incorrect. Insulinomas are associated with MEN 1, not MEN 2B.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • MEN 2B syndrome should be considered in patients with mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and a family history of medullary thyroid cancer.
  • The syndrome commonly includes medullary thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma but not parathyroid hyperplasia or pancreatic tumors seen in MEN 1.

 

Early identification and management of MEN 2B can significantly influence outcomes due to the aggressive nature of medullary thyroid carcinoma and potential complications from pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man experiences nausea, fatigue, and dyspnea at high altitude. He attempts to climb higher but feels worse. What condition is he most at risk for if he continues climbing immediately?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ataxia

 

  • High-altitude cerebral edema (HACE), a serious complication of acute mountain sickness, can cause ataxia, confusion, and coma if the patient continues to ascend.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased serum bicarbonate: Increased serum bicarbonate is a compensation for respiratory acidosis, not seen here.

 

Option C. Pleural effusions: Pleural effusions are related to other conditions like infections or organ failures.

 

Option D. Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax can occur in chronic lung diseases or trauma, not typically due to high altitude.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High-altitude cerebral edema (HACE), a serious complication of acute mountain sickness, can cause ataxia, confusion, and coma if the patient continues to ascend.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man has a 6-kg weight loss and nausea for the past 7 months without vomiting or diarrhea. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a 6-cm area of irregular, pale fundic mucosa and loss of rugal folds. Helicobacter pylori organisms are identified in mucus overlying adjacent mucosa. After antibiotic therapy for H. pylori, a repeat biopsy shows resolution of the infiltrate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue tumor

 

  • The resolution of the lymphoid infiltrate after antibiotic therapy for Helicobacter pylori indicates a mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) tumor.
  • MALT lymphomas are often associated with chronic H. pylori infection, and eradication of the infection can lead to tumor regression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic gastritis: While chronic gastritis can be associated with H. pylori, it does not explain the lymphoid infiltrate and resolution after treatment.

 

Option B. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma: This type of lymphoma would not typically resolve with antibiotic therapy for H. pylori.

 

Option C. Autoimmune gastritis: This condition is characterized by autoantibodies against parietal cells, not by H. pylori infection or lymphoid infiltrates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) tumors are associated with H. pylori infection and can regress after eradication of the bacteria.

questions.text: A biopsy specimen is obtained from a patient suspected of having a fungal infection. To identify potential fungal elements within the biopsy specimen, which stain would be most appropriate to use first?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gomori’s methenamine silver stain

 

  • Gomori’s methenamine silver stain is one of the most effective stains for identifying fungal elements in tissue specimens.
  • It stains fungal cell walls black, making it easier to visualize fungal hyphae and yeast forms against the tissue background.

 

Figure: Cysts of P.jerovicii on Gomori Methamine stain

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain: This stain can also be used to identify fungi, as it stains polysaccharides in fungal cell walls a magenta color. However, it is generally considered less specific and less sensitive than Gomori’s methenamine silver stain.

 

Option B. Von Kossa stain: This is used to identify calcium deposits in tissues, not fungi.

 

Option C. Mucicarmine stain: This stain is specific for mucin and can highlight the capsule of Cryptococcus species, but it is not generally used as the first choice for broad fungal identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gomori’s methenamine silver stain is the most appropriate and effective stain for the initial identification of fungal elements in a biopsy specimen due to its high sensitivity and specificity for fungal cell walls.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of a previous lower segment cesarean section is being evaluated for induction of labor. Which of the following methods for induction of labor should not be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prostaglandin tablet

 

  • In patients with a previous lower segment cesarean section, the use of prostaglandins (especially in tablet form) for cervical ripening and induction of labor is generally contraindicated due to the increased risk of uterine rupture.
  • Prostaglandins can cause strong uterine contractions, which can lead to rupture of the uterine scar from the previous cesarean section.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prostaglandin gel: While prostaglandin gel is also generally avoided in these patients due to similar risks, it is often less commonly referenced in contraindications compared to tablets. However, the answer focuses on the most widely recognized risk.

 

Option B. Stripping of the membrane: This method is considered relatively safe for induction of labor in patients with a previous lower segment cesarean section as it is less likely to cause strong uterine contractions.

 

Option C. Oxytocin drip: Oxytocin can be used with caution under close monitoring in patients with a previous cesarean section. It is preferred over prostaglandins due to the ability to control and titrate the dosage to avoid hyperstimulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prostaglandin tablets should not be used for induction of labor in patients with a previous lower segment cesarean section due to the increased risk of uterine rupture.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is being investigated for a suspected endocrine disorder. Understanding the role of steroid receptors in the molecular mechanisms of steroid hormone action is crucial for her diagnosis. When examining the molecular mechanisms involved in steroid hormone action, which of the following components would steroid receptors NOT typically bind to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transcription Repressors

 

  • Steroid receptors are intracellular proteins that bind to steroid hormones and then act as transcription factors to regulate gene expression.
  • These receptors typically bind to specific DNA sequences known as steroid response elements (SREs) within the promoter regions of target genes.
  • They can also interact with transcription mediators to facilitate the assembly of the transcriptional machinery and enhance transcriptional activity.
  • However, steroid receptors do not typically bind directly to transcription repressors; instead, they may recruit corepressors indirectly through other protein interactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transcription Mediators: Steroid receptors can interact with transcription mediators, which help facilitate the assembly and function of the transcriptional machinery at the promoter region, enhancing gene transcription.

 

Option B. Transcription Promoters: Steroid receptors can influence transcription promoters indirectly by binding to steroid response elements within the promoter regions, thereby regulating the transcription of target genes.

 

Option D. Steroid Response Elements: Steroid response elements are specific DNA sequences that steroid receptors directly bind to, allowing them to regulate the transcription of target genes.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Steroid receptors do not typically bind directly to transcription repressors. Instead, they bind to steroid response elements within the promoter regions and can interact with transcription mediators to regulate gene expression.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a history of prolonged fever, headache, and abdominal discomfort. The clinician suspects typhoid fever and orders a Widal test as part of the diagnostic workup. What is the principle behind the Widal test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Agglutination

 

  • Agglutination is the principle behind the Widal test. The Widal test is a serological assay that detects agglutinating antibodies against the O (somatic) and H (flagellar) antigens of Salmonella typhi and Salmonella paratyphi in a patient's serum.
  • When the patient’s serum, containing antibodies, is mixed with standardized antigen suspensions, visible agglutination (clumping) indicates the presence of antibodies against Salmonella.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Slide flocculation test: This involves the formation of floccules (clumps) and is used for different diagnostic tests, such as the VDRL test for syphilis, but it is not the principle behind the Widal test.

 

Option B. Precipitation: This involves the formation of a solid from a solution during a chemical reaction and is not the principle behind the Widal test.

 

Option D. Complement fixation: This involves the binding of complement to antigen-antibody complexes and is used in different serological tests, but it is not used in the Widal test.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Drug A: Aspirin, Drug B: Abciximab, Drug C: Clopidogrel
Drug A: Ticagrelor, Drug B: Eptifibatide, Drug C: Prasugrel
Drug A: Dipyridamole, Drug B: Tirofiban, Drug C: Ticlopidine
Drug A: Aspirin, Drug B: Dipyridamole, Drug C: Eptifibatide

questions.text: Based on the figure provided, identify these drugs as Drug A, Drug B, and Drug C
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Drug A: Aspirin, Drug B: Abciximab, Drug C: Clopidogrel

 

  • Drug A: Aspirin: Aspirin inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX), decreasing the synthesis of thromboxane A2 (TxA2), a promoter of platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction. This is shown as the inhibition of the TxA2 pathway in the figure.
  • Drug B: Abciximab: Abciximab is a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor that prevents fibrinogen binding and cross-linking of platelets, thereby inhibiting platelet aggregation. This is depicted as the blockage of the GPIIb/IIIa receptor in the figure.
  • Drug C: Clopidogrel: Clopidogrel is an ADP receptor (P2Y12) antagonist. It inhibits the binding of ADP to its platelet receptor, preventing ADP-mediated activation of the GPIIb/IIIa complex. This is illustrated as the inhibition of the ADP pathway in the figure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Drug A: Ticagrelor, Drug B: Eptifibatide, Drug C: Prasugrel: While Ticagrelor and Prasugrel are ADP receptor antagonists and Eptifibatide is a GPIIb/IIIa inhibitor, this combination does not match the figure.

 

Option C. Drug A: Dipyridamole, Drug B: Tirofiban, Drug C: Ticlopidine: Dipyridamole acts differently by inhibiting phosphodiesterase, Tirofiban is a GPIIb/IIIa inhibitor, and Ticlopidine is an ADP receptor antagonist, but this combination does not align with the figure.

 

Option D. Drug A: Aspirin, Drug B: Dipyridamole, Drug C: Eptifibatide: Dipyridamole does not fit the GPIIb/IIIa inhibition or ADP receptor antagonism shown in the figure.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Aspirin, Abciximab, and Clopidogrel are antiplatelet agents that inhibit platelet aggregation through different mechanisms: Aspirin inhibits thromboxane A2 synthesis, Abciximab blocks GPIIb/IIIa receptors, and Clopidogrel antagonizes ADP receptors.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is scheduled for central venous catheter placement. The anesthesiologist discusses the landmarks used to identify the internal jugular vein for cannulation. Which of the following surface landmarks is used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sedillot’s triangle

 

  • Sedillot’s triangle, also known as the lesser supraclavicular fossa, is an anatomical landmark used to locate the internal jugular vein for cannulation.
  • It is bounded by the clavicle inferiorly, the sternal head of the sternocleidomastoid muscle medially, and the clavicular head of the sternocleidomastoid muscle laterally.
  • This triangle is used as a guide to access the internal jugular vein because it provides a relatively superficial and direct route to the vein.

 

 

Stemocleidomastoid muscle: SM: stemal head; CM: Cleidal head

 

Red dot: triangle of sedillot CL: clavicle

 

Triangle of Sedillot:

 

  • Medially -sternal head of sternocleidomastoid
  • Laterally-clavicular head of sternocleidomastoid
  • Base-Clavicle
  • Content -Internal jugular vein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subclavian triangle: This is not the primary landmark for internal jugular vein cannulation. It is more relevant for accessing the subclavian vein.

 

Option C. Scaleno Vertebral triangle: This is not typically used for venous cannulation but rather for identifying structures in the neck related to the scalene muscles and vertebrae.

 

Option D. Suboccipital triangle: This triangle is located at the posterior aspect of the neck and is not relevant for internal jugular vein cannulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sedillot’s triangle (lesser supraclavicular fossa) is the surface landmark used for cannulating the internal jugular vein, providing a direct and superficial route for venous access.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic liver disease presents to the clinic with symptoms suggestive of portal hypertension. The physician suspects a change in portal venous flow and needs to determine the best investigation to detect hepatofugal flow. What is the best investigation to detect a change in portal venous flow to hepatofugal flow?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Color Doppler

 

  • Color Doppler ultrasound is the best investigation to detect changes in portal venous flow, including the transition to hepatofugal (away from the liver) flow.
  • It provides real-time visualization of blood flow direction and velocity within the portal vein, making it an essential tool for diagnosing and monitoring portal hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B-mode USG: B-mode ultrasound provides grayscale imaging of the liver and blood vessels, which is useful for assessing liver structure and detecting masses or cirrhosis but does not provide information about blood flow direction or velocity.

 

Option C. M-Mode USG: M-Mode ultrasound is primarily used for detailed motion analysis of moving structures, such as heart valves, but it is not used for assessing blood flow in vessels.

 

Option D. A-Mode USG: A-Mode ultrasound provides a one-dimensional representation of structures based on the amplitude of reflected sound waves. It is not suitable for evaluating blood flow or direction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Color Doppler ultrasound is the best investigation to detect changes in portal venous flow, including the detection of hepatofugal flow, which is an early sign of portal hypertension.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presents with altered sensorium, convulsions, ascites, and jaundice. He also has friable and tufted hair. An ultrasound of the abdomen shows hepatomegaly, and blood tests reveal elevated ammonia levels and high argininosuccinate in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Which enzyme is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Argininosuccinate lyase

 

  • Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency leads to the accumulation of argininosuccinate in the blood and CSF, as this enzyme is responsible for cleaving argininosuccinate into arginine and fumarate in the urea cycle.
  • The deficiency causes elevated ammonia levels, leading to symptoms of hyperammonemia such as CNS dysfunction, altered sensorium, convulsions, and hepatomegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arginase: Arginase deficiency results in the accumulation of arginine and typically presents with spasticity, growth retardation, and developmental delay, but not with elevated argininosuccinate or ammonia in the blood and CSF.

 

Option C. Argininosuccinate synthetase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to citrullinemia type I, characterized by elevated citrulline levels, not argininosuccinate. Symptoms include hyperammonemia and associated neurological disturbances.

 

Option D. Fumarase: Fumarase deficiency, a rare metabolic disorder, leads to severe neurological impairment, but it does not cause elevated argininosuccinate or ammonia levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency causes elevated levels of argininosuccinate and ammonia, leading to CNS dysfunction and hepatomegaly.

choices.text: Myometrial excision for placental nonseparation

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman diagnosed with placenta percreta is scheduled for the triple P procedure. Which of the following is not involved in the triple P procedure for placenta percreta?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peripartum hysterectomy

 

  • The triple P procedure is a conservative surgical approach used in the management of placenta percreta, designed to control bleeding and preserve the uterus. The steps involved in the triple P procedure are:
  1. Placental localization using USG (Ultrasound): This step involves identifying the location and extent of placental invasion to plan the surgical approach.
  2. Myometrial excision for placental nonseparation: This step involves excising the area of the myometrium where the placenta is adherent and cannot be separated without causing significant bleeding.
  3. Pelvic devascularization: This step involves controlling blood flow to the pelvic organs to reduce bleeding during and after the procedure.
  • Peripartum hysterectomy is not part of the triple P procedure. It is a more radical approach involving the removal of the uterus and is typically reserved for cases where conservative measures fail or are not appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placental localization using USG: This is a crucial step in the triple P procedure for mapping the extent of placental invasion.

 

Option B. Myometrial excision for placental nonseparation: This is an essential step in the procedure to manage areas where the placenta cannot be separated from the uterus.

 

Option C. Pelvic devascularization: This step is important for controlling hemorrhage by reducing blood flow to the pelvic region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The triple P procedure for placenta percreta involves placental localization using ultrasound, myometrial excision for placental nonseparation, and pelvic devascularization.
  • Peripartum hysterectomy is not part of this procedure and is considered a more radical surgical option.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with marked abdominal pain, diffuse abdominal tenderness, and decreased bowel sounds. Laboratory studies show a serum creatinine level of 4.4 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen level of 42 mg/dL. Renal biopsy reveals focal fibrinoid necrosis of small arteries and arterioles with intravascular microthrombi and scattered neutrophils. Which of the following laboratory findings would most likely be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased complement C3

 

  • The clinical and histological findings suggest systemic vasculitis, such as polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), which is often associated with decreased levels of complement due to consumption during the inflammatory process.
  • The presence of focal fibrinoid necrosis and intravascular microthrombi with scattered neutrophils is typical for vasculitis.
  • Decreased complement C3 levels indicate active consumption in immune complex-mediated damage.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Neutropenia: Not associated with vasculitis characterized by fibrinoid necrosis.

 

Option C. Increased IgE: Seen in allergic conditions and parasitic infections, not vasculitis.

 

Option D. CD4+ lymphocytosis: Associated with chronic infections like HIV, not acute vasculitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Decreased complement C3 levels are indicative of immune complex-mediated vasculitis, such as polyarteritis nodosa, characterized by focal fibrinoid necrosis and microthrombi in small arteries and arterioles.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes and breast cancer treated with tamoxifen presents with acute chest pain and syncope. She has no palpable pulses and the ECG strip is shown. CPR is initiated. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV epinephrine therapy

 

  • The clinical picture is suggestive of a Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA).
  • Apart from CPR, epinephrine is the first-line treatment for PEA arrest to support circulation and improve perfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV amiodarone therapy: Amiodarone is for ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.

 

Option C. Hypothermia therapy: Hypothermia therapy is for post-cardiac arrest care.

 

Option D. Defibrillation: Defibrillation is for shockable rhythms like ventricular fibrillation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epinephrine is the first-line treatment for PEA arrest.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman is undergoing routine prenatal screening. Her blood test results show an elevated marker indicating a risk for neural tube defects (NTDs) in the fetus. Which of the following is the best marker for diagnosing NTDs?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acetylcholinesterase

 

  • Acetylcholinesterase is the most specific marker for neural tube defects when found in amniotic fluid, as it is released from fetal neural tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudocholinesterase: Not used for diagnosing NTDs.

 

Option C. Alpha-fetoprotein: Elevated in NTDs but not as specific as acetylcholinesterase.

 

Option D. Beta hCG: Elevated in conditions like pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acetylcholinesterase is the most specific marker for neural tube defects when found in amniotic fluid.

choices.text: Direct oxytocin injection after delivery of shoulder
Immediate cutting and cord clamping
Controlled and sustained cord traction

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the active management of the third stage of labor to prevent PPH?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate cutting and cord clamping

 

  • The active management of the third stage of labor is a set of practices intended to prevent postpartum hemorrhage.
  • It typically includes the administration of a uterotonic drug, early cord clamping and cutting, and controlled cord traction.
  • Immediate cord clamping is not recommended as part of the active management of the third stage of labor.
  • Delayed cord clamping (waiting at least 1–3 minutes after birth) is preferred as it allows for additional blood to transfer from the placenta to the newborn, which can improve the newborn’s iron stores and hemoglobin levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct oxytocin injection after delivery of shoulder: Oxytocin is commonly administered as a uterotonic to stimulate uterine contractions and prevent PPH.

 

Option C. Prophylactic misoprostol: Misoprostol is another uterotonic agent that can be used prophylactically to prevent PPH, especially where oxytocin is not available or contraindicated.

 

Option D. Controlled and sustained cord traction: Controlled cord traction is a technique used to assist with the delivery of the placenta and reduce the risk of retained placenta, which can lead to PPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The active management of the third stage of labor to prevent postpartum hemorrhage includes the administration of uterotonic drugs and controlled cord traction but does not include immediate cord clamping and cutting.

questions.text: A 3-week-old neonate presents with increasing jaundice, hepatomegaly, and pale stools. A liver biopsy reveals marked proliferation of bile ducts, portal tract edema and fibrosis, and extensive intrahepatic and canalicular bile stasis. The infant's jaundice worsens progressively, and the infant dies of liver failure at 9 months of age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Biliary atresia

 

  • Biliary atresia is a condition in which the bile ducts inside or outside the liver are abnormally narrow, blocked, or absent.
  • This leads to bile buildup in the liver, causing progressive liver damage.
  • The clinical presentation includes jaundice, hepatomegaly, and acholic (pale) stools.
  • The liver biopsy findings of bile duct proliferation, portal tract edema, fibrosis, and intrahepatic bile stasis are characteristic of biliary atresia.
  • If untreated, biliary atresia leads to worsening jaundice and liver failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Presents with a range of symptoms including neurological deficits and chorioretinitis, but does not match the liver pathology described here.

 

Option B. α1-Antitrypsin deficiency: Can cause neonatal hepatitis and cholestasis but typically does not present with the severe bile duct proliferation and fibrosis seen in biliary atresia.

 

Option D. Choledochal cyst: Causes cystic dilatation of the bile ducts but is less likely to cause the described severe liver pathology and progression to liver failure seen in biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Biliary atresia is characterized by progressive jaundice, hepatomegaly, and acholic stools in neonates, with liver biopsy showing bile duct proliferation, fibrosis, and bile stasis, leading to liver failure if untreated.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male diagnosed with abetalipoproteinemia presents with abnormal blood picture, including acanthocytes. He also exhibits hyperkeratosis, acrodermatitis, and hypercholesterolemia. The abnormal red cell morphology is most likely due to malabsorption of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Linoleic acid

 

  • Abetalipoproteinemia is a condition characterized by the inability to properly absorb and transport certain lipids, leading to deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins and essential fatty acids.
  • Linoleic acid, an essential fatty acid, is crucial for maintaining the structural integrity and function of cell membranes.
  • Its deficiency can lead to the formation of acanthocytes, abnormal red blood cells with spiky projections, due to disrupted lipid composition of the cell membrane.
  • Additionally, deficiency in essential fatty acids can contribute to skin conditions like hyperkeratosis and acrodermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ascorbic acid: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums and joint pain, but it does not typically cause acanthocytes or the skin conditions seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Folic acid: Folic acid deficiency results in megaloblastic anemia, not acanthocytosis. It is crucial for DNA synthesis and repair, but its deficiency does not align with the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. Arachidonic acid: While arachidonic acid is important for cell membrane function and is a precursor for prostaglandins, its deficiency is less commonly associated with acanthocytes. Linoleic acid deficiency is more directly implicated in the pathophysiology of abetalipoproteinemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abetalipoproteinemia leads to malabsorption of essential fatty acids like linoleic acid, resulting in abnormal red cell morphology (acanthocytes) and skin conditions such as hyperkeratosis and acrodermatitis.

choices.text: Hodgkin lymphoma, lymphocyte depletion type

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents with fatigue, weight loss, and splenomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated white blood cell count. Cytogenetic analysis shows the BCR-ABL fusion gene resulting from the t(9;22)(q34;q11) translocation. Which condition is most likely associated with this genetic finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic myelogenous leukemia

 

  • The BCR-ABL fusion gene, resulting from the t(9;22)(q34;q11) translocation, is known as the Philadelphia chromosome and is characteristic of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).
  • This fusion gene encodes an abnormal tyrosine kinase that leads to uncontrolled cell proliferation, a hallmark of CML.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Acute promyelocytic leukemia: This condition is associated with the t(15;17) translocation involving the PML-RARA gene, not BCR-ABL.

 

Option B. Follicular lymphoma: This is typically associated with the t(14;18) translocation involving the BCL2 gene, not BCR-ABL.

 

Option D. Hodgkin lymphoma, lymphocyte depletion type: This is not associated with the BCR-ABL fusion gene or the t(9;22) translocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The BCR-ABL fusion gene from the t(9;22) translocation is specifically associated with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), leading to uncontrolled proliferation of leukemic cells.

choices.text: Serum iron level

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with psychiatric symptoms, including irritability and personality changes. On physical examination, the lens of his eye is shown below. Based on this finding, what test should be done next to diagnose the condition/disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serum ceruloplasmin

 

  • The image shows a sun-flower cataract in the lens of the eye. Also visible is Kayser-Fleischer ring, which is a golden-brown ring around the cornea, indicative of Wilson's disease.
  • Wilson's disease is a disorder of copper metabolism, and serum ceruloplasmin levels are typically low in this condition.
  • Confirmatory tests include 24-hour urinary copper excretion and liver biopsy for hepatic copper content.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum iron level: This is used to diagnose iron-related disorders such as hemochromatosis, but it is not relevant to the condition suggested by the iris finding.

 

Option C. Alpha-1 antitrypsin: This test is used for diagnosing alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, which affects the lungs and liver, but not related to the iris finding.

 

Option D. Alpha-fetoprotein: This marker is used for screening and diagnosing certain liver diseases and cancers, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma, but it is not related to the iris finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of a Sun Flower cataract and Kayser-Fleischer ring are indicative of Wilson's disease, a disorder of copper metabolism. The next step in diagnosis is to measure serum ceruloplasmin levels, which are typically low in this condition.

questions.text: A patient with mitochondrial dysfunction is being evaluated for persistent muscle weakness and fatigue. Laboratory tests show impaired ATP production. Which of the following processes is directly coupled to ATP generation during oxidative phosphorylation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proton translocation

 

  • During oxidative phosphorylation, ATP generation is directly coupled with proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane.
  • This process creates a proton gradient, or proton motive force, which drives the synthesis of ATP via ATP synthase as protons flow back into the mitochondrial matrix.
  • This coupling of proton translocation to ATP generation is essential for efficient cellular respiration and energy production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electron flow through cytochromes: Although electron flow through cytochromes is critical for creating the proton gradient, it is the actual translocation of protons that directly couples with ATP synthesis, not the electron flow itself.

 

Option B. Reduction of NADH: In oxidative phosphorylation, NADH is oxidized, not reduced. The electrons released from NADH contribute to the electron transport chain, helping to create the proton gradient necessary for ATP production. Reduction of NADH does not directly couple with ATP generation.

 

Option D. Substrate level phosphorylation: This process generates ATP independently of oxidative phosphorylation, occurring during glycolysis and the TCA cycle. It does not involve the electron transport chain or proton translocation, thus is not part of the oxidative phosphorylation mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oxidative phosphorylation couples ATP generation with the translocation of protons across the inner mitochondrial membrane, creating a gradient that drives ATP synthesis.

choices.text: Physiological left and right half of liver

questions.text: In evaluating a patient for potential liver surgery, the surgical team reviews key anatomical landmarks for safe navigation. One landmark discussed is the cholecysto caval line. Which structures does this line separate in the liver?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Physiological left and right half of liver

 

  • The cholecysto caval line is an important anatomical landmark in the liver. It extends from the gallbladder to the inferior vena cava (IVC), effectively separating the physiological left and right halves of the liver.
  • This line is used to delineate the functional lobes of the liver rather than the anatomical lobes, which are divided by the falciform ligament.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caudate and quadrate lobe:  This is incorrect as these lobes are not separated by the cholecysto caval line.

 

Option C. IVC and gallbladder:  While the cholecysto caval line runs between these two structures, it is not defined as separating them.

 

Option D. Caudate lobe and IVC:  This is incorrect as the caudate lobe lies posteriorly and is not separated from the IVC by the cholecysto caval line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cholecysto caval line is a crucial landmark that separates the physiological left and right halves of the liver.

questions.text: At what age does this reflex typically disappear?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6 months

 

  • The asymmetric tonic neck reflex (ATNR) typically disappears by 6 months of age, allowing for more symmetrical movement and the development of voluntary movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The asymmetric tonic neck reflex (ATNR) is a primitive reflex that normally disappears by 6 months of age, aiding in the development of coordinated and voluntary movements in infants.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with atrial fibrillation is being considered for anticoagulation therapy. Which of the following is an oral factor Xa inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rivaroxaban

 

  • Rivaroxaban is an oral anticoagulant that directly inhibits factor Xa. It is used for stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation, and for the treatment and prevention of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).
  • Unlike warfarin, it does not require routine monitoring of coagulation parameters.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dabigatran: Dabigatran etexilate is an oral anticoagulant that is a direct thrombin inhibitor (factor IIa), not a factor Xa inhibitor. It is also used for stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation and the treatment and prevention of DVT and PE.

 

Option C. Argatroban: Argatroban is a parenteral (injectable) direct thrombin inhibitor used in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

 

Option D. Fondaparinux: Fondaparinux is an injectable synthetic pentasaccharide that acts indirectly by inhibiting factor Xa through antithrombin III activation. It is not an oral anticoagulant.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Rivaroxaban is an oral factor Xa inhibitor used for anticoagulation in conditions such as atrial fibrillation and thromboembolic disorders.
  • Other new oral anticoagulants include dabigatran (a direct thrombin inhibitor), and apixaban, edoxaban, and betrixaban (all factor Xa inhibitors).
  • Argatroban is an injectable thrombin inhibitor, while fondaparinux is an injectable factor Xa inhibitor via antithrombin III activation.

questions.text: 60-year-old male is being treated with quinine for severe malaria. During follow-up, he is monitored for potential adverse effects of the medication. All of the following are known adverse effects of quinine except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bull’s eye retinopathy

 

  • This is not a known adverse effect of quinine.
  • Bull’s eye retinopathy is typically associated with chronic use of chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine, not quinine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypotension: Quinine can cause hypotension, particularly when administered intravenously.

 

Option B. Hypoglycemia: Quinine can stimulate insulin release, leading to hypoglycemia, especially in pregnant women and children.

 

Option D. Arrhythmias: Quinine can prolong the QT interval and cause various cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Quinine is associated with several adverse effects, including hypotension, hypoglycemia, and arrhythmias.
  • However, bull’s eye retinopathy is not among the adverse effects of quinine and is more commonly associated with long-term use of chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine.
  • Understanding the adverse effect profiles of antimalarial drugs is essential for monitoring and managing patient safety during treatment.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a recent diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity is evaluated for a surgical approach. The surgical team is considering a supraomohyoid neck dissection. Which group of lymph nodes is typically spared in a supraomohyoid neck dissection for oral cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Level 4

 

  • Supraomohyoid neck dissection typically includes the removal of lymph nodes from levels I, II, and III.
  • This dissection is often employed in the management of oral cancers to address potential micrometastatic disease while minimizing morbidity.
  • Level IV nodes are not typically included in this type of dissection and are therefore spared unless disease extension or imaging studies indicate involvement.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Level 1: Incorrect. Level 1 nodes are included in supraomohyoid neck dissection, as they are often affected in cancers of the oral cavity.

 

Option B. Level 2: Incorrect. Level 2 nodes are also included in the dissection due to their proximity to the primary oral cavity tumors and their common involvement.

 

Option C. Level 3: Incorrect. Level 3 nodes are included as well, particularly because of their location along the path of lymphatic drainage from the oral cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In supraomohyoid neck dissection, typically employed for oral cancers, lymph nodes in levels I, II, and III are removed, while level IV nodes are spared unless specifically indicated by tumor spread.
  • This selective approach helps to manage regional metastases while preserving tissue and reducing postoperative complications.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with a history of leukemia presents one month after a bone marrow transplant with a widespread scaling rash. She received a partially mismatched donor marrow. A skin biopsy is performed, and the histopathological findings show the presence of apoptotic cells. Which of the following biochemical reactions most likely explains these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Activation of caspases

 

  • The histopathological findings in the skin biopsy, which show apoptotic cells, are indicative of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).
  • In GVHD, donor immune cells attack the recipient's tissues, leading to apoptosis.
  • Apoptosis is mediated by a cascade of biochemical events involving the activation of caspases.
  • Caspases are proteolytic enzymes that play a crucial role in the execution phase of cell apoptosis, leading to the orderly and programmed dismantling of cellular components.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduction of ATP synthesis: This is typically associated with cellular necrosis rather than apoptosis. Necrosis results from severe ATP depletion and is characterized by cell swelling and rupture, not the orderly process seen in apoptosis.

 

Option B. Increase in glycolysis: While an increase in glycolysis can occur in various conditions, it is not specifically related to the apoptotic changes seen in this biopsy.

 

Option C. Activation of lipases: Lipase activation can occur in the context of cell injury leading to necrosis, particularly in the pancreas, but it is not directly related to the apoptotic process observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of apoptotic cells in a skin biopsy from a patient with a scaling rash after a bone marrow transplant is indicative of graft-versus-host disease, driven by the activation of caspases, leading to programmed cell death (apoptosis).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, who has been undergoing treatment for infertility, presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and acute urinary retention. What is the most likely etiology for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retroverted uterus

 

  • In early pregnancy, a retroverted uterus can sometimes become "incarcerated" in the pelvis.
  • This can cause the uterus to press against the bladder, leading to urinary retention.
  • This condition is more likely to occur in the first trimester when the uterus is still small and the retroversion can cause significant compression of the bladder outlet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pelvic hematocoele: This refers to a collection of blood in the pelvic cavity, often related to trauma or ruptured ectopic pregnancy, which would present with different symptoms such as acute abdominal pain and signs of internal bleeding.

 

Option C. Impacted cervical fibroid: While an impacted cervical fibroid can cause urinary retention, it is less common than a retroverted uterus in early pregnancy.

 

Option D. Carcinoma cervix: This condition can cause urinary symptoms, but acute urinary retention is less common as an initial presentation and would more likely be accompanied by other symptoms such as abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A retroverted uterus in early pregnancy can cause acute urinary retention by compressing the bladder, making it the most likely etiology for a woman presenting with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and urinary retention.

choices.text: Superior constrictor muscle
Inferior constrictor muscle
Middle constrictor muscle

questions.text: A 41-year-old male patient presents with symptoms of dysphagia and regurgitation. A barium swallow test reveals the following picture. This condition is primarily associated with weakness in which anatomical region?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior constrictor muscle

 

  • The inferior constrictor muscle is crucial in swallowing, closing the pharynx and esophagus.
  • Zenker's diverticulum forms due to a weakness in Killian’s triangle, a zone of muscular weakness between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus parts of the inferior constrictor muscle.
  • This area is susceptible to herniation of the mucosal layer through the muscle, forming the diverticulum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior constrictor muscle: The superior constrictor muscle forms part of the pharyngeal wall and plays a role in initiating the swallowing process by constricting the pharyngeal wall. However, it is not typically involved in the formation of Zenker's diverticulum, which occurs lower down at the junction of the pharynx and the esophagus.

 

Option C. Middle constrictor muscle: The middle constrictor muscle of the pharynx functions in the swallowing process, reducing the diameter of the pharynx to push food into the esophagus. It is not associated with the typical location of Zenker's diverticulum, which is above the esophageal opening.

 

Option D. Palatopharyngeus muscle: The palatopharyngeus muscle is part of the soft palate and helps to elevate the pharynx and larynx during swallowing. This muscle is not involved in the formation of Zenker's diverticulum, as it is located away from the typical site of diverticulum formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Zenker's diverticulum is an example of a pharyngeal pouch that results from a specific weakness in the inferior constrictor muscle at Killian's triangle.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with a one-week history of fever, headache, and myalgia. He reports a recent hiking trip in a rural area of Assam. On physical examination, he is found to have a maculopapular rash on his trunk and extremities and an eschar on his back, as shown in the image. Laboratory tests reveal thrombocytopenia and elevated hepatic transaminases. He denies any respiratory symptoms, gastrointestinal symptoms, or a history of similar episodes. Which of the following diseases is most likely depicted by the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scrub typhus

 

  • Scrub typhus is an acute febrile illness caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi.
  • It is transmitted through the bite of larval trombiculid mites (chiggers). The characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, combined with fever, headache, myalgia, maculopapular rash, thrombocytopenia, and elevated hepatic transaminases, strongly suggests scrub typhus.
  • The patient's recent hiking trip in a rural area of Southeast Asia further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. COVID-19: While COVID-19 can present with fever, headache, and myalgia, it typically does not present with an eschar, maculopapular rash, thrombocytopenia, and elevated hepatic transaminases in the absence of respiratory symptoms. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option B. Malaria: Malaria can present with fever, headache, and myalgia, but it does not typically cause an eschar or maculopapular rash. Additionally, malaria is diagnosed based on blood smears showing Plasmodium parasites, which is not described in this case. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option C. Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF): RMSF can present with fever, headache, myalgia, and a maculopapular rash. However, it is primarily associated with tick bites and is more common in the United States. The presence of an eschar and the geographic location of the patient make scrub typhus a more likely diagnosis. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scrub typhus is characterized by the presence of an eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with fever, headache, myalgia, maculopapular rash, thrombocytopenia, and elevated hepatic transaminases.

questions.text: Which of the following is the longest worm known to infect humans?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Taenia saginata

 

  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm) is the longest worm known to infect humans, reaching lengths of up to 10 meters or more. It is transmitted through the ingestion of undercooked or raw beef containing cysticerci, the larval form of the parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Taenia solium: (pork tapeworm) can grow up to 2-3 meters long but is generally shorter than Taenia saginata.

 

Option C. Hookworm: Includes species like Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus, which are much shorter, typically measuring 12 cm in length.

 

Option D. Ascaris lumbricoides: The giant roundworm can reach up to 20-30 cm in length, making it the longest roundworm but still significantly shorter than Taenia saginata.

 

Educational Objective
