  • Taenia saginata, the beef tapeworm, is the longest worm known to infect humans, capable of reaching lengths up to 10 meters or more.

questions.text: A pharmacological experiment involves the administration of an unknown drug to a rabbit ileum. The drug produces the effect, as shown in the figure. Based on this information, identify the unknown drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Barium chloride

 

  • The figure shows that the unknown drug has a stimulatory effect on the rabbit ileum that is not blocked by atropine.
  • This indicates that the drug acts directly on the smooth muscle rather than through muscarinic receptors.
  • Barium chloride is a directly acting stimulant that increases the tone of the rabbit ileum and is not affected by atropine.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Acetylcholine: Acetylcholine stimulates muscarinic receptors and its effect would be blocked by atropine, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Adrenaline: Adrenaline has a depressant effect on the rabbit ileum, which is not consistent with the stimulatory effect shown in the figure.

 

Option D. Papaverine: Papaverine has a depressant effect on the rabbit ileum, which is also inconsistent with the stimulatory effect observed.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Bright red blood in the stool
Relief of abdominal pain after defecation

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, bloating, and loose stools with mucus for several years, recently worsening over the last 6 weeks. Pain varies in location and intensity. She has moderate lower abdominal pain during menstruation. Vital signs are normal. Further evaluation is most likely to show which finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Relief of abdominal pain after defecation

 

  • Relief of abdominal pain after defecation is a common symptom in patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), a chronic gastrointestinal disorder with variable presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Black, tarry stools: Black, tarry stools indicate upper gastrointestinal bleeding, not typical for IBS.

 

Option B. Bright red blood in the stool: Bright red blood suggests lower gastrointestinal bleeding, seen in conditions like colorectal cancer.

 

Option D. Abdominal pain at night: Night pain is often associated with peptic ulcer disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Relief of abdominal pain after defecation is a common symptom in patients with irritable bowel syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with unexplained weight gain, fatigue, and cold intolerance, prompting concerns about possible thyroid dysfunction. As part of the assessment, the clinician considers the role of Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone (TRH) in regulating thyroid function. Apart from TSH, TRH stimulates the release of which other hormone?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prolactin

 

  • Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone (TRH) is produced by the hypothalamus and stimulates the anterior pituitary gland to release Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone (TSH), which in turn stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones.
  • In addition to TSH, TRH also stimulates the release of prolactin from the anterior pituitary.
  • Prolactin plays a crucial role in lactation and has various other physiological functions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GH - Growth Hormone: Growth Hormone is regulated by Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone (GHRH) and somatostatin, not TRH. Therefore, TRH does not stimulate the release of GH.

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is produced in the hypothalamus and released from the posterior pituitary. Its release is regulated by neural mechanisms rather than TRH, so TRH does not stimulate the release of oxytocin.

 

Option C. Gonadotropin: Gonadotropins (LH and FSH) are regulated by Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH), not TRH. Thus, TRH does not stimulate the release of gonadotropins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Apart from stimulating the release of TSH, Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone (TRH) also stimulates the release of prolactin from the anterior pituitary.

choices.text: Metastatic adenocarcinoma of the prostate gland

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with increasing enlargement and heaviness in his scrotum for the past year. Physical examination reveals the right testis is twice its normal size, firm, and slightly tender. Ultrasound shows a 3.5-cm solid mass in the right testis. Abdominal CT scan reveals para-aortic lymph node enlargement, and a chest radiograph shows multiple lung nodules. Laboratory findings indicate markedly increased serum levels of chorionic gonadotropin and α-fetoprotein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mixed germ cell tumor

 

  • Mixed germ cell tumors can produce both chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and α-fetoprotein (AFP).
  • The presence of both elevated serum markers, along with the clinical and radiologic findings, is characteristic of a mixed germ cell tumor.
  • These tumors often contain a combination of different germ cell components, such as teratoma, embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor, and choriocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leydig cell tumor: These tumors are typically hormonally active but do not produce hCG or AFP.

 

Option B. Pure spermatocytic seminoma: This type of tumor generally does not produce hCG or AFP and is less likely to metastasize.

 

Option C. Metastatic adenocarcinoma of the prostate gland: Would not typically produce hCG or AFP and is less likely to present as a testicular mass with the described findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mixed germ cell tumors often present with elevated levels of both chorionic gonadotropin and α-fetoprotein and are characterized by their combination of different germ cell components, leading to complex clinical and radiologic findings.

choices.text: Expansion of CAG repeats on chromosome 4p16
Inheritance of a mutant prion gene
Inheritance of the ε4 allele at the ApoE gene

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with a 8-year history of progressive dementia dies of bronchopneumonia. Autopsy shows cerebral atrophy mainly in the frontal and parietal lobes. Microscopic examination reveals numerous neuritic plaques in the hippocampus, amygdala, and neocortex. Congo red staining shows amyloid in the cerebral arteries. Which genetic factor is most likely involved in her disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inheritance of the ε4 allele at the ApoE gene

 

  • The findings of neuritic plaques and amyloid deposition are characteristic of Alzheimer's disease.
  • The inheritance of the ε4 allele of the ApoE gene is a well-known genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer's disease, influencing the formation and deposition of amyloid plaques.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Expansion of CAG repeats on chromosome 4p16: This is associated with Huntington's disease, not Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option B. Inheritance of a mutant prion gene: Associated with prion diseases like Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, not Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option C. HLA-DR3/DR4: Associated with autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and type 1 diabetes, not Alzheimer's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inheritance of the ε4 allele at the ApoE gene is a significant risk factor for developing late-onset Alzheimer's disease, which is characterized by amyloid plaque formation and cerebral atrophy.

choices.text: Debridement of the affected tissue
Intravenous administration of warmed crystalloid
Extracorporeal blood rewarming
Immersion of affected extremities in warm water

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents after severe cold exposure. His hand appears like as shown in the image. Rectal temperature is 35.2°C (95.3°F). What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Immersion of affected extremities in warm water

 

  • Active rewarming with warm water immersion is the first step in frostbite treatment to prevent further tissue damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Debridement of the affected tissue: Debridement is delayed until tissue viability is clear.

 

Option B. Intravenous administration of warmed crystalloid: IV crystalloid is for severe hypothermia.

 

Option C. Extracorporeal blood rewarming : Extracorporeal blood rewarming is for severe hypothermia, not localized frostbite

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Active rewarming with warm water immersion is the first step in frostbite treatment to prevent further tissue damage

questions.text: A patient present with symptoms indicative of a vitamin deficiency. Laboratory tests suggest a deficiency in pyridoxine (vitamin B6). Which of the following enzymes would have impaired catalytic activity due to this deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alanine aminotransferase

 

  • Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) is a precursor for pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), which serves as a coenzyme for many aminotransferases, including alanine aminotransferase (ALT).
  • PLP is essential for the catalytic activity of these enzymes, facilitating the transfer of amino groups in amino acid metabolism.
  • A deficiency in pyridoxine leads to decreased PLP levels, thereby impairing the function of ALT and other PLP-dependent enzymes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutamate dehydrogenase: This enzyme catalyzes the reversible oxidative deamination of glutamate to α-ketoglutarate and does not primarily depend on pyridoxal phosphate for its activity.

 

Option C. Glutamine synthetase: This enzyme catalyzes the ATP-dependent conversion of glutamate and ammonia to glutamine and does not require pyridoxal phosphate for its activity.

 

Option D. Glutaminase: This enzyme catalyzes the hydrolysis of glutamine to glutamate and ammonia. It is not dependent on pyridoxal phosphate for its catalytic activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency impairs the catalytic activity of enzymes that require pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a coenzyme, such as alanine aminotransferase.

choices.text: Pneumothorax is a recognized complication of central venous catheterization via the IJV.
Ultrasound guidance reduces the risk of pneumothorax during central venous catheter insertion in the IJV.
The risk of pneumothorax is higher when using a landmark-based approach compared to ultrasound guidance for IJV catheterization.
Pneumothorax is more commonly seen with left-sided IJV catheterization compared to right-sided insertion.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding pneumothorax after inserting a central venous catheter in the internal jugular vein (IJV) is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pneumothorax is more commonly seen with left-sided IJV catheterization compared to right-sided insertion.

 

  • Incorrect. Pneumothorax is not more commonly seen with left-sided IJV catheterization compared to right-sided insertion.
  • While the right IJV is often preferred for central venous catheterization due to its more direct route to the superior vena cava, the risk of pneumothorax is similar for both sides.
  • The risk of pneumothorax is primarily related to procedural technique and patient factors rather than the side of catheter insertion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax is a recognized complication of central venous catheterization via the IJV: Correct. Pneumothorax is indeed a recognized complication of central venous catheterization via the internal jugular vein (IJV). This occurs due to inadvertent puncture of the pleura during needle or catheter insertion.

 

Option B. Ultrasound guidance reduces the risk of pneumothorax during central venous catheter insertion in the IJV: Correct. Studies have shown that ultrasound guidance reduces the risk of pneumothorax during central venous catheter insertion in the IJV. Ultrasound allows for real-time visualization of the needle and adjacent structures, decreasing the likelihood of inadvertent puncture of the pleura.

 

Option C. The risk of pneumothorax is higher when using a landmark-based approach compared to ultrasound guidance for IJV catheterization: Correct. The risk of pneumothorax is higher when using a landmark-based approach (anatomical landmarks for needle insertion) compared to ultrasound guidance for IJV catheterization. Ultrasound guidance provides better visualization of the needle trajectory and surrounding structures, reducing the risk of complications such as pneumothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pneumothorax is a recognized complication of central venous catheterization via the internal jugular vein (IJV).
  • The use of ultrasound guidance reduces the risk of pneumothorax during IJV catheter insertion by providing real-time visualization of the needle and surrounding structures.
  • The risk of pneumothorax is higher with landmark-based approaches compared to ultrasound guidance.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 34 weeks' gestation presents with sudden onset abdominal pain and slight vaginal bleeding. On examination, the uterine size is larger than expected for gestational age, and fetal heart sounds are absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Concealed hemorrhage

 

  • Concealed hemorrhage, a type of placental abruption, is the most likely diagnosis given the presentation of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, an unexpectedly large uterine size, and absent fetal heart sounds.
  • In placental abruption, the placenta separates from the uterine wall prematurely, causing bleeding.
  • When the bleeding is trapped behind the placenta and does not exit through the vagina, it is termed concealed hemorrhage.
  • This condition can lead to significant maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality, including the absence of fetal heart sounds, indicating fetal compromise or demise.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Active labor: Active labor typically presents with regular contractions and cervical dilation, not with an unexpectedly large uterine size or absent fetal heart sounds unless there is a severe complication like a fetal demise.

 

Option C. Hydramnios: Hydramnios (polyhydramnios) involves excessive amniotic fluid, which can cause the uterus to be larger than expected. However, it does not typically present with the combination of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and absent fetal heart sounds unless there is an associated complication.

 

Option D. Uterine rupture: Uterine rupture can present with severe abdominal pain and bleeding, especially in the context of a previous cesarean section. It can lead to absent fetal heart sounds, but it is less likely to cause a larger-than-expected uterine size without significant external bleeding or trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Concealed hemorrhage, a type of placental abruption, should be suspected in a pregnant woman at 34 weeks' gestation presenting with abdominal pain, slight vaginal bleeding, a larger-than-expected uterine size, and absent fetal heart sounds.

choices.text: Inadequate information to calculate 95% CI

questions.text: A 45-year-old epidemiologist is conducting a study to estimate the prevalence of a specific disease in a community. The study finds a prevalence of 10% with a sample size of 100 individuals. What is the 95% confidence interval for the estimated prevalence?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4–16

 

  • To calculate the 95% confidence interval for a proportion, the formula is:

 

 

 

 

  • When rounded to the nearest whole percentage, the 95% confidence interval is approximately 4% to 16%.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Confidence Intervals for Population proportions (For 95% Confidence)

CI = P ± 2 SEP = P ± 2 √pq/n

questions.text: The fracture seen in the x-ray given below is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galeazzi’s fracture

 

  • Galeazzi's fracture involves a fracture of the distal radius with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint.
  • It is often associated with a fall onto an outstretched hand with the wrist extended.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Monteggia Fracture: A Monteggia fracture involves a fracture of the proximal ulna along with dislocation of the radial head. It typically occurs due to a direct blow to the forearm or a fall onto an outstretched hand with the elbow extended.

 

 

Option C. Smith’s Fracture: Smith's fracture is a fracture of the distal radius with volar (palmar) displacement of the distal fragment. It is often the result of a fall onto a flexed wrist or direct trauma to the back of the hand.

 

 

Option D. Colles' Fracture: Colles' fracture is a fracture of the distal radius with dorsal (backwards) displacement of the distal fragment. It is commonly caused by a fall onto an outstretched hand with the wrist extended.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the Galeazzi fracture of the distal radius along with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to a hospital with a 3-week history of muffled hearing and a sensation of fullness in the right ear. Examination reveals no signs of acute infection, but otoscopy indicates the presence of a middle ear effusion. The patient denies any recent upper respiratory infections or allergies. In managing his condition, which procedure is most appropriate to relieve his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion

 

  • Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion is indicated in this scenario to alleviate the symptoms of serous otitis media by draining the middle ear effusion.
  • This procedure involves making a small incision in the tympanic membrane (typically in the anteroinferior quadrant to avoid damaging major structures) to suction out fluid and relieve pressure, often followed by the placement of a tympanostomy tube to allow continued aeration of the middle ear and prevent fluid reaccumulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tympanoplasty: Used to reconstruct the tympanic membrane or ossicles and is not indicated for uncomplicated serous otitis media.

 

Option C. Cochlear implant: Indicated for severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss, not for middle ear effusions.

 

Option D. Conservative management with decongestants: Although sometimes used for initial management, in this case, the duration and symptoms suggest a need for more definitive treatment like myringotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of serous otitis media with persistent effusion and symptoms of aural fullness or hearing impairment, myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion is an effective procedure to immediately relieve symptoms by draining the effusion and ventilating the middle ear.
  • This procedure is commonly performed when medical management fails or is deemed inappropriate due to the duration or severity of the effusion.

choices.text: Removal at cesarean section

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with severe abdominal pain, and an ultrasound confirms the presence of a fibroid undergoing red degeneration. What is the appropriate treatment for red degeneration of a fibroid during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Analgesics

 

  • Red degeneration of a fibroid (also known as carneous degeneration) is a common complication during pregnancy, characterized by acute pain due to hemorrhage within the fibroid.
  • The appropriate treatment is primarily conservative, focusing on pain management with analgesics.
  • This approach helps to control symptoms while avoiding unnecessary surgical intervention that could complicate the pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laparotomy: This invasive surgical procedure is generally not indicated for red degeneration of fibroids during pregnancy unless there is a complication such as torsion or necrosis that necessitates surgical intervention.

 

Option C. Termination of pregnancy: Termination of pregnancy is not required for the management of red degeneration of fibroids. Conservative management with analgesics is typically effective.

 

Option D. Removal at cesarean section: While fibroids can be removed during a cesarean section if necessary, this is not the immediate treatment for red degeneration. The primary approach during pregnancy is symptom management with analgesics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The treatment for red degeneration of fibroids during pregnancy is primarily conservative, focusing on pain relief with analgesics to manage symptoms effectively.

choices.text: Anti-Mullerian hormone deficiency
Maternal androgen adrenal tumor
Placental aromatase deficiency

questions.text: A 46XX newborn presents with male external genitalia. Which of the following is NOT a possible cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-Mullerian hormone deficiency

 

  • Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) deficiency is not a cause of male external genitalia in a 46XX newborn.
  • AMH is responsible for the regression of Müllerian ducts in male embryos, and its deficiency would lead to the presence of Müllerian structures in a male fetus rather than affecting the development of external genitalia in a 46XX individual.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. WNT 4 mutation: Mutations in WNT 4 can lead to disrupted ovarian development, potentially causing androgen excess and masculinization of external genitalia in a 46XX individual.

 

Option C. Maternal androgen adrenal tumor: An adrenal tumor in the mother producing excess androgens can cross the placenta, leading to virilization of a female fetus.

 

Option D. Placental aromatase deficiency: This condition results in the inadequate conversion of androgens to estrogens, leading to elevated androgen levels and masculinization of the external genitalia in a 46XX individual.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) deficiency does not lead to the development of male external genitalia in a 46XX newborn.
  • Conditions causing excess androgen exposure during fetal development, such as placental aromatase deficiency, maternal androgen-producing tumors, and WNT 4 mutations, can result in this phenotype.

choices.text: Venous ulcers are most commonly seen in the lower part of the leg, near the medial malleolus.
Venous ulcers are caused by ambulatory venous hypertension.
Venous ulcers are deep and painful.
An active venous ulcer is classified as CEAP C6.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with a history of chronic venous insufficiency presents to the clinic with a non-healing ulcer on his lower leg. Which of the following statements about venous ulcers is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Venous ulcers are deep and painful.

 

  • Venous ulcers are typically shallow and may be painful, but the pain is often more related to associated inflammation rather than the depth of the ulcer itself.
  • They are not typically deep, which contrasts with arterial ulcers that are often deep and very painful.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous ulcers are most commonly seen in the lower part of the leg, near the medial malleolus: Correct because venous ulcers are indeed most commonly found in the lower part of the leg, especially near the medial malleolus (Gaiter’s area) due to venous hypertension affecting the lower extremities.

 

Option B. Venous ulcers are caused by ambulatory venous hypertension: Correct as venous ulcers are primarily caused by chronic venous hypertension, which results from valvular incompetence or obstruction in the venous system.

 

Option D. An active venous ulcer is classified as CEAP C6: Correct because an active venous ulcer is classified as CEAP C6 in the clinical classification of chronic venous disorders, indicating skin changes with active ulceration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Venous ulcers are typically shallow and located in the lower part of the leg, especially near the medial malleolus, and are often associated with chronic venous insufficiency and ambulatory venous hypertension.
  • They are classified as CEAP C6 when there is active ulceration.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman has inherited a mutant BRCA1 gene and has a 60% chance of developing breast cancer by the age of 50. The BRCA1 gene produces a protein involved in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks. Which of the following processes is adversely affected by the deficiency of the BRCA1 protein?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Homologous recombination

 

  • The BRCA1 protein is essential for repairing DNA double-strand breaks through homologous recombination.
  • This process ensures accurate repair by using a homologous sequence as a template, maintaining genetic stability.
  • A deficiency in BRCA1 disrupts this repair mechanism, leading to genomic instability and a heightened risk of cancers, particularly breast and ovarian cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Removal of thymine dimers: This is part of the nucleotide excision repair pathway, which does not primarily depend on BRCA1.

 

Option C. Removal of RNA primers: This is a process in DNA replication involving RNase H and DNA polymerase I, not BRCA1.

 

Option D. Removal of carcinogen adducts: This also falls under nucleotide excision repair and is not directly related to BRCA1 function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRCA1 protein deficiency adversely affects homologous recombination, a critical process for accurately repairing DNA double-strand breaks.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with difficulty in finger movements, specifically in extending his fingers. During a detailed musculoskeletal examination, you assess the involvement of various muscles in the dorsal digital expansion. Which of the following muscles does not participate in the dorsal digital expansion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adductor Pollicis

 

  • The dorsal digital expansion (extensor hood) is a complex structure that allows for coordinated finger movements. It is primarily formed by the tendons of the extensor digitorum, lumbricals, and interossei muscles.
  •  These muscles work together to extend the fingers at the interphalangeal joints and flex at the metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • The adductor pollicis, however, is a muscle of the thumb that does not contribute to the dorsal digital expansion. It is responsible for adducting the thumb and does not play a role in finger extension.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extensor Digitorum: This muscle inserts into the dorsal digital expansion and is crucial for extending the fingers.

 

Option B. Lumbricals: These muscles attach to the extensor hoods and assist in extending the fingers at the interphalangeal joints while flexing the metacarpophalangeal joints.

 

Option C. Interossei: These muscles also attach to the extensor hoods and play a role in both finger abduction/adduction and extension at the interphalangeal joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The adductor pollicis does not participate in the dorsal digital expansion, which is primarily involved in finger extension and is formed by the extensor digitorum, lumbricals, and interossei muscles.

choices.text: Ganglia in mesenteric plexus

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with chronic abdominal pain. During an exploratory laparotomy, a large nerve ganglion is noted in the mesentery. Histological examination reveals neurons with large cell bodies and a large, eccentric nucleus. Which of the following is the most likely location of these neurons?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spinal ganglia

 

  • Spinal ganglia, also known as dorsal root ganglia, contain neurons with large cell bodies and a large, eccentric nucleus.
  • These characteristics are typical of the ganglia found in the spinal ganglia, which are responsible for transmitting sensory information from the periphery to the central nervous system.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Ganglia in mesenteric plexus: Ganglia in the mesenteric plexus, also known as the enteric nervous system, contain neurons that typically have centrally located nuclei. The description of neurons with large, eccentric nuclei does not match the typical histological appearance of the mesenteric plexus ganglia.

 

Option C. Coeliac ganglia: The coeliac ganglia, part of the sympathetic nervous system, also contain neurons, but these neurons do not typically have large, eccentric nuclei. These ganglia are involved in the autonomic innervation of abdominal organs but have a different histological appearance.

 

Option D. Cervical ganglia: Cervical ganglia are part of the sympathetic chain in the neck. Neurons in these ganglia do not typically have the described large, eccentric nuclei. They are involved in the sympathetic innervation of the head, neck, and upper limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neurons in the spinal ganglia are characterized by large cell bodies and large, eccentric nuclei, which are distinguishing features of these sensory ganglia.

choices.text: Oblique diameter of inlet
Interspinous diameter of outlet
AP diameter of outlet

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in active labor is being assessed for pelvic adequacy. Which diameter of the pelvis is the most important during labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Interspinous diameter of outlet

 

  • The interspinous diameter, also known as the interspinous distance, is the most important diameter of the pelvis during labor.
  • It is the narrowest part of the pelvic outlet and the critical determinant of whether the fetal head can pass through the pelvis during delivery.
  • This measurement is crucial for assessing the adequacy of the pelvis for vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oblique diameter of inlet: While the oblique diameter of the pelvic inlet is relevant to the overall shape and size of the pelvis, it is not the most critical dimension during labor. The fetal head must navigate through the entire pelvic canal, making the interspinous diameter more important.

 

Option C. AP diameter of outlet: The anteroposterior (AP) diameter of the pelvic outlet is also significant but is not as critical as the interspinous diameter. The AP diameter is generally larger than the interspinous diameter, making the latter the limiting factor during labor.

 

Option D. Intertubercular diameter: This refers to the distance between the ischial tuberosities, which is less critical compared to the interspinous diameter for the passage of the fetal head during labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The interspinous diameter of the pelvis is the most important diameter during labor, as it represents the narrowest part of the pelvic outlet and determines whether the fetal head can successfully pass through the pelvis during delivery.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of neonatal mortality in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prematurity

 

  • The leading cause of neonatal mortality in India, primarily due to complications related to preterm birth such as respiratory distress syndrome, sepsis, and intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diarrhea: Although a major cause of morbidity and mortality in infants and older children, it is less common in the neonatal period.

 

Option C. Pneumonia: Significant cause of neonatal mortality, but less frequent compared to complications of prematurity.

 

Option D. Asthma: Not a significant cause of neonatal mortality as it typically presents later in childhood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prematurity is the most common cause of neonatal mortality in India, highlighting the importance of prenatal care and interventions to prevent preterm birth.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. Histopathology of the resected gall bladder is reported as Stage T1a of gallbladder cancer. What would be the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) No further treatment.

 

  • Cholecystectomy is sufficient for gallbladder carcinoma with T1a lesions, wherein the tumour penetrates the lamina propria but does not invade the muscle layer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perform extended cholecystectomy: This is required for T1b (muscle invasive) Ca GB.

 

Option C. Adjuvant chemotherapy: This is required in T1b or higher stages of Ca GB.

 

Option D. Radiation: This is not usually needed in treatment of Ca Gb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment options for carcinoma gall bladder found incidentally after cholecystectomy:

 

  • T1a with negative margins: Standard cholecystectomy
  • T1a with perineural/ lymphatic/ vascular invasion: Extended cholecystectomy Chemotherapy is not required in an early gall bladder cancer. Radiation has no role.
  • T1b: Extended cholecystectomy. No need for port site excision.

choices.text: It is a prodrug that is converted to a peripherally acting enkephalinase inhibitor
It is a drug used in constipation
It is metabolized by the liver
It has anti-secretory action in the GIT

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is prescribed racecadotril for the treatment of diarrhea. Which of the following statements about racecadotril is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is a drug used in constipation

 

  • This statement is false. Racecadotril is used to treat diarrhea, not constipation. It works by reducing intestinal secretions rather than altering bowel motility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a prodrug that is converted to a peripherally acting enkephalinase inhibitor: This statement is true. Racecadotril is a prodrug that, once metabolized, inhibits enkephalinase, an enzyme involved in the breakdown of endogenous enkephalins. This inhibition enhances the anti-secretory effects of enkephalins in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. It is metabolized by the liver: This statement is true. Racecadotril undergoes hepatic metabolism.

 

Option D. It has anti-secretory action in the GIT: This statement is true. Racecadotril reduces the secretion of water and electrolytes into the intestine, helping to control diarrhea.


Educational Objective:

 

  • Racecadotril is a prodrug converted to a peripherally acting enkephalinase inhibitor used for the treatment of diarrhea.
  • It has an anti-secretory action in the gastrointestinal tract and is metabolized by the liver. It is not used to treat constipation.

choices.text: Rest at an angle, inclined to surface of skin

questions.text: A 35-year-old epidemiologist is examining various vectors of malaria for a public health report. Which of the following is NOT a characteristic feature of the malaria vector?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Siphon tube

 

  • The siphon tube is a feature of mosquito larvae, specifically Culex species, which are not the primary vectors of malaria.
  • Anopheles mosquitoes, the vectors of malaria, do not have a siphon tube. Anopheles larvae rest parallel to the water surface without a siphon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spotted wings: Anopheles mosquitoes have characteristic spotted wings, which help in their identification.

 

Option C. Boat shaped eggs: Anopheles mosquitoes lay boat-shaped eggs with lateral floats on the water surface.

 

Option D. Rest at an angle, inclined to surface of skin: Anopheles mosquitoes typically rest at an angle (45 degrees) with their head down and abdomen up, inclined to the surface of the skin, when feeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anopheles mosquitoes, the primary vectors of malaria, have distinctive features such as spotted wings, boat-shaped eggs, and a characteristic resting posture at an angle inclined to the surface of the skin.
  • They do not have a siphon tube, which is a feature associated with Culex mosquito larvae.
  • Understanding these characteristics is crucial for the identification and control of malaria vectors.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with epilepsy presents with gingival overgrowth as shown in the image. Which antiepileptic drug is most likely to lead to this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phenytoin

 

  • Phenytoin is known to cause gingival hyperplasia (overgrowth) as a common adverse effect.
  • This occurs in a significant number of patients taking the drug for long-term epilepsy management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbamazepine: This sodium channel blocker is not typically associated with gingival hyperplasia. Its adverse effects more commonly include dizziness, drowsiness, and, in rare cases, agranulocytosis.

 

Option C. Valproate: Valproate has a broad mechanism of action, including increasing GABA levels and blocking sodium channels, but it does not cause gingival hyperplasia. Common side effects of valproate include weight gain, hair loss, and hepatotoxicity.

 

Option D. Lamotrigine: Another sodium channel blocker, lamotrigine is not known to cause gingival hyperplasia. Its side effects more commonly include rash, which can be severe (Stevens-Johnson syndrome), and dizziness.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Phenytoin is a sodium channel blocker used to treat epilepsy that can cause gingival hyperplasia as a significant adverse effect.
  • This side effect requires monitoring in patients on long-term phenytoin therapy.

 

Additional Information:

 

The mechanism of action of antiepileptic drugs:

choices.text: Large grafts can be harvested

questions.text: All are advantages of split thickness skin grafting except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Good cosmesis

 

Partial Thickness (Thiersch) or Split Skin Graft

 

  • Consist of epidermis and variable portion of dermis
  • Cosmesis is poor. Grafts are hairless and do not sweat (these structures are not transferred)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Good uptake: Uptake is good

 

Option B. Reusable donor site: Donor site can be used as it heals without scarring. Site: Thigh (MC) upper arm, flexor aspect of forearm and abdominal wall

 

Option D. Large grafts can be harvested: Large sized graft can be taken

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • STSG is placed over large wounds where cosmesis is not needed. It is avoided over the face.

choices.text: Methylene blue test is used to detect microorganisms in milk
Phosphatase test is used to detect the efficiency of pasteurization
Milk is heated to 135°C in the ultra-high temperature (UHT) method

questions.text: A food safety inspector is reviewing the methods used for disinfecting and sterilizing milk. The inspector asks which statement is false regarding these methods. Which of the following is false about the methods used for disinfecting/sterilizing milk?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pasteurization kills 100% of bacteria

 

  • Pasteurization kills 100% of bacteria is false.
  • Pasteurization does not kill 100% of bacteria; instead, it significantly reduces the number of pathogenic microorganisms to a level that is safe for consumption.
  • Some non-pathogenic bacteria may survive the pasteurization process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylene blue test is used to detect microorganisms in milk: This is true. The methylene blue reduction test is a common method used to estimate the number of bacteria in milk.

 

Option B. Phosphatase test is used to detect the efficiency of pasteurization: This is true. The phosphatase test checks for the presence of the enzyme phosphatase, which should be inactivated during proper pasteurization.

 

Option D. Milk is heated to 135°C in the ultra-high temperature (UHT) method: This is true. The UHT method involves heating milk to temperatures around 135°C for a few seconds to achieve sterilization and extend shelf life.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Methylene blue reduction test is used to detect microorganism in milk
  • In pasteurization: Milk is heated to high temperature for short time (72°C for 15 seconds). Efficacy of pasteurization is tested by the phosphatase test.
  • Ultra-heat treated milk: The milk is exposed to very high temperature of 135°C for 1 second so that all microorganisms with their spores are destroyed.

questions.text: A respiratory physiology seminar presents a pressure-volume loop obtained from a patient during mechanical ventilation. The difference in the course of the inspiratory loop and the expiratory loop in the curve is being discussed. The difference in the course of the inspiratory loop and the expiratory loop in the curve is due to which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Difference in Surfactant Concentration

 

  • The pressure-volume loop shown in the image displays hysteresis, which is the difference between the inflation (inspiration) and deflation (expiration) curves.
  • This hysteresis is primarily due to the dynamic properties of the lung's surfactant, which reduces surface tension and thereby influences lung compliance differently during inflation and deflation.
  • During inspiration, the surfactant molecules are more spread out, resulting in higher surface tension and lower compliance. During expiration, the surfactant molecules become more concentrated, decreasing surface tension and increasing compliance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Difference in Alveolar Pressure: While alveolar pressure changes during breathing, the primary cause of the hysteresis observed in the pressure-volume loop is related to surfactant dynamics rather than direct changes in alveolar pressure.

 

Option C. Difference in Airway Resistance: Airway resistance affects the flow of air but does not significantly contribute to the hysteresis seen in the pressure-volume loop. The loop's shape is more influenced by lung compliance and surfactant properties.

 

Option D. Active Inspiration, Passive Expiration: Although inspiration is typically an active process and expiration is usually passive, this does not explain the hysteresis in the pressure-volume loop. The hysteresis is due to the properties of the lung tissue and surfactant rather than the muscular activity involved in breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The difference in the course of the inspiratory and expiratory loops in the pressure-volume curve (hysteresis) is primarily due to the difference in surfactant concentration, which affects lung compliance during inflation and deflation.

questions.text: A 60 kg man receives an intravenous dose of 100 mg of lignocaine. The concentration of lignocaine in the arteries entering the liver is 10 mg/L, while it is 2 mg/L in the veins leaving the liver. If the hepatic blood flow is 1.5 L/hour, what is the hepatic clearance of lignocaine?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1.2 L/hour

 

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Hepatic clearance is calculated using the hepatic blood flow and the extraction ratio.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a low-grade fever, loss of appetite, and weight loss. A barium meal follow-through is performed and reveals abnormalities. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ileocecal TB

 

  • Based on the given clinical scenario and the barium study findings, the patient is likely suffering from ileocecal tuberculosis.
  • The barium study revealed several characteristic features of this condition, including a dilated proximal ileum, narrowed terminal ileum with a string sign, and a shrunken cecum that appears pulled up away from the right iliac fossa.
  • The ileocecal junction, which is the most common site of tuberculosis in the gastrointestinal tract, is also narrowed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Colonic diverticulosis: Colonic diverticulosis involves the presence of diverticula, which are small, bulging pouches in the colon. It usually does not present with a low-grade fever, loss of appetite, and significant weight loss, and the barium meal follow-through would show outpouchings in the colonic wall rather than the specific findings associated with ileocecal TB.

 

Option C. Crohn's disease: Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract but commonly involves the terminal ileum and can present with similar symptoms. However, the barium meal follow-through for Crohn's disease typically shows skip lesions, cobblestone appearance, and strictures, rather than the specific signs associated with ileocecal TB.

 

Option D. Carcinoma caecum: Carcinoma of the cecum would usually present with more localized symptoms, such as a palpable mass, obstruction, or bleeding, and might show an irregular, filling defect on a barium study. The systemic symptoms and specific radiographic findings described here are more indicative of ileocecal TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ileocecal TB is characterized by a narrowed terminal ileum, thickening of the ileocecal valve, and a "string sign" on barium meal follow-through, along with systemic symptoms like low-grade fever, loss of appetite, and weight loss.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of prostate cancer and bilateral nephrostomy tubes presents with low urine output, right flank pain, and confusion. Vital signs show T-39.2oC, PR 124/min, RR 22/min, and BP 76/50 mm Hg. After 2.5 L of 0.9% saline, his BP is 78/54 mm Hg. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Norepinephrine therapy

 

  • Norepinephrine is the vasopressor of choice for septic shock unresponsive to fluid resuscitation, helping to increase blood pressure by vasoconstriction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylephrine therapy: Phenylephrine is a second-line vasopressor with less cardiac support.

 

Option B. Dopamine therapy: Dopamine is less preferred due to arrhythmia risk.

 

Option C. Dobutamine therapy: Dobutamine is primarily an inotrope used in heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Norepinephrine is the vasopressor of choice for septic shock unresponsive to fluid resuscitation

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with type 1 diabetes mellitus for 10 years has been managing his condition with insulin therapy. Despite good compliance, his blood glucose levels remain high. After consulting a dietitian, he is advised to consume more high-fiber foods. Which of the following dietary fibers would help in maintaining normal blood glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pectin

 

  • Pectin is a soluble dietary fiber known for its ability to form a gel in the digestive tract.
  • This property slows down the absorption of sugar, leading to better control of blood glucose levels.
  • Soluble fibers like pectin can delay gastric emptying and reduce the rise in blood glucose levels following a meal, making it particularly beneficial for patients with diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemicellulose: Hemicellulose is a mixed type of dietary fiber that includes both soluble and insoluble fibers. While it can have some beneficial effects on digestive health, it does not have as significant an impact on blood glucose levels as soluble fibers like pectin.

 

Option B. Cellulose: Cellulose is an insoluble dietary fiber that helps in increasing stool bulk and improving bowel movements. It does not dissolve in water and thus does not form gels that can slow down glucose absorption, making it less effective for blood glucose control.

 

Option D. Lignin: Lignin is another type of insoluble fiber. It is not fermentable by gut bacteria and does not form gels. Therefore, it does not significantly affect blood glucose levels, unlike soluble fibers such as pectin.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Soluble fibers like pectin can help control blood glucose levels by slowing the absorption of sugar in the digestive tract.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child presents to the clinic for routine immunizations. You are reviewing the preservatives used in various vaccines. Which preservative is used for BCG and Measles vaccines?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No preservative used

 

  • BCG and Measles vaccines do not contain preservatives. These vaccines are typically lyophilized and reconstituted with a diluent immediately before administration to ensure safety and efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiomersal: A preservative used in some multi-dose vaccines (like DPT) to prevent bacterial and fungal growth, but not used in BCG and Measles vaccines.

 

Option B. Aluminium hydroxide: An adjuvant used to enhance the immune response in DPT vaccines, but not a preservative used in BCG and Measles vaccines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BCG and Measles vaccines do not contain preservatives, ensuring their safety and efficacy through lyophilization and immediate reconstitution.

questions.text: A patient present with an extensive soft tissue infection that has rapidly spread through the connective tissue. Laboratory tests confirm the presence of Streptococcus pyogenes. Which Streptococcus exoenzyme is primarily responsible for the breakdown of connective tissue, contributing to the spread of the infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyaluronidase

 

  • Hyaluronidase, sometimes referred to as "spreading factor," is an enzyme produced by certain bacteria, including Streptococci, which breaks down hyaluronic acid in connective tissue.
  • This degradation process allows the bacteria to penetrate and spread through tissues, facilitating the invasive nature of certain infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptolysin O: A hemolysin that is oxygen-labile and contributes to the lysis of red and white blood cells but is not primarily responsible for the breakdown of connective tissue.

 

Option C. Streptolysin S: A hemolysin that is oxygen-stable and also contributes to cell lysis but is not involved in breaking down connective tissue.

 

Option D. Streptococcus pyogenic exotoxin: These are superantigens that contribute to systemic effects like fever and shock but do not break down connective tissue.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Hyaluronidase is the exoenzyme produced by Streptococcus pyogenes that facilitates the breakdown of connective tissue, aiding in the spread of infection.

choices.text: Occurs in 10% of newborns
An indicator of considerably increased incidence of major malformation of the fetus
Equally common in newborns of diabetic and non-diabetic mothers

questions.text: A newborn's umbilical cord is examined after delivery, revealing the presence of a single umbilical artery. What does this finding indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) An indicator of considerably increased incidence of major malformation of the fetus

 

  • The presence of a single umbilical artery (SUA) is significant because it is associated with an increased risk of congenital anomalies.
  • SUA is found in approximately 0.5-1% of singleton pregnancies and about 5% of twin pregnancies.
  • This finding warrants further evaluation as it can be associated with major malformations, particularly of the cardiovascular, renal, and musculoskeletal systems.
  • It is an important marker that prompts careful examination of the newborn and possibly further investigations to rule out associated anomalies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insignificant: The presence of a single umbilical artery is not insignificant. It is a marker for potential congenital anomalies and should be investigated further.

 

Option B. Occurs in 10% of newborns: This statement is incorrect. SUA occurs in about 0.5-1% of singleton pregnancies, not 10%.

 

Option D. Equally common in newborns of diabetic and non-diabetic mothers: SUA can occur in both diabetic and non-diabetic mothers, but this option does not address the significance of the finding, which is the increased risk of congenital anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The finding of a single umbilical artery in the umbilical cord is an indicator of a considerably increased incidence of major malformations of the fetus, and it necessitates further evaluation for associated congenital anomalies.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with leg swelling, recurrent canker sores, and painful genital ulcers. Examination reveals evidence of deep vein thrombosis but no urethritis or conjunctivitis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Behcet syndrome

 

  • Behcet syndrome is characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, deep vein thrombosis, and inflammation throughout the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis: Ankylosing spondylitis affects the spine.

 

Option B. Polymyalgia rheumatic: Polymyalgia rheumatica causes muscle pain and stiffness.

 

Option D. Drug-induced lupus erythematous: Drug-induced lupus has different clinical features, including a specific drug history.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Behcet syndrome is characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, deep vein thrombosis, and inflammation throughout the body.

choices.text: PRIS is characterized by metabolic acidosis, rhabdomyolysis, and cardiac failure
It is more commonly seen in pediatric patients compared to adults
PRIS is associated with high-dose and long-duration propofol infusion, particularly in critically ill patients when dose exceeds > 4mg/kg/hour
Treatment of PRIS includes discontinuation of propofol infusion and supportive care measures

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding propofol infusion syndrome (PRIS) is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is more commonly seen in pediatric patients compared to adults

 

  • Incorrect. PRIS is actually more commonly seen in adults compared to pediatric patients.
  • While PRIS can occur in pediatric patients, it is relatively rare in this population.
  • Adults, especially those with critical illnesses or receiving high-dose propofol infusions for prolonged periods, are at higher risk of developing PRIS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PRIS is characterized by metabolic acidosis, rhabdomyolysis, and cardiac failure: Correct. Propofol infusion syndrome (PRIS) is characterized by metabolic acidosis, rhabdomyolysis, and cardiac failure. These manifestations can lead to significant morbidity and mortality, particularly in critically ill patients receiving high doses of propofol for extended durations.

 

Option C. PRIS is associated with high-dose and long-duration propofol infusion, particularly in critically ill patients when dose exceeds > 4mg/kg/hour: Correct. PRIS is indeed associated with high-dose and long-duration propofol infusion, particularly in critically ill patients such as those in the intensive care unit (ICU). Risk factors for PRIS include doses exceeding 4 mg/kg/hour and durations of infusion longer than 48 hours.

 

Option D. Treatment of PRIS includes discontinuation of propofol infusion and supportive care measures: Correct. Treatment of PRIS involves discontinuation of propofol infusion and supportive care measures. This includes addressing metabolic acidosis, electrolyte imbalances, and cardiac dysfunction. Supportive measures may include vasopressor therapy, renal replacement therapy for severe metabolic acidosis, and management of rhabdomyolysis-related complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Propofol infusion syndrome (PRIS) is a rare but potentially life-threatening complication associated with high-dose and long-duration propofol infusion, particularly in critically ill adult patients.
  • It is characterized by metabolic acidosis, rhabdomyolysis, and cardiac failure.
  • Treatment involves prompt discontinuation of propofol infusion and supportive care measures to manage the metabolic and cardiovascular complications of PRIS.

questions.text: A patient in the intensive care unit with an intravascular catheter develops signs of infection. The healthcare team suspects a bacterial infection and orders blood cultures. Which species of Pseudomonas is most commonly associated with intravascular catheter-related infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) P. aeruginosa

 

  • P. aeruginosa is the most common species of Pseudomonas associated with intravascular catheter-related infections.
  • This pathogen is known for its ability to form biofilms on medical devices, making it a frequent cause of infections in hospitalized patients with indwelling catheters.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P. cepacia: Also known as Burkholderia cepacia, it is less common in catheter-related infections and is more typically associated with respiratory infections in patients with cystic fibrosis.

 

Option C. P. maltophila: Now classified as Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, it is less common than P. aeruginosa in catheter-related infections but can still be a significant nosocomial pathogen.

 

Option D. P. mallei: This species causes glanders, a disease primarily affecting animals, and is rare in humans. It is not associated with intravascular catheter-related infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common species of Pseudomonas responsible for intravascular catheter-related infections, known for its biofilm formation on medical devices.

choices.text: Small apparent volume of distribution
Large apparent volume of distribution
Less excretion in urine
High excretion in saliva

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is started on a new medication. Initial pharmacokinetic studies suggest that the drug is being stored in the tissues. Which of the following findings would be most indicative of this?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Large apparent volume of distribution

 

  • A large apparent volume of distribution (Vd) indicates that a drug is extensively distributed into body tissues rather than remaining in the plasma.
  • This is characteristic of drugs that are stored in tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small apparent volume of distribution: This indicates that the drug remains mostly in the plasma, suggesting limited tissue storage.

 

Option C. Less excretion in urine: While reduced renal excretion can occur for various reasons, it does not specifically indicate tissue storage.

 

Option D. High excretion in saliva: This is not a common or specific marker for tissue storage of a drug.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Volume of distribution (Vd) signifies the distribution of drug in the tissues.
  • Low Vd mean less drug is distributed to tissues whereas high value of Vd means drug is being stored in some tissue.
  • A large apparent volume of distribution (Vd) suggests that a drug is extensively distributed into and stored in body tissues rather than remaining in the plasma.
  • Volume of distribution is the hypothetical volume of plasma that would be required to contain the administered dose if that dose was evenly distributed at the concentration measured in plasma.
  • If more amount of drug is entering the tissues, it has a higher volume of distribution and vice-a-versa.
  • It depends on several factors like lipid solubility and plasma protein binding.

choices.text: Estimation of time since death
Deciding the cause of death

questions.text: What is the primary use of Casper's dictum?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Estimation of time since death

 

  • Casper's dictum is a forensic principle that helps estimate the time since death by comparing the rates of decomposition under different conditions. According to this dictum, a body decomposes twice as fast in air as it does in water and eight times faster in air than in soil.
  • In this case, the body was found in water, indicating a slower rate of decomposition compared to air, which the medical officer uses to estimate the post-mortem interval.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Deciding the cause of death - This involves identifying the underlying disease or injury that led to death, which is not the purpose of Casper's dictum.

 

Option C. Manner of death - Determining the manner of death (e.g., natural, accidental, suicidal, or homicidal) requires a broader investigation and is not directly related to the decomposition rate.

 

Option D. Liquefaction of tissues - While tissue liquefaction is part of the decomposition process, Casper's dictum specifically addresses how quickly decomposition occurs in different environments, rather than focusing on this specific stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Casper's dictum is used primarily to estimate the time since death by analyzing the rate of decomposition in various environments.
  • This principle is crucial for forensic experts in establishing a timeline for death, especially when bodies are found in varying conditions like air, water, or soil.

questions.text: Match the Genital ulcer disease in Column A with its clinical presentation in Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

  • The correct match between the Viral organisms / infections in Column A with its Histopathological characteristic features in Column B

 

 

1. Donovanosis (Granuloma inguinale): This condition is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis and typically presents with painless, progressive ulcerative lesions without regional lymphadenopathy. Hence, the correct match for Donovanosis is "Lymphadenopathy absent" (b).

 

2. Chancre: The primary lesion of syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is typically a painless ulcer. Therefore, the correct match for Chancre is "Painless ulcer" (c).

 

3. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): Caused by certain serovars of Chlamydia trachomatis, LGV often presents with an initial transient genital ulcer that is often unnoticed, followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes). In the context of the given options, the match "Ulcer absent" (a) is appropriate for LGV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Donovanosis presents with lymphadenopathy absent, Chancre presents with a painless ulcer, and Lymphogranuloma venereum typically has a transient ulcer that may be absent during the examination.

choices.text: Fracture of Scaphoid has a Low incidence of Non Union
Scaphoid Bone Articulates with Five Bones totally
Scaphoid Bone can be easily Immobilized
Fracture Line on the Scaphoid Bone may deprive the Distal Fragment of its Arterial Supply

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency room after a fall from a height, landing on his outstretched left wrist. He reports pain and tenderness in the region of the anatomical snuffbox of his left hand. An X-ray confirms a fracture of the scaphoid bone. Which of the following statements about the scaphoid bone is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scaphoid Bone Articulates with Five Bones totally

 

  • The scaphoid bone is one of the carpal bones in the wrist and articulates with five bones: the radius, lunate, capitate, trapezium, and trapezoid.
  • This articulation allows for the complex range of movements in the wrist and hand.
  • Understanding the scaphoid bone's connections is crucial in diagnosing and treating wrist injuries effectively.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fracture of Scaphoid has a Low incidence of Non Union: This is incorrect because scaphoid fractures have a high incidence of non-union due to the bone's poor blood supply.

 

Option C. Scaphoid Bone can be easily Immobilized:  This is incorrect as immobilizing the scaphoid can be challenging due to its position and the wrist's movement.

 

Option D. Fracture Line on the Scaphoid Bone may deprive the Distal Fragment of its Arterial Supply:  This is incorrect; it is typically the proximal fragment that is at risk of avascular necrosis due to disruption in the blood supply.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scaphoid bone articulates with five bones: the radius, lunate, capitate, trapezium, and trapezoid, which is important for understanding wrist mechanics and injuries.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe eye irritation and unusual reddish tearing. He was found unconscious at his home, near a bottle labelled "Pesticide." On examination, the medical officer notes that the patient has pinpoint pupils and excessive salivation. Which of the following substances is most likely associated with chromolacryorrhea, observed in this case of poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Organophosphorus

 

  • Organophosphorus compounds, commonly used in pesticides, can cause a distinct clinical syndrome due to cholinesterase inhibition.
  • One of the key features of organophosphorus poisoning is chromolacryorrhea, which is the emission of reddish tears, along with other signs such as miosis (pinpoint pupils), excessive salivation, and muscle weakness.
  • These symptoms are part of the classic presentation of organophosphorus poisoning, which matches the scenario described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobra - Cobra venom primarily causes neurotoxic effects, such as paralysis, and does not typically result in chromolacryorrhea.

 

Option C. Dhatura - This plant contains anticholinergic substances like atropine and scopolamine, leading to dilated pupils and dry skin, opposite to the symptoms of cholinergic excess observed in the case.

 

Option D. Carbolic acid - Carbolic acid poisoning would cause burns and systemic toxicity but does not specifically cause chromolacryorrhea.

 

Educational Objective

 

Sign and Symptoms of OP Poisoning -

choices.text: PDPH typically presents with a dull, throbbing headache aggravated by sitting or standing.
The incidence of PDPH is higher with larger gauge needles used for lumbar puncture.
PDPH is caused by leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the dural puncture site.
PDPH is more commonly seen in patients with a history of migraine headaches.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PDPH is more commonly seen in patients with a history of migraine headaches.

 

  • Incorrect. PDPH is not typically associated with a history of migraine headaches.
  • While migraine headaches can have similar symptoms to PDPH, they are distinct entities with different underlying mechanisms and triggers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PDPH typically presents with a dull, throbbing headache aggravated by sitting or standing: Correct. PDPH often presents with a dull, throbbing headache that worsens upon assuming an upright position, such as sitting or standing. This positional component is characteristic of PDPH.

 

Option B. The incidence of PDPH is higher with larger gauge needles used for lumbar puncture: Correct. The incidence of PDPH is indeed higher when larger gauge needles are used for lumbar puncture. Larger needles create a larger hole in the dura, increasing the likelihood of CSF leakage and subsequent headache.

 

Option C. PDPH is caused by leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the dural puncture site: Correct. PDPH is caused by leakage of CSF from the dural puncture site. This leakage leads to a decrease in CSF volume and intracranial pressure, resulting in characteristic symptoms of PDPH. D)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is a common complication following lumbar puncture, characterized by a positional headache aggravated by sitting or standing.
  • The incidence of PDPH is higher with the use of larger gauge needles, and it is caused by leakage of cerebrospinal fluid from the dural puncture site.
  • Unlike migraine headaches, PDPH is not typically associated with a history of migraine headaches.

choices.text: Originates from the Anterior Tibial Artery and Enters the Tibia on its Anterior Surface
Originates from the Posterior Tibial Artery and Enters the Tibia on its Posterior Surface
Originates from the Fibular Artery and Enters the Tibia on its Lateral Surface
Originates from the Popliteal Artery and Enters the Tibia on its Posterior Surface

questions.text: During the assessment of bone healing in a patient with a tibial fracture, the focus is on ensuring a robust blood supply for effective recovery. Which of the following accurately describes the source and point of entry of the nutrient artery responsible for supplying the tibia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Originates from the Posterior Tibial Artery and Enters the Tibia on its Posterior Surface

 

 

  • The nutrient artery of the tibia is a crucial vessel that provides blood supply to the inner two-thirds of the cortical bone.
  • This artery typically originates from the posterior tibial artery, which is located behind the knee. The nutrient artery enters the tibia on its posterior surface through a nutrient foramen located in the proximal third of the bone.
  • This anatomical arrangement ensures adequate blood flow to the tibia, which is vital for bone health and repair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Originates from the Anterior Tibial Artery and Enters the Tibia on its Anterior Surface:  This is incorrect because the anterior tibial artery does not give rise to the nutrient artery of the tibia, nor does it enter on the anterior surface.

 

Option C. Originates from the Fibular Artery and Enters the Tibia on its Lateral Surface: This is incorrect as the fibular artery supplies the fibula, not the tibia.

 

Option D. Originates from the Popliteal Artery and Enters the Tibia on its Posterior Surface. Popliteal artery is not the common source for the origin of nutrient artery of tibia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The nutrient artery of the tibia originates from the  posterior tibial artery and enters the tibia on its posterior surface, providing essential blood supply to the inner two-thirds of the bone's cortex.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man worked in a chemical plant for over 30 years and retired 5 years ago. He has recently been diagnosed with fatigue, easy bruising, and frequent infections. Given his prolonged exposure to chemicals in the plant, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blood cancer

 

  • Long-term exposure to chemicals such as benzene, which is commonly found in industrial settings, significantly increases the risk of developing hematologic malignancies, such as leukemia and other types of blood cancer.
  • Benzene is a well-known carcinogen affecting the bone marrow and leading to disorders of the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skin cancer: Benzene exposure is not typically associated with skin cancer. Skin cancers are more commonly related to UV radiation and certain chemicals.

 

Option B. Lung cancer: Although exposure to various industrial chemicals can increase the risk of lung cancer, benzene specifically is more strongly linked to blood cancers.

 

Option C. Bladder cancer: Bladder cancer is usually associated with exposure to certain industrial chemicals like aromatic amines, rather than benzene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prolonged exposure to industrial chemicals such as benzene primarily increases the risk of developing blood cancers, including leukemia. Recognizing the health risks associated with specific occupational exposures is essential for early diagnosis, prevention, and appropriate management of related diseases.
  • Note - IARC classifies benzene as “carcinogenic to humans,” based on sufficient evidence that benzene causes acute myeloid leukemia (AML)
  • IARC also notes that benzene exposure has been linked with acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL), chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), multiple myeloma, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with chest pain after an RTA has BP 74/50 mm/ Hg, PR 126 bpm, and diminished lung sounds on the right. Hematocrit is 43.2%. What other finding is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tracheal deviation

 

  • Tension pneumothorax causes hypotension, tachycardia, tracheal and mediastinal shift away from the affected side.
  • Auscultation would reveal a reduced air entry and percussion would reveal an hyper-resonant note on the involved side.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Increase in tactile fremitus: Tactile fremitus decreases with pneumothorax.

 

Option B. Kussmaul sign: Kussmaul sign is seen in cardiac conditions.

 

Option C. Muffled heart sounds: Muffled heart sounds are in cardiac tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tension pneumothorax causes hypotension, tachycardia, tracheal and mediastinal shift away from the affected side

questions.text: The Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon is a characteristic finding seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital stationary night blindness (CSNB)

 

  • The Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon is typically observed in patients with CSNB, particularly the Oguchi disease variant.
  • This phenomenon is characterized by a unique change in the color of the retina from a golden or grayish appearance in the dark-adapted state to a normal reddish color upon light exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. X-linked retinitis pigmentosa: This condition involves progressive vision loss due to degeneration of the retina but does not show the Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon.

 

Option C. Congenital cone dystrophy: This condition affects the cone cells of the retina, leading to impaired color vision and central vision loss, but does not show the Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon.

 

Option D. Leber congenital amaurosis: This is a severe retinal dystrophy that leads to blindness or severe visual impairment from birth but does not exhibit the Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mizuo-Nakamura phenomenon is characteristic of congenital stationary night blindness (CSNB), particularly Oguchi disease, and involves a reversible change in the color of the retina upon light

choices.text: Supportive psychotherapy focused on providing emotional support and encouragement.
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) with a focus on Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP).
Psychodynamic psychotherapy to explore unconscious conflicts and childhood experiences.
Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) aimed at managing distress and improving emotional regulation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to a psychiatric clinic complaining of recurrent and intrusive thoughts that her hands are contaminated despite repeated washing since past 2 years. These thoughts led to repeated hand washing, which occupies several hours of her day, significantly impairing her social and occupational functioning. She reports experiencing significant distress from these thoughts, and her hands are visibly chapped and bleeding. Which of the following psychotherapeutic interventions is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) with a focus on Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP)

 

  • For a patient displaying classic symptoms of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), including recurrent, intrusive thoughts about contamination and compulsive handwashing, CBT with ERP is the optimal treatment.
  • This approach specifically targets OCD symptoms by exposing patients to their fear triggers (contamination in this case) without allowing the compulsive behavior (handwashing), effectively teaching them to manage their anxiety and reduce compulsive responses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supportive psychotherapy focused on providing emotional support and encouragement: While supportive, does not address the specific behavioral mechanisms of OCD.

 

Option C. Psychodynamic psychotherapy to explore unconscious conflicts and childhood experiences: More focused on underlying emotional conflicts, less immediate in managing OCD symptoms.

 

Option D. Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) aimed at managing distress and improving emotional regulation: Mainly used for disorders involving emotional dysregulation, not specifically designed for OCD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CBT with ERP is specifically tailored to treat OCD by breaking the cycle of obsessive thoughts and compulsive actions, making it the most effective psychotherapeutic intervention for reducing OCD symptoms and improving functional outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following interferons is primarily produced by fibroblasts and is stable at pH 2.0?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IFN-β

 

  • IFN-β is primarily produced by fibroblasts and is known as fibroblast interferon.
  •  It is classified as a Type I interferon and is stable at pH 2.0.
  • IFN-β has antiviral activity, increases MHC class I expression, and has immunoregulatory functions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. IFN-α: Produced mainly by macrophages, known as leukocyte interferon, also stable at pH 2.0, and classified as Type I interferon.

 

Option C. IFN-γ: Produced by lymphocytes, particularly Th1 cells, and is labile at pH 2.0, classified as Type II interferon.

 

Option D. IFN-λ: Not listed in the provided information and generally refers to another family of interferons (Type III), not included in this context.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis
Colloid goitre

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with lethargy, weight gain, and a bosselated goiter. She underwent an excision biopsy which revealed the histological findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis

 

  • The biopsy image shows lymphoid follicles with germinal centers in thyroid gland, characteristic of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis.
  • This autoimmune disorder typically presents with symptoms of hypothyroidism such as weight gain and lethargy, and histologically it is marked by lymphocytic infiltration and the presence of Hurthle cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Viral thyroiditis: Incorrect because it generally presents acutely with pain in the thyroid region and tends to show a more inflammatory response with neutrophils or a mixed cellular infiltrate rather than lymphocytic predominance and Hurthle cells.

 

Option C. Colloid goitre: Incorrect as colloid goitres primarily exhibit distended follicles filled with colloid and a flat epithelial lining rather than lymphocytic infiltration and Hurthle cells.

 

Option D. Riedel’s thyroiditis: Incorrect because Riedel's thyroiditis is a rare fibrosing condition that presents with a hard, woody texture of the thyroid gland on examination, and histology typically shows extensive fibrosis, which is not evident in the provided biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is an autoimmune thyroid disorder characterized by the presence of lymphocytic infiltration, Hurthle cells, and germinal centers in the thyroid gland.
  • Patients commonly present with symptoms of hypothyroidism. Diagnosis can be supported by serology showing elevated thyroid antibodies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic with multiple painful genital ulcers. She reports that the ulcers appeared a few days ago, accompanied by fever and inguinal lymphadenopathy. On physical examination, you observe several irregular, shallow ulcers with a purulent base and ragged edges. Which organism is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Haemophilus ducreyi

 

  •  Haemophilus ducreyi is the causative agent of chancroid, which typically presents with multiple painful genital ulcers.
  • The ulcers are irregular, shallow, and have a purulent base with ragged edges.
  • This presentation, along with fever and inguinal lymphadenopathy, strongly suggests Haemophilus ducreyi.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV): Typically causes painful vesicles and ulcers, but they are usually grouped and not as irregular or purulent as those seen in chancroid.

 

Option C. Treponema pallidum: Causes syphilis, which typically presents with a single painless ulcer (chancre), not multiple painful ulcers.

 

Option D.  Klebsiella granulomatis: Causes granuloma inguinale (donovanosis), which usually presents with painless ulcers that tend to be beefy red and bleed easily, not the painful, purulent ulcers described here.

 

Differential diagnoses 

 

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Remove IUCD and terminate pregnancy
