questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) in place becomes pregnant. On examination, the tail of the IUCD is visible. What should be the next course of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Remove the IUCD

 

  • If a woman with an IUCD becomes pregnant and the tail of the IUCD is visible, the recommended course of action is to remove the IUCD.
  • Removing the IUCD decreases the risk of complications such as infection, miscarriage, and preterm delivery.
  • The removal is generally recommended as soon as possible, regardless of the patient's decision to continue or terminate the pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy): This option is not necessary solely based on the presence of an IUCD. The decision to terminate the pregnancy should be based on the patient’s wishes and other clinical considerations

 

Option C. Continue the pregnancy: While continuing the pregnancy is possible, it is preferable to remove the IUCD to reduce the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes.

 

Option D. Remove IUCD and terminate pregnancy: Termination of pregnancy is not automatically indicated just because an IUCD is present. The removal of the IUCD should be done to minimize risks, but the decision to terminate the pregnancy should be based on other factors and the patient's choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a pregnant woman with a visible IUCD tail, the IUCD should be removed to reduce the risk of pregnancy complications.
  • This action should be taken regardless of whether the pregnancy will be continued or terminated.

choices.text: Supine hypotension syndrome occurs due to compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) by the gravid uterus.
It typically presents with symptoms such as lightheadedness, nausea, and hypotension.
Treatment involves placing the patient in the right lateral tilt position to relieve pressure on the IVC.
Supine hypotension syndrome can be relieved by placing a wedge below the right hip.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding supine hypotension syndrome in obstetric anesthesia is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Treatment involves placing the patient in the right lateral tilt position to relieve pressure on the IVC.

 

  • Incorrect. Treatment for supine hypotension syndrome involves placing the patient in the left lateral tilt position, not the right lateral tilt position.
  • This left lateral tilt position shifts the gravid uterus off the IVC, relieving compression and restoring venous return and cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supine hypotension syndrome occurs due to compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) by the gravid uterus: Correct. Supine hypotension syndrome occurs due to compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) by the gravid uterus when the pregnant patient is in the supine position. This compression reduces venous return to the heart, leading to hypotension.

 

Option B. It typically presents with symptoms such as lightheadedness, nausea, and hypotension: Correct. Typical symptoms of supine hypotension syndrome include lightheadedness, nausea, and hypotension. These symptoms result from decreased cardiac output and blood pressure secondary to decreased venous return.

 

Option D. Supine hypotension syndrome can be relieved by placing a wedge below the right hip: Correct. Supine hypotension syndrome can indeed be relieved by placing a wedge below the right hip. This maneuver tilts the patient slightly to the left, reducing compression on the IVC by the gravid uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Supine hypotension syndrome in obstetric anesthesia occurs due to compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) by the gravid uterus when the patient is in the supine position.
  • Treatment involves placing the patient in the left lateral tilt position or placing a wedge below the right hip to relieve pressure on the IVC.
  • This helps restore venous return and cardiac output, alleviating symptoms of hypotension.

questions.text: A primigravida at full term complains of feeling faint when lying down but feels well when turning to the side or sitting up. What is the most likely cause of this symptom?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IVC compression

 

  • The faintness experienced by a full-term pregnant woman when lying down is most likely due to compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) by the gravid uterus.
  • This condition, known as supine hypotensive syndrome, occurs because the large uterus compresses the IVC when the woman is in a supine position, leading to reduced venous return to the heart and decreased cardiac output.
  • This can cause symptoms of hypotension, such as faintness or dizziness, which are relieved by turning to the side or sitting up.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Increased intracranial pressure: Increased intracranial pressure is not related to changes in body position during pregnancy and does not cause positional faintness.

 

Option C. After heavy lunch: While eating a heavy meal can cause some discomfort, it does not specifically lead to faintness when lying down and is unrelated to the positional changes described.

 

Option D. Increased abdominal pressure: Increased abdominal pressure occurs during pregnancy but does not directly cause faintness when lying down. The faintness is specifically due to IVC compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The faintness experienced by a full-term pregnant woman when lying down is due to inferior vena cava (IVC) compression by the gravid uterus, a condition known as supine hypotensive syndrome.
  • This can be alleviated by turning to the side or sitting up.

choices.text: Uncuffed endotracheal tubes are commonly used in infants and young children to minimize the risk of airway trauma.
The use of uncuffed tubes in children is associated with a lower incidence of post-extubation stridor.
Uncuffed tubes provide a better seal and protection against aspiration compared to cuffed tubes
Narrowest part in pediatric airway is subglottic area.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the use of uncuffed endotracheal tubes in children is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uncuffed tubes provide a better seal and protection against aspiration compared to cuffed tubes

 

  • Incorrect. Uncuffed tubes do not necessarily provide a better seal and protection against aspiration compared to cuffed tubes.
  • Cuffed tubes, when appropriately sized and inflated, can provide a more secure seal, especially in children with larger airways or those at risk of aspiration.
  • The cuff helps in protecting against aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uncuffed endotracheal tubes are commonly used in infants and young children to minimize the risk of airway trauma: Correct. Uncuffed endotracheal tubes are commonly used in infants and young children to minimize the risk of airway trauma. The smaller size of the uncuffed tubes reduces the likelihood of causing damage to the delicate pediatric airway during intubation.

 

Option B. The use of uncuffed tubes in children is associated with a lower incidence of post-extubation stridor: Correct. The use of uncuffed tubes in children is indeed associated with a lower incidence of post-extubation stridor. This is because uncuffed tubes cause less mucosal trauma during intubation, reducing the risk of inflammation and subsequent stridor upon extubation.

 

Option D. Narrowest part in pediatric airway is subglottic area: Correct. The narrowest part of the pediatric airway is indeed the subglottic area, specifically the cricoid cartilage. This is an important consideration when selecting the appropriate size and type of endotracheal tube for pediatric intubation to prevent airway obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uncuffed endotracheal tubes are commonly used in infants and young children to minimize the risk of airway trauma and post-extubation stridor.
  • While they may not provide a better seal compared to cuffed tubes, they are preferred in situations where minimizing trauma to the pediatric airway is crucial.
  • The narrowest part of the pediatric airway is the subglottic area, which should be considered when selecting the appropriate size and type of endotracheal tube for pediatric intubation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male is prepared for a surgical procedure under general anesthesia. The surgical team positions him according to the requirements of the procedure. Which of the following best describes the patient's position?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left lateral decubitus position

 

  • The left lateral decubitus position involves the patient lying on their left side, which is often used for surgical access to the right side of the body or for certain medical examinations.
  • This position can be identified by the left side of the body being in contact with the operating table, and the right side facing upwards.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right lateral decubitus position: Incorrect – patient should be lying on their right side.

 

Option B. Sims position: Incorrect – Sims left lateral position also required the hips to be flexed. It is used in digital rectal examination.

 

Option D. Trendelenburg position: Incorrect - The Trendelenburg position involves the patient being laid back on an incline with feet higher than the head, which does not match the side-lying description.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The left lateral decubitus position is critical for procedures requiring access to the right-hand side of the body or where gravitational repositioning of organs is beneficial.
  • Recognizing and correctly setting up this position ensures optimal surgical outcomes and patient safety.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient undergoing radiation therapy for head and neck cancer is prescribed a medication to reduce the toxicity of the radiation. Which of the following drugs acts as a radioprotector?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amifostine

 

  • Amifostine is a radioprotector approved by the FDA to reduce the toxicities of radiation therapy.
  • It works by scavenging free radicals produced by radiation, thereby protecting normal tissues from radiation-induced damage.
  • Amifostine is also used to mitigate cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity and radiation-induced xerostomia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colony stimulating factor: Colony stimulating factors are used to manage chemotherapy-induced leucopenia but do not protect against radiation-induced toxicity.

 

Option C. Cisplatin: Cisplatin is a chemotherapeutic agent that can cause nephrotoxicity, and its toxicity can be reduced by using amifostine, but cisplatin itself is not a radioprotector.

 

Option D. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a chemotherapeutic agent and immunosuppressant that does not have radioprotective properties.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Amifostine is a radioprotector that reduces the toxicities of radiation therapy by scavenging free radicals.
  • It is used prophylactically before radiation exposure to protect normal tissues from damage.
  • Understanding the role and mechanism of radioprotective agents is crucial in managing patients undergoing radiation therapy.

choices.text: Donor T cells in the graft

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with multiple myeloma develops a pruritic rash, abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and jaundice after an allogeneic stem cell transplant. Examination shows a generalized maculopapular rash, desquamation of the soles, and elevated liver enzymes. What is the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Donor T cells in the graft

 

  • Acute graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) is caused by donor T cells attacking the recipient's tissues, commonly affecting the skin, liver, and intestines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Newly formed anti-HLA antibodies: Anti-HLA antibodies mediate humoral rejection, not GvHD.

 

Option C. Proliferating transplanted B cells: Proliferating B cells are more associated with chronic GvHD.

 

Option D. Activated recipient T cells: Recipient T cells cause graft rejection, not GvHD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) is caused by donor T cells attacking the recipient's tissues, commonly affecting the skin, liver, and intestines.

questions.text: In a neuroanatomy class the professor is teaching the projections of different brain structures into thalamic nuclei. The instructor points to a structure labeled by an arrow in the image and asks about its thalamic connections. The indicated structure projects into which thalamic nucleus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior

 

  • The structure indicated by the arrow in the image is the mammillary body, part of the hypothalamus.
  •  The mammillary bodies project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus via the mammillothalamic tract.
  • The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is involved in the limbic system, particularly in processes related to memory and emotional regulation.
  • The fornix projects from hippocampus to mammillary body.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventrolateral: This nucleus primarily receives input from the cerebellum and is involved in motor control.

 

Option C. Ventral Anterior: This nucleus receives input from the basal ganglia and is involved in planning and initiating movement.

 

Option D. Ventral Posterolateral: This nucleus receives sensory input from the body, not input from the mammillary bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mammillary bodies project into the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, which is part of the limbic system and plays a role in memory and emotional regulation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with multiple rashes on her ankle, as shown in the image. She reports that she recently returned from a hiking trip in a rural area of Tamil nadu. She also complains of fever, headache, and body aches. Based on the history and examination, which of the following vectors is most likely responsible for the transmission of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chigger

 

  • Chigger: Chiggers, the larval stage of trombiculid mites, are the vectors for Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus.
  • The presence of erythematous papules, fever, headache, and a history of hiking in rural Southeast Asia are consistent with scrub typhus.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Flea: Fleas are vectors for diseases such as plague (caused by Yersinia pestis) but are not associated with the presentation seen here.

 

Option C. Tick: Ticks are vectors for several other diseases, including Lyme disease (caused by Borrelia burgdorferi) and ehrlichiosis, but not scrub typhus.

 

Option D.  Mosquito: Mosquitoes are vectors for diseases such as malaria, dengue, and Zika virus, but are not associated with the presentation seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chiggers, the larval stage of trombiculid mites, are the vectors for Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus. This disease is characterized by erythematous papules, fever, and a history of exposure in rural areas, particularly in Southeast Asia.

questions.text:
A 4-week-old infant presents with projectile vomiting after feeding and poor weight gain. On examination, the pediatrician notes a palpable olive-like mass in the abdomen. Based on these findings, which of the following are associated with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?

 

  1. Bilious vomiting
  2. Palpable abdominal mass in the right hypochondrium in a relaxed baby
  3. Visible peristalsis in the abdomen from right to left
  4. Hypokalemic alkalosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) II, IV are correct

 

  • Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) is characterized by hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter, leading to progressive gastric outlet obstruction.
  • Common features include a palpable abdominal mass (often described as an "olive") and hypokalemic alkalosis due to the loss of stomach acid from persistent vomiting.
  • The vomiting is typically projectile and non-bilious since the obstruction is proximal to the bile entry into the intestine.

 

II. Correct - A palpable abdominal mass, often described as an "olive," is a classic sign of IHPS.

 

IV. Correct - Hypokalemic alkalosis occurs due to the loss of hydrochloric acid from vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

I. Incorrect - Vomiting in IHPS is non-bilious because the blockage occurs before bile enters the stomach.

 

III. Incorrect - Peristalsis in IHPS is visible moving from left to right, not right to left, due to the location of the pyloric mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is characterized by non-bilious projectile vomiting, a palpable "olive-like" abdominal mass, and can lead to hypokalemic alkalosis due to excessive vomiting.
  • Visible peristalsis should be observed moving from left to right.

choices.text: Begin isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol therapy
Order CT-guided transthoracic needle biopsy
Begin metronidazole therapy
Begin ampicillin/sulbactam therapy

questions.text: A 41-year-old man with shortness of breath, fever, and foul-smelling sputum has dullness to percussion over the right middle lung field. Chest X-ray is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Begin ampicillin/sulbactam therapy

 

  • X-ray shows typical signs of a lung abscess (thick walled cavity with air fluid levels).
  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics with anaerobic coverage, like ampicillin/sulbactam, are used for lung abscesses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Begin isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol therapy: TB treatment is for confirmed cases, not suspected lung abscess.

 

Option B. Order CT-guided transthoracic needle biopsy: Biopsy is for suspected malignancies.

 

Option C. Begin metronidazole therapy: Metronidazole is used with other antibiotics, not alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics with anaerobic coverage, like ampicillin/sulbactam, are used for lung abscesses.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with symptoms of a severe bacterial respiratory infection. The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease, so the physician decides to prescribe an antibiotic that is highly effective when taken orally and will require careful dose adjustment due to his renal impairment. Which of the following fluoroquinolones is most appropriate for this patient due to its highest oral bioavailability?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Levofloxacin

 

  • Levofloxacin has the highest oral bioavailability among fluoroquinolones, nearly 100%, which ensures that the drug is highly effective when taken orally.
  • It is excreted primarily through renal tubular secretion, so dose adjustment is necessary in patients with renal impairment.
  • This makes levofloxacin a suitable choice for patients who need effective systemic treatment with consideration for renal function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gemifloxacin: Gemifloxacin has good oral bioavailability but not as high as levofloxacin. Like levofloxacin, its absorption can be affected by multivalent cations.

 

Option C. Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin has moderate oral bioavailability (approximately 70-80%). It also requires dose adjustment in renal impairment due to renal excretion.

 

Option D. Norfloxacin: Norfloxacin has the lowest oral bioavailability among these options and is primarily used for treating urinary tract infections rather than systemic infections due to its poor systemic absorption.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Levofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone with nearly 100% oral bioavailability, is highly effective for treating systemic infections when taken orally.
  • It is excreted via renal tubular secretion, requiring dose adjustment in patients with renal impairment.
  • Understanding the pharmacokinetics of fluoroquinolones, including their bioavailability and excretion routes, is essential for optimizing antibiotic therapy, especially in patients with compromised renal function.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with symptoms suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy. During surgical exploration, the pregnancy is found to be in the abdominal cavity. What diagnostic criteria are used to confirm primary abdominal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Studdiford criteria

 

  • The Studdiford criteria are used to diagnose primary abdominal pregnancy. These criteria include:
  1. Normal tubes and ovaries with no evidence of a tubal pregnancy.
  2. Absence of uteroperitoneal fistula.
  3. The pregnancy must be related solely to the peritoneal surface and be early enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation following a primary nidation in the tube.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Spigelberg criteria: These criteria are related to ovarian pregnancies, not abdominal pregnancies.

 

Option B. Rubin’s criteria: Rubin’s criteria are used for diagnosing tubal pregnancies.

 

Option D. Wrigley criteria: There are no widely recognized Wrigley criteria related to the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Studdiford criteria are the diagnostic criteria for primary abdominal pregnancy, focusing on the exclusion of other sites of ectopic implantation and confirming the implantation on the peritoneal surface.

questions.text: Features of McCune Albright Syndrome are:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

  • This option indicates that all of the listed features (precocious puberty, Shepherd's crook deformity, and café-au-lait spots) are characteristic manifestations of McCune-Albright syndrome (MAS).
  • MAS is defined by the presence of precocious puberty due to endocrine abnormalities, skeletal abnormalities such as Shepherd's crook deformity resulting from fibrous dysplasia, and café-au-lait spots due to melanin deposition in the skin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Precocious Puberty: Precocious puberty refers to the onset of puberty at an abnormally early age, typically before 8 years in girls and before 9 years in boys. In MAS, precocious puberty is one of the most common and earliest presenting features, affecting both girls and boys. It results from the overproduction of sex hormones due to autonomous activation of ovarian or testicular tissue. Precocious puberty is a hallmark feature of MAS and is often one of the earliest signs observed in patients with fibrous dysplasia. It may manifest as breast development, pubic hair growth, accelerated linear growth, and skeletal maturation at an unusually young age.

 

Option B. Shepherd's Crook Deformity: Shepherd's crook deformity is a skeletal manifestation characterized by a marked bowing of the femoral neck, resulting in an exaggerated angulation resembling the shape of a shepherd's crook. This deformity occurs due to fibrous dysplasia, a common skeletal manifestation of MAS. It can lead to pain, limping, and functional impairment, especially as the child grows and weight-bearing increases.

 

Option C. Café-au-lait Spots: Café-au-lait spots are pigmented skin lesions characterized by well-defined, light to dark brown patches with smooth borders. These spots are typically oval or rounded in shape and vary in size. Café-au-lait spots are a common feature of many genetic syndromes, including MAS. Café-au-lait spots are often present from birth or early childhood. They can appear on any part of the body and are caused by increased melanin deposition in the skin. The presence of multiple café-au-lait spots can raise suspicion for MAS, especially when accompanied by other clinical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • All the given options i.e., precocious puberty, shepherd’s crook deformity, and café-au-lait spots are the features of the McCune Albright Syndrome.

questions.text: A newborn presents with microcephaly, and imaging reveals calcifications at the gray matter-white matter junction. The physician suspects congenital Zika virus infection and needs to select the best imaging modality to confirm the diagnosis. What is the investigation of choice to detect congenital Zika virus infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) NCCT (Non-Contrast Computed Tomography)

 

  • NCCT (Non-Contrast Computed Tomography) is effective in detecting calcifications within the brain, which are characteristic of congenital Zika virus infection.
  • NCCT is particularly useful for identifying intracranial calcifications, which are a hallmark of this infection.
  • It is a widely available, quick, and cost-effective method for identifying these calcifications and confirming the diagnosis of congenital Zika virus infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI: While MRI is excellent for detailed brain imaging and can identify many abnormalities associated with congenital infections, NCCT is more sensitive in detecting calcifications specifically, which are critical in the diagnosis of congenital Zika virus infection.

 

Option B. X-ray: X-ray imaging is not suitable for detecting intracranial calcifications or brain abnormalities associated with congenital Zika virus infection.

 

Option C. CT angiography: CT angiography focuses on blood vessels and is not appropriate for detecting brain parenchymal calcifications or diagnosing congenital infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NCCT is the preferred investigation for detecting calcifications in the brain, a key feature of congenital Zika virus infection, making it the best choice for confirming this diagnosis.

choices.text: To take warfarin after delivery
Compulsory prophylaxis with warfarin starting at 10 weeks
Chance of thromboembolism increases by 12% in next pregnancy

questions.text: 32-year-old pregnant woman with a history of thromboembolism during the postpartum period is seeking advice on managing her condition during her current pregnancy. What is the most appropriate medical management to prevent postpartum thromboembolism in this pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) To take warfarin after delivery

 

  • Warfarin is an anticoagulant that is typically avoided during pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects but can be safely used in the postpartum period to prevent thromboembolism.
  • In a woman with a history of thromboembolism, postpartum anticoagulation with warfarin is an appropriate strategy to prevent recurrence.
  • The period after delivery is a high-risk time for thromboembolism, and warfarin provides effective anticoagulation during this period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Does not need anything: This is incorrect because a history of thromboembolism significantly increases the risk of recurrence, particularly in the postpartum period. Prophylactic anticoagulation is necessary.

 

Option C. Compulsory prophylaxis with warfarin starting at 10 weeks: Warfarin is contraindicated during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester, due to its teratogenic effects. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is the preferred anticoagulant during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Chance of thromboembolism increases by 12% in next pregnancy: While it is true that the risk of thromboembolism increases in subsequent pregnancies, this statement does not address the appropriate management or prophylaxis strategy for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a pregnant woman with a history of thromboembolism, the most appropriate medical management to prevent postpartum thromboembolism is to initiate warfarin therapy after delivery.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man with alcohol dependence is admitted to the emergency department displaying severe agitation, confusion, and hallucinations. He reports that his last drink was over 48 hours ago. His vital signs show tachycardia and hypertension. What is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this patient?

 

  1. Intravenous Lorazepam
  2. Parenteral Thiamine
  3. Intravenous Haloperidol
  4. Oral Diazepam
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 & 2

 

  • The patient's presentation of severe agitation, confusion, hallucinations, tachycardia, and hypertension after a significant period without alcohol suggests alcohol withdrawal delirium, a severe form of alcohol withdrawal.
  • Immediate treatment with intravenous lorazepam is indicated to manage the acute symptoms of withdrawal.
  • Concurrently, parenteral thiamine is essential to prevent Wernicke's encephalopathy, a critical complication in alcohol-dependent patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 2 & 3: Including intravenous haloperidol is less advisable initially due to potential complications such as lowering the seizure threshold.

 

Option C. 2, 3 & 4: This choice does not prioritize the immediate control of withdrawal symptoms through appropriate sedation and includes less optimal management strategies.

 

Option D. 1 & 3: Excludes thiamine, crucial for preventing severe neurological outcomes, making it an incomplete approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For severe alcohol withdrawal symptoms like alcohol withdrawal delirium, the optimal initial management includes administering intravenous benzodiazepines for symptom control and parenteral thiamine to prevent neurological damage.

questions.text:
Which of the following diseases typically have an incubation period of 10-15 days?

 

  1. Chickenpox
  2. Rubella
  3. Hepatitis A
  4. Dengue
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 2

 

Explanation:

 

  • 1. Chickenpox: The incubation period for chickenpox (varicella) is typically 10-21 days, commonly around 14 days.
  • 2. Rubella: The incubation period for rubella is typically 14-21 days, with many cases falling within the 10-14-day range.

 

Other Options:

 

  • 3. Hepatitis A: The incubation period for hepatitis A ranges from 15-45 days.
  • 4. Dengue: The incubation period for dengue fever is typically 3-10 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chickenpox and rubella are examples of infectious diseases with typical incubation periods within the range of 10-14 days.
  • Accurate knowledge of incubation periods is essential for implementing effective quarantine measures and controlling the spread of infectious diseases.

questions.text: Match the structure of ear with its embryological origin:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The above table gives various structures of the ear and their embryological origin.

questions.text: Based on the provided image, which type of country does this age pyramid most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Developed countries

 

  • The age pyramid shown in the image is characteristic of developed countries.
  • These countries typically have a more balanced distribution of population across different age groups, with a larger proportion of elderly individuals.
  • The shape indicates lower birth and death rates, consistent with a stable or slowly growing population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Developing countries: Developing countries often have a broad base in their age pyramids, indicating a higher birth rate and a larger proportion of younger individuals.

 

Option C. Underdeveloped countries: Underdeveloped countries also tend to have pyramids with a broad base, reflecting high birth rates and higher mortality rates among younger age groups.

 

Option D. Countries in transition: Countries in transition may show characteristics between developing and developed countries, with a somewhat broader base but also a significant proportion of older individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Utility of Population pyramid:

 

  1. Shape of population pyramid indicates fertility pattern
  • Broad base, Narrow top (upright triangle): High proportion of younger population (developing countries)
  • Bulge in Middle, Spindle shape: High proportion of adults (developed countries)
  1. Span (height) of population pyramid indicates life expectancy
  • Taller pyramid: Higher life expectancy (developed countries)
  • Shorter pyramid: Lower life expectancy (developing countries)
  1. Symmetry of population pyramid indicates sex ratio
  • Symmetric pyramid: ideal sex ratio (developed countries)
  • Asymmetric pyramid: unfavourable sex ratio <1000 (developing countries)

choices.text: Superior and lateral position eyeball

questions.text: A patient present with symptoms suggestive of oculomotor nerve palsy. All of the following are seen in oculomotor nerve palsy except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superior and lateral position eyeball

 

  • This is incorrect. In oculomotor nerve palsy, the eyeball typically deviates downwards and outwards (inferolaterally) due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles, which are innervated by the abducens and trochlear nerves, respectively.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Ptosis: The oculomotor nerve innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which elevates the eyelid. Damage to this nerve results in ptosis (drooping of the eyelid).

 

Option B. Pupillary dilatation: The oculomotor nerve carries parasympathetic fibers to the pupil. Palsy of this nerve results in unopposed sympathetic activity, causing pupillary dilatation (mydriasis).

 

Option D. Light reflex absent: The oculomotor nerve is involved in the pupillary light reflex. Damage to this nerve can result in an absent light reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oculomotor nerve palsy results in ptosis, pupillary dilatation, and an absent light reflex.
  • The characteristic position of the eyeball in this condition is inferolateral, not superior and lateral.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an adverse effect of SGLT2 inhibitors?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Angioedema

 

  • Angioedema is not commonly reported as an adverse effect of SGLT2 inhibitors.
  • It is more commonly associated with other drug classes, such as ACE inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketoacidosis: SGLT2 inhibitors can lead to euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis, particularly in patients with type 1 diabetes or those who significantly reduce their insulin dose.

 

Option B. Urosepsis: These medications increase glucose excretion in the urine, which can predispose patients to urinary tract infections (UTIs), including severe cases such as urosepsis.

 

Option C. Fournier’s gangrene: SGLT2 inhibitors have been associated with rare cases of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum, known as Fournier’s gangrene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sodium Glucose Transporter 2 (also called SGLT2) is a transporter for reabsorption of glucose and Na+.
  • It is present in PCT of nephrons. Drug inhibiting this transporter are Canagliflozin, Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin, Ertugliflozin etc.
  • SGLT2 inhibitors are associated with specific adverse effects, including ketoacidosis, urosepsis, and Fournier’s gangrene.
  • However, angioedema is not a typical adverse effect of this class of drugs.

choices.text: Paresthesia over inner aspect

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes a Shirodkar sling operation for uterine prolapse. Postoperatively, the surgeon discusses potential complications associated with the procedure. Which of the following is NOT a potential complication of the Shirodkar sling operation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subacute intestinal obstructions

 

  • The Shirodkar sling operation, a surgical procedure used to treat uterine prolapse, involves placing a synthetic mesh or tape around the cervix to provide support.
  • Subacute intestinal obstructions are not typically associated with the Shirodkar sling operation.
  • This type of complication is more commonly related to abdominal or intestinal surgeries rather than pelvic procedures focused on supporting the uterus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterocele: This is a possible complication where a portion of the small intestine descends into the pelvic cavity, forming a hernia.

 

Option C. Ureteral injury: During the placement of the sling, there is a risk of injuring the ureters, which can lead to urinary complications.

 

Option D. Paresthesia over inner aspect: This complication can occur due to nerve damage or irritation during the surgery, leading to sensory changes in the inner thigh area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subacute intestinal obstructions are not typically a complication of the Shirodkar sling operation.
  • Common complications include enterocele, ureteral injury, and paresthesia over the inner aspect due to nerve involvement.

choices.text: It selectively inhibits the reuptake of serotonin, enhancing serotonergic activity in the brain.
It acts as a monoamine oxidase inhibitor, preventing the breakdown of neurotransmitters such as serotonin and norepinephrine.
It primarily blocks dopamine receptors to reduce psychotic symptoms.
It acts as a serotonin receptor modulator and reuptake inhibitor, affecting multiple neurotransmitter pathways.

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism of action of the antidepressant drug Vortioxetine?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It acts as a serotonin receptor modulator and reuptake inhibitor, affecting multiple neurotransmitter pathways.

 

  • Vortioxetine's mechanism involves both inhibition of serotonin reuptake and modulation of several serotonin receptors (including 5-HT1A agonism and 5-HT3, 5-HT7 antagonism).
  • This dual action not only enhances serotonin availability but also impacts various neural circuits involved in mood and cognition, making it effective against depression and associated cognitive dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It selectively inhibits the reuptake of serotonin, enhancing serotonergic activity in the brain: Incorrect, as vortioxetine also modulates serotonin receptors, not merely inhibiting reuptake.

 

Option B. It acts as a monoamine oxidase inhibitor, preventing the breakdown of neurotransmitters such as serotonin and norepinephrine: Incorrect, vortioxetine does not inhibit monoamine oxidase but works through serotonin modulation and reuptake inhibition.

 

Option C. It primarily blocks dopamine receptors to reduce psychotic symptoms: Incorrect, vortioxetine's action is centered on serotonin pathways, not dopamine receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vortioxetine- A novel antidepressant with a unique mechanism of action that includes-
    • Blockade of the reuptake of serotonin
    • Modulation of several serotonin receptors: Agonism at 5HT1A, partial agonism at 5HT1B, antagonism at 5HT3, 5HT1D and 5HT7 receptors.

questions.text: Free radicals primarily attack several biological targets in the body. Which of the following is not a main target of free radicals?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glycosaminoglycans

 

  • Free radicals are highly reactive molecules that cause damage to various cellular components.
  • The primary targets of free radicals include polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA), proteins, and DNA.
  • These molecules are particularly susceptible to oxidative damage, leading to cellular dysfunction and contributing to various diseases.
  • Glycosaminoglycans, while important in the extracellular matrix and joint function, are not primary targets of free radicals compared to PUFA, proteins, and DNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Protein: Proteins can be oxidatively modified by free radicals, leading to changes in their structure and function. This can affect enzyme activity, signaling pathways, and overall cellular function.

 

Option C. DNA: Free radicals can cause oxidative damage to DNA, resulting in mutations, strand breaks, and impaired replication and transcription. This type of damage is a significant contributor to cancer and other genetic diseases.

 

Option D. PUFA: Polyunsaturated fatty acids are highly susceptible to lipid peroxidation by free radicals. This process damages cell membranes and can disrupt cellular integrity and function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Free radicals primarily target polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA), proteins, and DNA, leading to significant cellular damage.
  • Glycosaminoglycans are not main targets of free radicals.

choices.text: Pancreatic Lipase, Lingual Lipase, Gastric Lipase
Lingual Lipase, Gastric Lipase, Pancreatic Lipase
Gastric Lipase, Lingual Lipase, Pancreatic Lipase
Pancreatic Lipase, Gastric Lipase, Lingual Lipase

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with symptoms of malabsorption. In the process of fat digestion and absorption, which sequence correctly outlines the activation of various lipases in the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lingual Lipase, Gastric Lipase, Pancreatic Lipase

 

  • The correct sequence of lipase activation in the gastrointestinal tract begins with lingual lipase, followed by gastric lipase, and then pancreatic lipase.
  • Lingual Lipase: Secreted by the glands in the tongue, lingual lipase begins the digestion of fats in the mouth, particularly effective in breaking down short- and medium-chain fatty acids.
  • Gastric Lipase: Produced by the stomach, gastric lipase continues the digestion of fats, particularly in the acidic environment of the stomach, further breaking down triglycerides into diglycerides and free fatty acids.
  • Pancreatic Lipase: Secreted by the pancreas into the small intestine, pancreatic lipase is the primary enzyme for fat digestion, breaking down triglycerides into monoglycerides and free fatty acids in the alkaline environment of the small intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct sequence of lipase activation in the gastrointestinal tract is lingual lipase, gastric lipase, and then pancreatic lipase, each playing a specific role in the digestion of dietary fats.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient with chronic angina is prescribed a medication to help alleviate chest pain by opening potassium channels. Which of the following drugs acts as a potassium channel opener?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nicorandil

 

  • Nicorandil is a potassium channel opener that helps to alleviate angina by causing vasodilation.
  • It opens ATP-sensitive potassium channels in vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to hyperpolarization and relaxation of the blood vessels, improving blood flow and reducing myocardial oxygen demand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ranolazine: Ranolazine works by inhibiting the late phase of the sodium current in cardiac cells, which indirectly reduces intracellular calcium levels. It does not open potassium channels.

 

Option C. Ivabradine: Ivabradine specifically inhibits the If (funny) current in the sinoatrial node, reducing heart rate without affecting potassium channels.

 

Option D. Nitroprusside: Nitroprusside is a nitric oxide donor that causes vasodilation through the release of NO, leading to the activation of guanylate cyclase and increased cyclic GMP. It does not open potassium channels.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Nicorandil is a potassium channel opener used to alleviate angina by causing vasodilation, thereby improving blood flow and reducing myocardial oxygen demand.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents with a one-year history of abdominal pain. An abdominal CT scan shows a 10-cm mass in the pancreas. Biopsy reveals adenocarcinoma with inactivation of SMAD4. Which regulatory pathway is most likely altered?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TGF-β

 

  • The inactivation of SMAD4 in pancreatic adenocarcinoma suggests an alteration in the TGF-β (transforming growth factor-beta) pathway.
  • SMAD4 is a key signal transducer in the TGF-β signaling pathway, which is involved in the regulation of cell growth, differentiation, and apoptosis.
  • Loss of SMAD4 function impairs TGF-β signaling, resulting in uncontrolled cell proliferation and tumor growth.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. BCL2: This gene is involved in regulating apoptosis by preventing cell death. It is not directly related to SMAD4 or the TGF-β pathway.

 

Option B. β-catenin: This protein is part of the Wnt signaling pathway and is involved in cell adhesion and transcription regulation. It is not associated with SMAD4 in the context described.

 

Option C. MYC: This oncogene regulates cell proliferation, growth, and apoptosis. While MYC can be altered in various cancers, it is not directly linked to the SMAD4 and TGF-β pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inactivation of SMAD4 in pancreatic adenocarcinoma disrupts the TGF-β signaling pathway, leading to diminished transcriptional activation of cyclin-dependent kinases and contributing to tumor growth.

choices.text: It is the principal prostaglandin synthesized in the stomach
Its biosynthesis is inhibited by aspirin
It stimulates gastric acid secretion
It causes dilatation of submucosal blood vessels

questions.text: All of the following are true about prostaglandin E2 except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It stimulates gastric acid secretion

 

  • This statement is false. PGE2 actually inhibits gastric acid secretion and promotes the secretion of mucus and bicarbonate, which are protective factors for the gastric mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the principal prostaglandin synthesized in the stomach: Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) is indeed the principal prostaglandin synthesized in the stomach, where it plays a key role in protecting the gastric mucosa.

 

Option B. Its biosynthesis is inhibited by aspirin: Aspirin, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, thereby reducing the biosynthesis of prostaglandins, including PGE2.

 

Option D. It causes dilatation of submucosal blood vessels: PGE2 causes vasodilation, including dilatation of submucosal blood vessels, which helps maintain mucosal blood flow and protect the gastric lining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) is crucial for gastric mucosal protection, inhibits gastric acid secretion, promotes mucus and bicarbonate secretion, and causes vasodilation of submucosal blood vessels.
  • Its synthesis is inhibited by aspirin.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of bilateral gluteal claudication and recent onset impotence. He mentions that walking exacerbates his pain, which is relieved by rest. On examination, an aortic bruit is audible. Which site of arterial obstruction is most likely associated with his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aorto-iliac artery

 

  • The patient's symptoms of bilateral gluteal claudication and impotence, coupled with the presence of an aortic bruit, are indicative of aorto-iliac occlusive disease.
  • This condition often presents with bilateral lower extremity claudication and can impact erectile function due to impaired blood flow to the pelvis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior tibial artery: Incorrect because symptoms would predominantly include claudication of the calf and foot, which does not match the patient's presentation of gluteal discomfort and impotence.

 

Option B. External iliac artery: Incorrect as unilateral thigh claudication would be more typical, whereas the patient exhibits bilateral symptoms and impotence.

 

Option D. Superficial femoral artery: Incorrect because this would more likely present with claudication in the calf, not the gluteal region or associated with impotence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aorto-iliac occlusive disease should be considered in patients presenting with bilateral lower extremity claudication, impotence, and an aortic bruit.
  • This condition is due to atherosclerotic blockages in the aorta and iliac arteries affecting blood flow to the lower limbs and pelvic organs.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man, who has been consuming a diet primarily consisting of Lathyrus sativus (grass pea) due to economic hardship and successive crop failures, presents with progressive weakness in his legs, spasticity, and difficulty walking. Which toxin is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BOAA

 

  • β-N-Oxalyl-L-α, β-diaminopropionic acid (BOAA) is a neurotoxin found in Lathyrus sativus (grass pea).
  • Chronic consumption of this legume can lead to lathyrism, which manifests as spastic paraparesis, upper motor neuron signs, and gait instability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aflatoxin: Aflatoxin is a mycotoxin produced by Aspergillus species and primarily causes liver damage and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option C. Ergot toxin: Ergot toxins, produced by Claviceps purpurea, can cause ergotism, characterized by hallucinations, severe vasoconstriction, and gangrene, but not spastic paraparesis.

 

Option D. Sanguinarine: Sanguinarine is an alkaloid found in certain plants like bloodroot and has antimicrobial properties, but is not associated with spastic paraparesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • BOAA is a neurotoxin found in Lathyrus sativus (grass pea), and its chronic consumption can lead to lathyrism, characterized by spastic paraparesis, upper motor neuron signs, and gait instability.
  • Recognizing the dietary sources and clinical manifestations of various toxins is crucial for diagnosing and managing toxin-induced conditions.
  • Human neurolathyrism (NL) is a self-limiting disease of the nervous system mainly affecting the upper motor neuron and causing degeneration of the distal corticospinal tract in the spinal cord which results in a spastic paraparesis spastic paraparesis, instability in gait’

questions.text: A 34-year-old man undergoing evaluation for infertility presents for a semen analysis. His sample shows a high percentage of nonmotile sperm, and the clinician needs to determine if these nonmotile sperm are dead or viable. Which of the following tests can differentiate between dead and nonmotile sperm?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypoosmotic swelling test

 

  • The hypoosmotic swelling (HOS) test is used to assess the viability of nonmotile sperm.
  • This test works by placing sperm in a hypoosmotic solution. Viable sperm, which have intact cell membranes, will swell due to the influx of water, while non-viable (dead) sperm will not swell.
  • This allows for the differentiation between nonmotile but live sperm and dead sperm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zona penetration assay: This test evaluates the ability of sperm to penetrate the zona pellucida of an ovum. It does not specifically differentiate between dead and nonmotile sperm.

 

Option B. DNA fragmentation index: This test measures the level of DNA damage in sperm. While important for assessing sperm quality, it does not differentiate between dead and nonmotile sperm.

 

Option D. Mannose fluorescence assay: This is not a standard test used in routine semen analysis or for differentiating between dead and nonmotile sperm. It is more related to sperm-egg binding studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The hypoosmotic swelling (HOS) test can differentiate between dead and nonmotile sperm by assessing the integrity of the sperm cell membrane.

questions.text: An infant present with an abnormal head shape. Based on the images provided, identify the abnormality:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trigonocephaly

 

  • Premature fusion of metopic suture is known as trigonocephaly

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brachycephaly: A condition where the head is disproportionately wide relative to its depth; does not fit the images shown.

 

Option C. Dolichocephaly: An elongated head shape in the anteroposterior dimension; also not represented in the images.

 

Option D. Plagiocephaly: premature fusion of lambdoid suture is known as plagiocephaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The condition responsible for premature fusion of metopic suture is known as trigonocephaly.
  • Early identification and intervention are crucial to manage and correct the deformity effectively.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a history of chronic lower back pain is consulting with her healthcare provider about various pain management strategies. The physician explains the gate control theory as one approach to modulating her pain perception to his resident. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily associated with the gate control theory in modulating pain perception?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain Suppression

 

  • The gate control theory of pain proposes that the spinal cord contains a neurological "gate" that either blocks pain signals or allows them to continue on to the brain.
  • Non-painful input closes the gates to painful input, which prevents pain sensation from traveling to the central nervous system.
  • This mechanism involves the activation of large-diameter Aβ fibers that inhibit the transmission of pain signals carried by smaller-diameter Aδ and C fibers, leading to pain suppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enhanced Pain Stimulation: This is incorrect. The gate control theory involves reducing pain perception by inhibiting pain signals, not enhancing pain stimulation.

 

Option B. Increased Pain Transmission: This is incorrect. The theory focuses on blocking or modulating pain signals, not increasing pain transmission.

 

Option C. Augmented Pain Perception: This is incorrect. The gate control theory aims to suppress or modulate pain perception, not augment it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The gate control theory of pain is primarily associated with pain suppression by modulating pain signals at the spinal cord level through the activation of non-painful input pathways, which inhibit the transmission of pain signals.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female undergoes a surgical procedure to manage gastroesophageal reflux disease, as illustrated in the image. Which complication is she most likely to experience in the early postoperative period?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysphagia

 

  • Dysphagia, or difficulty swallowing, is the most common complication following a 360-degree fundoplication, particularly in the short term.
  • This complication arises from the tight wrap of the gastric fundus around the esophagus, which can sometimes be overly restrictive, affecting the patient's ability to swallow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrence of symptomatic reflux: Incorrect - While the recurrence of symptomatic reflux can occur, it is less common immediately following surgery and typically associated with a failure of the procedure over time or improper surgical technique.

 

Option C. Esophageal perforation: Incorrect - Esophageal perforation is a severe but rare complication of this procedure, generally linked to surgical error rather than a common postoperative issue.

 

Option D. Infectious complications: Incorrect - Infectious complications are possible with any surgery but are not the most common issue following a 360-degree fundoplication, where mechanical complications like dysphagia predominate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Postoperative dysphagia is a frequently encountered complication following a 360-degree fundoplication and should be considered when evaluating patients after this procedure.
  • Careful surgical technique and appropriate patient selection are crucial to minimize this risk.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of myasthenia gravis presents with worsening muscle weakness. To differentiate between a myasthenic crisis and a cholinergic crisis, which of the following drugs should be used?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Edrophonium

 

  • Edrophonium is a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor.
  • It increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.
  • In patients experiencing a myasthenic crisis (due to insufficient acetylcholine), administration of edrophonium results in a dramatic improvement in muscle strength.
  • Conversely, in a cholinergic crisis (due to excess acetylcholine), edrophonium administration worsens the symptoms by further increasing acetylcholine levels.
  • This differential response helps clinicians distinguish between myasthenic and cholinergic crises.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neostigmine: Although it is also an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, neostigmine has a longer duration of action, making it less suitable for this diagnostic test.

 

Option C. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that counteracts the effects of acetylcholine but is not used for differentiating between myasthenic and cholinergic crises.

 

Option D. Acetylcholine: Direct administration of acetylcholine is not practical or effective for this diagnostic purpose.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Edrophonium is preferred for differentiating between myasthenic crisis and cholinergic crisis due to its short duration of action.
  • It increases acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, improving symptoms in myasthenic crisis and worsening them in cholinergic crisis, thus aiding in the accurate diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic heart failure is undergoing evaluation for his condition. During an arterial pulse waveform analysis, the presence of a dicrotic notch is noted. The dicrotic notch in the arterial pulse waveform corresponds to which of the following events?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Closure of aortic valve

 

  • The dicrotic notch in the arterial pulse waveform represents the closure of the aortic valve.
  • When the left ventricle finishes ejecting blood into the aorta, the aortic valve closes to prevent backflow into the ventricle.
  • This closure causes a brief and characteristic dip in the arterial pressure waveform, known as the dicrotic notch, marking the end of systole and the beginning of diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Opening of mitral valve: The opening of the mitral valve occurs during diastole, allowing blood to flow from the left atrium into the left ventricle. This event does not produce a dicrotic notch in the arterial pulse waveform.

 

Option B. Closure of mitral valve: The closure of the mitral valve marks the beginning of ventricular systole, which prevents blood from flowing back into the left atrium. This event is associated with the first heart sound (S1) but does not produce a dicrotic notch in the arterial pulse waveform.

 

Option C. Opening of aortic valve: The opening of the aortic valve occurs at the start of systole, allowing the left ventricle to eject blood into the aorta. This event does not create a dicrotic notch in the arterial pulse waveform.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The dicrotic notch in the arterial pulse waveform is associated with the closure of the aortic valve, signaling the end of systole and the beginning of diastole.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man has had severe abdominal pain for the past 2 days. Physical examination shows board-like rigidity of the abdominal muscles, making further examination difficult. There is no observable abdominal distension. The representative gross appearance of the disease process is shown in the figure. Which of the following is the mechanism most likely to produce this appearance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dysregulation of trypsinogen inactivation

 

  • The image provided suggests a pancreatic pathology, likely acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis with foci of white chalky necrosis, given the clinical presentation of severe abdominal pain and the gross appearance of the pancreas.
  • Acute pancreatitis is commonly associated with dysregulation of trypsinogen inactivation.
  • Normally, trypsinogen is activated to trypsin in the small intestine, but premature activation within the pancreas leads to autodigestion and inflammation, which is what can be seen in the image.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. CFTR gene mutation: Mutations in the CFTR gene are responsible for cystic fibrosis, which can lead to chronic pancreatitis due to thick secretions that block the pancreatic ducts. However, this does not typically lead to the acute process seen in the image.

 

Option B. Coxsackievirus B infection: This is associated with myocarditis and pericarditis, and while it can affect other organs, it is not a common cause of the acute pancreatitis depicted in the image.

 

Option D. K-RAS gene mutation: Mutations in the K-RAS gene are often seen in cancers, including pancreatic cancer, but would not cause the acute process indicated by the gross pathology in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the context of acute severe abdominal pain and the pathologic appearance of the pancreas suggesting pancreatitis, dysregulation of trypsinogen inactivation is the most likely mechanism of disease, leading to autodigestion of the pancreas and the clinical presentation of acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of recurrent spontaneous abortions is undergoing evaluation. Which of the following investigations is least warranted in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Testing for TORCH infections

 

  • In cases of recurrent spontaneous abortion, certain investigations are prioritized to identify common and treatable causes.
  • Testing for TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other infections, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, and Herpes simplex virus) is not typically warranted because these infections are not common causes of recurrent pregnancy loss.
  • Instead, investigations focus on anatomical, immunological, hormonal, and genetic factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testing for antiphospholipid antibodies: This test is crucial because antiphospholipid syndrome is a well-known cause of recurrent pregnancy loss. Detecting and treating this condition can significantly improve pregnancy outcomes.

 

Option B. Hysteroscopy: This procedure allows direct visualization of the uterine cavity to identify any structural abnormalities (e.g., uterine septum, fibroids, adhesions) that could contribute to recurrent pregnancy loss.

 

Option C. Thyroid function tests: Thyroid dysfunction, particularly hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism, can impact pregnancy and is an important factor to rule out or manage in women with recurrent pregnancy loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Testing for TORCH infections is generally not warranted in the evaluation of recurrent spontaneous abortion, as these infections are not common causes of recurrent pregnancy loss.
  • Evaluation should focus on anatomical, immunological, hormonal, and genetic factors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to an ENT clinic with a 6-month history of dull, persistent pharyngeal pain radiating to his ears and exacerbated by turning his head. He also complains of intermittent episodes of dysphagia and a sensation of a foreign body in his throat. On examination, a palpable mass is noted in the tonsillar fossa. Which condition is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Classic Eagle syndrome

 

  • Classic Eagle syndrome is characterized by dull and persistent pharyngeal pain that often radiates to the ear, exacerbated by head rotation, and can be associated with a palpable mass or bulge in the tonsillar fossa.
  • The patient’s symptoms align closely with this condition, making it the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glossopharyngeal neuralgia: Presents typically with sharp, stabbing throat pain that can radiate to the ears, triggered by swallowing, coughing, or yawning, not typically associated with a palpable mass.

 

Option B. Tonsillitis: While it can cause throat pain and sometimes referred ear pain, it is usually associated with signs of infection such as fever and tonsillar exudates, which are not described here.

 

Option D. Laryngopharyngeal reflux: Causes throat irritation and symptoms of reflux like heartburn and voice changes, not typically associated with a palpable mass or pain exacerbated specifically by head rotation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Classic Eagle syndrome should be considered in patients presenting with unexplained persistent pharyngeal pain, especially if associated with a palpable tonsillar mass and exacerbated by head movements.
  • Diagnosis can often be supported by imaging studies and physical examination.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes, central obesity, and abnormal liver enzymes is evaluated for risk of future complications. Without treatment, she is at greatest risk for which condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steatohepatitis

 

  • The most common complications of metabolic syndrome include cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), which can lead to liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Central sleep apnea: Risk factors for central sleep apnea include cardiac abnormalities and chronic opioid use.

 

Option B. Osteoporosis: Obesity is protective against osteoporosis.

 

Option D. Subarachnoid haemorrhage: Metabolic syndrome is associated with ischemic stroke rather than subarachnoid hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common complications of metabolic syndrome include cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)

choices.text: Phyllodes tumors are always benign.
Treatment options include wide local excision or simple mastectomy.
Axillary clearance is not typically required for phyllodes tumors.
Phyllodes tumors can present with a bosselated surface and overlying ulceration.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a large, mobile mass in her breast. She reports the mass has been growing rapidly but is not painful. After a biopsy, she is diagnosed with a phyllodes tumor. Based on the information provided, which of the following statements about phyllodes tumors is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phyllodes tumors are always benign.

 

  • Phyllodes tumors can be benign, borderline, or malignant based on histological features.
  • While they are generally benign, malignant phyllodes tumors do occur and can be aggressive, making statement A false.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Treatment options include wide local excision or simple mastectomy: This is correct as both wide local excision (WLE) and simple mastectomy are standard treatments depending on the size, location, and histologic grade of the tumor.

 

Option C. Axillary clearance is not typically required for phyllodes tumors: Correct, because phyllodes tumors rarely metastasize to axillary lymph nodes, axillary dissection is usually unnecessary unless there is clear evidence of nodal involvement.

 

Option D. Phyllodes tumors can present with a bosselated surface and overlying ulceration: Correct, phyllodes tumors often present as large, palpable masses with these physical characteristics.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Phyllodes tumors of the breast can range from benign to malignant and do not always necessitate axillary lymph node dissection unless there is clinical or pathological evidence of metastasis.
  • Management usually involves surgical resection with an emphasis on obtaining clear margins to reduce recurrence rates.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a sudden severe headache, initially at the back of her head, presents with hypertension and smoking history. CT is normal and hence Lumbar puncture was tried. It showed the following result What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CT Angiogram

 

  • Xanthochromia in CSF confirms SAH and hence, CT Angiogram is the most appropriate step in this case to localize the berry aneurysm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Admission for overnight observation: Admission without further workup could delay localization of the aneurysm.

 

Option C. Repeat Lumbar puncture: Repeating Lumbar puncture would reveal the same result and hence, unnecessary.

 

Option D. MRI brain: MRI brain will not help in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CT Angiogram is the most appropriate step in this case to localize the berry aneurysm.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with progressive hearing loss and balance issues. Imaging reveals a mass in the cerebellopontine angle. The physician considers the differential diagnoses but needs to exclude one condition that is unlikely to present in this location. The differential diagnosis can include all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tuberculoma

 

  • Tuberculoma does not cause cerebellopontine angle mass.
  • They are ring-enhancing lesions within the brain parenchyma, most commonly around the brainstem.

 

 

Acoustic schwannoma is the most common cerebellopontine tumor (90%).

 

CP (cerebellopontine) angle Tumors

 

  • S: Schwannoma

 

  • A: Arachnoid cyst
  • M: Meningioma, Metastases
  • E: Epidermoid cyst
  • Tuberculomas are granulomatous lesions caused by tuberculosis and are more commonly found in the cerebral hemispheres, brainstem, and spinal cord.
  • They are rare in the cerebellopontine angle and not typically considered in the differential diagnosis for a mass in this location.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meningioma: Meningiomas are common tumors that can occur in the cerebellopontine angle, arising from the meninges.

 

Option B. Acoustic schwannoma: Acoustic schwannomas (vestibular schwannomas) are the most common tumors in the cerebellopontine angle, originating from the Schwann cells of the vestibulocochlear nerve.

 

Option D. Epidermoid cyst: Epidermoid cysts are benign growths that can also occur in the cerebellopontine angle, presenting with similar symptoms due to compression of adjacent structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While meningiomas, acoustic schwannomas, and epidermoid cysts are common in the cerebellopontine angle, tuberculomas are rare in this location and are not typically included in the differential diagnosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with neck pain and limited range of motion following a minor car accident. Radiologic examination reveals an abnormality in the apical ligament of the dens. This ligament is embryologically derived from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Notochord

 

  • The apical ligament of the dens, also known as the apical odontoid ligament, is embryologically derived from the notochord.
  • The notochord is a rod-like structure that forms during early embryogenesis and plays a critical role in the development of the vertebral column and the axial skeleton.
  • In the adult, remnants of the notochord contribute to the structure of the intervertebral discs, particularly the nucleus pulposus, and certain ligaments like the apical ligament of the dens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neural Tube: The neural tube gives rise to the central nervous system, including the brain and spinal cord. It does not contribute to the formation of the apical ligament of the dens.

 

Option B. Neural Crest: Neural crest cells differentiate into a wide variety of structures, including peripheral nerves, the adrenal medulla, and certain facial cartilage and bones. However, they do not contribute to the formation of the apical ligament of the dens.

 

Option D. Neuropore: The neuropores are the openings at the ends of the neural tube that close during development. They are not directly involved in the formation of the apical ligament of the dens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The apical ligament of the dens is derived from the notochord, which is a key embryological structure involved in the development of the vertebral column and related structures.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man in a nursing home presents with coughing up copious amounts of blood-tinged sputum, digital clubbing, and cyanosis of the lips. Physical exam reveals coarse crackles throughout the lungs, and chest X-ray shows increased translucency and tram-track opacities in the right lower lung field. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bronchiectasis

 

  • Bronchiectasis presents with chronic cough, copious sputum production, hemoptysis, and characteristic X-ray findings like bronchial wall thickening (tram-track opacities).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chronic bronchitis: Chronic bronchitis involves a chronic productive cough, but less hemoptysis and no tram-track opacities.

 

Option C. Aspiration pneumonia: Aspiration pneumonia usually presents with acute symptoms and localized infiltrates.

 

Option D. Emphysema: Emphysema involves chronic cough and small amounts of sputum, without the tram-track opacities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bronchiectasis presents with chronic cough, copious sputum production, hemoptysis, and characteristic X-ray findings like bronchial wall thickening.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a 10-day history of abdominal pain, dark urine, and purpuric skin lesions. Urinalysis shows hematuria and proteinuria. Serologic tests are negative for P-ANCAs and C-ANCAs. Skin biopsy reveals necrotizing vasculitis of small dermal vessels, and renal biopsy shows IgA-rich immune complex deposition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Henoch-Schönlein purpura

 

  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a small vessel vasculitis primarily affecting children.
  • It is characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in small vessels.
  • The clinical presentation typically includes a triad of palpable purpura, abdominal pain, and renal involvement, such as hematuria and proteinuria.
  • The biopsy findings of necrotizing vasculitis in the dermis and IgA deposition in the glomeruli are consistent with HSP.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Takayasu arteritis: This vasculitis affects large arteries, particularly the aorta and its branches, and is not associated with IgA deposition or the described clinical features in children.

 

Option C. Wegener granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis): This condition involves granulomatous inflammation affecting the respiratory tract and kidneys and is associated with ANCA positivity, not IgA deposition.

 

Option D. Giant cell arteritis: This vasculitis affects large and medium-sized arteries and primarily occurs in older adults, not in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by IgA deposition, presenting with palpable purpura, abdominal pain, and renal involvement, making it the most likely diagnosis in this scenario.
